    If a city employee takes an open competitive examination for a position and passes, his or her name will be placed on a promotion list. 
(Ord. 25 § 12.0, 1943) 
2.72.150 - Reemployment list. 
    Employees separated from the service through no fault of their own will be placed on a reemployment list in the order of ratings which will give major emphasis to their efficiency and will also reflect their length of service with the city. 
    Employees who resign their positions in good standing may be placed on a reemployment list with the approval of the department head provided they seek reinstatement into the service within one year from the effective date of their resignation. The ranking of such employees on the list will be based on the same factors used for employees separated from the service as above. 
(Ord. 25 § 13.0, 1943) 
2.72.160 - Eligible lists. 
    The personnel director shall, from time to time, as conditions warrant, with such outside assistance as required, hold tests where feasible for the purpose of establishing eligible lists for the various positions in the service. 
    The tests shall be such as will determine the relative qualifications and fitness of the candidates for each position. 
(Ord. 25 § 14.0, 1943) 
2.72.170 - Appointments to vacant positions. 
    Whenever a position in the service becomes vacant, the appointing authority shall make a requisition to the personnel director for persons eligible for appointment thereto. 
    The personnel director shall certify the names of three persons standing highest from these lists in the order named: departmental reemployment list, general reemployment list, transfer list, promotion list, and eligible list. 
    If there are insufficient names on any of the lists, names shall be certified from each succeeding list until three persons are certified. 
    If there is more than one vacancy to be filled, the number of persons certified shall be two more names than there are vacancies. 
    The appointing authority shall notify the personnel director of the appointment to the position and the date the appointment takes effect. 
(Ord. 25 § 15.0, 1943) 
2.72.180 - Working test period. 
    All appointments shall be made for a working test period of not to exceed six months, unless said period is extended in accordance with Section 2.72.070 of this chapter. 
    If at any time during such working test period, upon observation or consideration of the performance of duty, the appointing officer deems the appointee unfit or unsatisfactory for service, the appointing officer may release such person by notifying the personnel director in writing and setting forth the reasons for the dismissal. Any person released shall not have the right to appeal for a hearing. 
    In the case of such release, if the employee has been transferred or promoted, he or she shall be returned to his or her former position, and, if from a promotional list, a reemployment list, or an eligible list, he or she may be restored to the proper list by the personnel director should such action appear to be for the best interest of the service. 
    At the conclusion of the working test period, the services of the employee shall be terminated automatically unless the appointing authority notifies the personnel director that the services of appointee are satisfactory. 
(Ord. 25 § 16.0, 1943) 
2.72.190 - Temporary appointments. 
    Appointments to temporary positions may be made for periods not to exceed six months; provided, however, if the appointment is from an eligible list, the appointment may be renewed for an additional period. 
    If, during such a period, it is decided the position shall be changed from a temporary status to a permanent status, the provisions of Section 2.72.170 of this chapter shall be applied. 
(Ord. 25 § 17.0, 1943) 
2.72.200 - Provisional appointments. 
    When a permanent or a temporary position is vacant and there is no list of appointees and it is necessary to fill the position immediately, a provisional appointment may be made. 
    The appointing authority shall appoint to the position someone who is qualified to fill the position. 
    A provisional appointment shall last only until a list of appointees is created, but in no case to exceed sixty (60) days. 
    A person receiving a provisional appointment may take the examination for the position and be certified and appointed to the position. 
(Ord. 25 § 18.0, 1943) 
2.72.210 - Emergency appointments. 
    If necessary, to prevent the stoppage of public business, the appointing authority may fill a position by emergency appointment. 
    No emergency appointment shall be for a longer period than thirty (30) days, and no person shall serve for more than thirty (30) days in any one year. 
(Ord. 25 § 19.0, 1943) 
2.72.220 - Certification of payrolls. 
    The personnel director shall sign every payroll, before payment is made, and make certain that only authorized persons are placed on the payroll, that proper class titles and rates of pay are observed and that regulations relating to hours of work and leave are enforced. 
(Ord. 25 § 20.0, 1943) 
2.72.230 - Attendance and leave regulations. 
    The personnel director shall prepare and recommend to the city council regulations concerning hours of work and leave regulations. 
(Ord. 25 § 21.0, 1943) 
2.72.240 - Penalties-Demotions. 
    Whenever an employee is incapable of performing his or her work satisfactorily, or as a disciplinary action for misconduct not justifying dismissal, the appointing authority may demote the person to a lower grade. 
    The personnel advisory board shall be notified of the demotion and the reasons therefor. 
(Ord. 25 § 22.0, 1943) 
2.72.250 - Penalties-Suspensions. 
    For disciplinary purposes, the appointing authority may suspend, without pay, any employee for a period or periods not exceeding thirty (30) days within one calendar year, and if any suspension has the effect of making the total time more than thirty (30) days, it shall be considered a dismissal. 
    The personnel advisory board shall be notified of the suspension and the reasons therefor. 
(Ord. 25 § 23.0, 1943) 
2.72.260 - Terminations-Dismissals. 
    The appointing authority may dismiss any employee for inefficiency, insubordination, lack of cooperation, habitual tardiness, or other just cause for the good of the service. 
    The personnel advisory board shall be notified of the dismissal and the reasons therefor. 
(Ord. 25 § 24.0, 1943) 
2.72.270 - Terminations-Layoffs. 
    Whenever, because of lack of work or funds, it is necessary to reduce the number of employees, the personnel director shall make an investigation of the matter and make a report to the personnel advisory board. 
    Consideration shall be given to the length of service of the employee and his or her efficiency on the job. 
(Ord. 25 § 25.0, 1943) 
2.72.280 - Terminations-Resignations. 
    An employee resigning from the service shall, whenever possible, give sufficient notice of his or her intention to enable the city to make proper provisions for the filling of his or her position. 
    All resignations shall be in writing and shall be filed with the personnel director. 
(Ord. 25 § 26.0, 1943) 
2.72.290 - Notice to employees. 
    In the case of demotions, suspensions, dismissals, and layoffs, the employee shall be notified by the appointing authority in writing setting forth the reasons therefor. 
(Ord. 25 § 27.0, 1943) 
2.72.300 - Appeal. 
    Any employee who is demoted, suspended, or dismissed, or believes he or she has been unfairly treated or discriminated against may make an appeal to the personnel advisory board in writing and request a hearing thereon if he or she desires. 
    Such appeal shall state the pertinent facts relating to the cause of appeal and shall be filed with the secretary of the personnel advisory board within twenty (20) days after he or she has been notified of the action against which he or she is appealing. 
    After considering all the evidence, the personnel advisory board may: 
A.  Reinstate the employee after dismissal or demotion, with or without pay for lost time; 
B.  Reduce the period of suspension and provide the employee be compensated for the lost time or not allow such pay; 
C.  Confirm the demotion, suspension, dismissal, or layoff; 
D.  Place the employee on the eligible list for future employment. 
    The determination of the personnel advisory board shall be deemed administratively final. 
(Ord. 351 § 2, 1964; Ord. 87 § 1 (part), 1948; Ord. 25 § 28.0, 1943) 
2.72.310 - Political activity prohibited. 
    No officer or employee or member of the personnel advisory board shall be a candidate for any elective office of the city or become actively interested in a political campaign for an elective public office of the city without first resigning from his or her position. This provision shall in no way interfere with the right of a person to sign a petition or cast his or her vote as an individual. 
(Ord. 243 § 1, 1958; Ord. 25 § 29.0, 1943) 
Chapter 2.76 - 1945 RETIREMENT PLAN 
Sections: 

2.76.010 - Established. 
    The city employees retirement system is established for the purpose of providing retirement allowances for employees of the city, and certain benefits to beneficiaries of the employees, under the provisions of this chapter. The effective date of the retirement system shall be July 1, 1945. 
(Ord. 212 § 1, 1956: Ord. 60 § 1, 1945) 
2.76.020 - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases as used in this chapter, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the following meanings: 
A.  "Accumulated contributions" means the sums of all amounts deducted from the compensations of a member and credited to his or her individual account in the annuity savings fund, together with regular interest thereon. 
B.  "Annuity" means an annual amount, payable for the life of a person, derived from the accumulated contributions of a member. All annuities shall be paid in equal monthly installments. 
C.  "Annuity reserve" means the present value of all payments to be made on account of any annuity, or benefit in lieu of any annuity, computed upon the basis of such mortality tables and regular interest, as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
D.  "Beneficiary" means any person in receipt of a retirement allowance, pension, or other benefit, payable from funds of the retirement system on account of credited service rendered by another person. 
E.  "Board" means the board of trustees provided for in this chapter. 
F.  "City" means the city of Hazel Park, Michigan. 
G.  "Compensation" means the salary or wages paid a member by the city for personal services rendered by him or her to the city as an officer or employee of the city. In case a member's compensation is not all paid in money, the board shall fix the value of that part of his or her compensation not paid in money. 
H.  "Council" means the city council. 
I.  "Credited service" means the sum of the membership service and prior service credited a member, to the extent provided in this chapter. 
J.  "Final average compensation" means the average of the highest annual compensations received by a member during a period of five consecutive years of credited service contained within his or her ten years of credited service immediately preceding his or her retirement. If a member has less than five years of credited service his or her final average compensation shall be the average of his or her annual compensation received during his or her total years of credited service. 
K.  "Final compensation" means a member's annual rate of compensation at the time his or her city employment last terminates. 
L.  "General member" means any member except a police officer or firefighter member. 
M.  "Member" means any person included in the membership of the retirement system. 
N.  "Membership service" means service rendered after June 30, 1945. 
O.  "Pension" means an annual amount, payable for the life of a person, derived from money provided by the city, or any appropriating division of the city. All pensions shall be paid in equal monthly installments. 
P.  "Pension reserve" means the present value of all payments to be made on account of any pension, or benefit in lieu of any pension, computed upon the basis of such mortality and other tables of experience, and regular interest, as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
Q.  "Police officer or firefighter member" or "police officers and firefighters members," means any officer or employee of the police or fire department of the city holding the rank of patrolman or firefighter, as the case may be, or higher rank; provided, that in no case shall the terms police officer or firefighter member and police officers and firefighters members include any person privately employed as a police officer or firefighter, any person temporarily employed as a police officer or firefighter for an emergency, nor civilian employees in either the police or fire department. 
R.  "Prior service" means service rendered prior to July 1, 1945. 
S.  "Regular interest" means such rate or rates of interest per year, compounded annually, as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
T.  "Retirant" means any member who retires with a retirement allowance or pension payable from funds of the retirement system. 
U.  "Retirement" means withdrawal from service with a retirement allowance or pension payable from funds of the retirement system. 
V.  "Retirement allowance" means the sum of the annuity and the pension. 
W.  "Retirement system" means the city employees retirement system. 
X.  "Service" means personal service rendered to the city by an officer or employee of the city. In the case of the transfer to the city of the functions of any department in the government of Royal Oak Township, the persons in the employ of the department, as of the date of such transfer, who become employed by the city within six months from and after the date of such transfer shall have their Royal Oak Township service rendered from and after June 30, 1945, credited them as city service; provided, that the person deposits in the annuity savings fund, prior to July 1, 1953, the accumulated contributions credited to him or her in the employees' savings fund of the municipal employees' retirement system, established by Act No. 135 of the Public Acts of 1945, as amended, and is not entitled to a deferred retirement allowance provided by the municipal employees' retirement system. 
Y.  "Voluntary retirement age" means age sixty (60) years for a general member, and age fifty-five (55) years for a police officer or firefighter member; provided, that the council may, in the national interest during time of war engaged in by the United States or other national emergency, extend the age at which any class of members may voluntarily retire. 
(Ord. 212 § 2, 1956: Ord. 146 § 1, 1953: Ord. 60 § 2, 1945) 
2.76.030 - Board of trustees-Members. 
    There is created a board of trustees in whom is vested the general administration, management and responsibility for the proper operation of the retirement system and for making effective the provisions of this chapter. The board shall be organized immediately after three trustees have qualified. The board shall consist of seven trustees, as follows: 
A.  Two members of the council to be selected by the council; 
B.  The city manager; 
C.  A police officer to be elected by the members of the police department to represent them and a firefighter to be elected by the members of the fire department; 
D.  Two members of the retirement system, other than a police officer or firefighter member, to be elected by the members of the retirement system other than police officers and firefighters members; 
E.  The member trustees provided for in subsections C and D of this section shall be elected under such rules and regulations as the board shall adopt to govern such elections. 
(Ord. 428 §§ 1-3, 1968: Ord. 60 § 3,1945) 
2.76.040 - Preliminary board. 
    Until the first election is held the city manager shall appoint the member trustees provided for in Section 2.76.030 subsections C and D to serve until their successors are elected and have qualified. The board so constituted, including the trustees provided for in Section 2.76.030 subsections A and B shall order and arrange for an election by the members of the retirement system to be held within ninety (90) days after the effective date of the retirement system. At the first election the police officer or firefighter trustee shall serve two years, and the general city trustee shall serve one year. 
(Ord. 60 § 4, 1945) 
2.76.050 - Term of office-Compensation. 
    After the first election, the regular term of office of a member trustee shall be two years. Each trustee shall, within ten days after his or her election or appointment, take an oath of office to be administered by the city clerk. The members of the board shall serve without compensation for their services as trustees. 
(Ord. 60 § 5, 1945) 
2.76.060 - Vacancy-Filling. 
    If a vacancy occurs in the office of a member trustee, the city manager shall, within thirty (30) days after the date of the vacancy, appoint a qualified person to fill the vacancy for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. 60 § 6, 1945) 
2.76.070 - Meetings-Rules. 
    The board shall hold meetings regularly, at least one in each month, and shall designate the time and place thereof. Three trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board. Each trustee shall be entitled to one vote in the meetings of the board and at least three concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision by the trustees. The board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the board shall be public. 
(Ord. 60 § 7, 1945) 
2.76.080 - Chairman of the board-Officers. 
A.  The board shall elect from its members a chairman and a vice-chairman. 
B.  The city clerk shall be the secretary and the administrative officer of the retirement system. 
C.  The city treasurer shall be treasurer of the retirement system and the custodian of its funds. All payments from the funds of the retirement system shall be made only upon warrant checks signed by the city manager and the city clerk and countersigned by the city treasurer. No payment from the funds of the retirement system shall be made unless it has been previously authorized by resolution of the board. 
D.  The city attorney shall be the legal advisor to the board. 
E.  The board shall appoint an actuary who shall be the technical advisor to the board on matters regarding the operation of the retirement system and who shall perform such other duties as are required in connection therewith. 
F.  The board shall appoint as medical director a physician who is not eligible to membership in the retirement system. The medical director shall be responsible to and shall hold office at the pleasure of the board. The medical director shall arrange for and shall pass upon all medical examinations required under the provisions of this chapter, shall investigate all essential statements and certificates of a medical nature by or on behalf of a member or beneficiary in connection with an application for disability benefits, and shall report in writing to the board his or her conclusions on matters referred to him or her. 
G.  The board shall employ such professional and clerical services as are required for the proper operation of the retirement system. Compensation for such services shall be determined according to provisions of the City Charter. 
(Ord. 60 § 8, 1945) 
2.76.090 - Records-Report. 
    The secretary shall keep, or cause to be kept, in convenient form, such data as shall be necessary for an actuarial valuation of the assets and liabilities of the retirement system. The board shall render a report to the council on or before the first day of November of each year, showing the fiscal transactions of the retirement system for the year ending the preceding thirtieth day of June, and the last balance sheet showing the financial condition of the retirement system by means of an actuarial valuation of the assets and liabilities of the retirement system. 
(Ord. 60 § 9, 1945) 
2.76.100 - Adoption of tables. 
    The board shall adopt such mortality and other tables of experience as are necessary in the operation of the retirement system on an actuarial basis. 
(Ord. 60 § 10, 1945) 
2.76.110 - Retirement system members. 
    The membership of the retirement system shall include all officers and employees who are in the regular employ of the city on the day preceding the effective date of the retirement system and who continue in the employ of the city on and after the effective date of the retirement system and all persons who become employed by the city on and after the effective date of the retirement system. The membership of the retirement system shall not include any person whose services are compensated for on a contractual or fee basis, nor any person whose compensation paid by the city averages less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) a year. 
    In all cases of doubt, the board shall decide who is a member within the meaning of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 60 § 11, 1945) 
2.76.120 - Termination of membership. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, should any member leave city service, for any reason except his or her retirement or death, he or she shall thereupon cease to be a member and his or her credited service at that time shall be forfeited by him or her. If he or she is reemployed by the city he or she shall again become a member of the retirement system and should his or her reemployment occur within a period of five years from and after the date he or she last separated from city service his or her credited service last forfeited by him or her shall be restored to his or her credit; provided, that he or she returns to the annuity savings fund all amounts he or she might have withdrawn therefrom at the time he or she last left city service, together with regular interest thereon from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. Upon becoming a retirant or upon his or her death, his or her membership shall terminate. 
(Ord. 212 § 3, 1956: Ord. 146 § 2, 1953: Ord. 60 § 12, 1945) 
2.76.130 - Years of service. 
    The board shall fix and determine by appropriate rules and regulations how much service in any year is equivalent to a year of service, but in no case shall less than ten days' service in a calendar month constitute a month of service, nor shall less than ten months' service in a calendar year constitute a year of service, nor shall more than one year of service be credited for all service rendered in one calendar year. 
(Ord. 60 § 13, 1945) 
2.76.140 - War service credit. 
    An officer, employee or member who, while employed by the city, entered or enters any armed service of the United States and who has been or who shall be on active duty during time of war, or other national emergency recognized by the council, shall be credited with the period of such armed service in the same manner as if his or her city service had not been interrupted; provided, that he or she returns to city employment within one year from and after the date of termination of such armed service required of him or her, and that he or she returns to the annuity savings fund all amounts he or she might have withdrawn therefrom at the time he or she entered or while in such armed service, together with regular interest thereon from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment; provided, further, that in any case of doubt as to the period to be so credited any member, the board shall have final power to determine such period. During the period of such absence from city service a member's contributions to the annuity savings fund shall be suspended and his or her balance standing to his or her credit in said fund shall be accumulated at regular interest. 
(Ord. 212 § 4, 1956: Ord. 60 § 14, 1945) 
2.76.150 - Service account. 
    The board shall maintain a service account for each member and shall credit the account with the number of years and months of service to which the member is entitled according to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 212 § 5, 1956: Ord. 60 § 15, 1945) 
2.76.160 - Voluntary retirement. 
    Any member who has attained or attains his or her voluntary retirement age and has ten or more years of credited service may retire upon his or her written application filed with the board setting forth at what time, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof, he or she desires to be retired. Upon his or her retirement he or she shall receive a retirement allowance provided for in Section 2.76.180. 
(Ord. 212 § 6, 1956: Ord. 60 § 16, 1945) 
2.76.170 - Normal retirement. 
A.  Any police officer or firefighter member who has attained or attains age sixty (60) years, and any general member, except an elected officer, who has attained or attains age sixty-five (65) years shall be separated from city service on the first day of the calendar month next following the month in which he or she attains age sixty (60) or sixty-five (65) years, as the case may be. 
B.  Any member, with ten or more years of credited service, who leaves city service as provided in this section shall be retired and he or she shall receive a retirement allowance provided for in Section 2.76.180. 
(Ord. 372 §§ 1-3, 1965; Ord. 212 § 7, 1956; Ord. 60 § 17, 1945) 
2.76.180 - Service retirement allowance. 
A.  A member's regular retirement allowance shall consist of the applicable benefits provided in this section. Upon his or her retirement he or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 2.76.200. 
1.  An annuity which shall be the actuarial equivalent of his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the annuity savings fund at the time of his or her retirement; and 
2.  A basic pension of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year; and 
3.  A membership service pension of 1/120 of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the number of years, and fraction of a year, of his or her credited service rendered after June 30, 1945; and 
4.  A prior service pension of 2/135 of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the number of years, and fraction of a year, of his or her credited service rendered prior to July 1, 1945. 
B.  In no case shall the regular retirement allowance, provided for in subsection A, payable to a police officer or firefighter member, be less than the sum of two percent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the first twenty-five (25) years of his or her credited service, plus one percent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the number of years, and fraction of a year, his or her credited service is in excess of twenty-five (25) years. 
C.  If a retirant dies before he or she has received in payment of his or her regular retirement allowance an aggregate amount equal to, but not exceeding, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the annuity savings fund at the time of his or her retirement, the difference between his or her accumulated contributions and the aggregate amount of retirement allowance payments received by him or her shall be paid to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If there is no such designated person or persons surviving the retirant, such difference, if any, shall be paid to the retirant's legal representative. No benefits shall be paid under this subsection on account of the death of a retirant if he or she elected option I, II or III provided for in Section 2.76.200. 
(Ord. 212 § 8, 1956: Ord. 117 § 1, 1950: Ord. 96 § 1, 1948: Ord. 60 § 18, 1945) 
2.76.190 - Retirement allowance. 
    A member who has twenty-five (25) or more years of credited service or has attained or attains age fifty-five (55) years and has fifteen (15) or more years of credited service in the case of a general member or has attained or attains age fifty (50) years and has fifteen (15) years or more of credited service in the case of a police officer or firefighter member, and in either case leaves city service prior to his or her attainment of his or her voluntary retirement age, for any reason except his or her retirement or death, shall receive a retirement allowance provided for in Section 2.76.180. His or her retirement allowance shall begin as of the first day of the calendar month next following the date his or her application for the same is filed with the board on or after his or her attainment of his or her voluntary retirement age. In the event the member withdraws all or part of his or her accumulated contributions from the annuity savings fund, he or she shall thereupon forfeit his or her right to a deferred retirement allowance provided for in this section. 
(Ord. 246 § 1, 1958: Ord. 212 § 9, 1956: Ord. 117 § 2, 1950: Ord. 60 § 19, 1945) 
2.76.200 - Retirement allowance-Options. 
A.  Any member may, prior to the effective date of his or her retirement but not thereafter, elect to receive his or her retirement allowance as a regular retirement allowance payable throughout his or her life, or he or she may elect to receive the actuarial equivalent, at that time, of his or her regular retirement allowance in a reduced retirement allowance payable throughout his or her life, and nominate a beneficiary, in accordance with the provisions of option I, II or III as set forth as follows: 
    Option I-Cash Refund Annuity. If a retirant dies before he or she has received in payment of the annuity portions of his or her reduced retirement allowance an aggregate amount equal to, but not exceeding, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the annuity savings fund at the time of his or her retirement, the difference between his or her accumulated contributions and the aggregate amount of annuity payments received to him or her shall be paid to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If there is no such designated person or persons surviving the retirant, such difference, if any, shall be paid to the retirant's legal representative; or 
    Option II-Joint and Survivor Allowance. Upon the death of a retirant, his or her reduced retirement allowance shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person, having an insurable interest in his or her life, as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to his or her retirement; or 
    Option III-Modified Joint and Survivor Allowance. Upon the death of a retirant, one half of his or her reduced retirement allowance shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person, having an insurable interest in his or her life, as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to his or her retirement. 
B.  Any member who continues in the service of the city on or after the date he or she either acquires twenty-five (25) years of credited service, or attains age fifty-five (55) years and has ten or more years of credited service, whichever occurs first, may, at any time prior to the effective date of his or her retirement but not thereafter, elect option II provided for in subsection A above, in the same manner as if he or she were then retiring from service, and nominate a beneficiary whom the board finds to be dependent upon him or her for at least fifty (50) percent of his or her support due to lack of financial means. Prior to the effective date of his or her retirement a member may revoke his or her election of option II and nomination of beneficiary and may again elect the option II and nominate a beneficiary as provided in this subsection. Upon the death of a member who has an option II election in force, his or her beneficiary, if living, shall immediately receive the same retirement allowance to which the beneficiary would have been entitled if the member had retired the day preceding the date of his or her death, notwithstanding that he or she may not have attained his or her voluntary retirement age. If a member has an option II election in force at the time of his or her retirement, his or her election of option II and nomination of beneficiary shall thereafter continue in force, unless prior to the effective date of his or her retirement he or she elects to receive his or her retirement allowance as a regular retirement allowance or according to any option provided for in subsection A above. 
C.  When any member who continues in the service of the city on or after the date he or she either acquires twenty-five (25) years of credited service, or attains age fifty-five (55) years and has ten or more years of credited service, whichever occurs first, and does not have an option II election in force as provided in subsection B above, and dies while in city service, and leaves a widow, or in the case of a female member leaves a widower whom the board finds to be totally and permanently disabled and to have been dependent upon the female member for at least fifty (50) percent of his or her support due to lack of financial means, the widow or widower, as the case may be, shall immediately receive the same retirement allowance to which the beneficiary would have been entitled if the member had: 
1.  Retired the day preceding the date of his or her death, notwithstanding that he or she may not have attained his or her voluntary retirement age; 
2.  Elected option II provided for in subsection A above; and 
3.  Nominated his or her widow or widower, as the case may be, as beneficiary. 
(Ord. 212 § 10, 1956; Ord. 117 § 3, 1950: Ord. 60 § 20, 1945) 
2.76.210 - Duty disability. 
    Upon the application of a member, or his or her department head, a member in the service of the city who becomes totally incapacitated for duty as the natural and proximate result of the actual performance of duty as an employee of the city, without wilful negligence on his or her part, shall be retired by the board; provided, that the medical director after a medical examination of such member shall certify that such member is mentally or physically totally incapacitated for the further performance of duty in the service of the city, and that such member should be retired; provided, further, that the board concurs in the report of the medical director. 
(Ord. 60 § 21, 1945) 
2.76.220 - Duty disability-Retirement after voluntary retirement age. 
    Upon his or her retirement on or after his or her voluntary retirement age, on account of disability as provided in Section 2.76.210, a member shall receive a retirement allowance computed according to Section 2.76.180, notwithstanding that he or she might not have ten years of credited service, and he or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 2.76.200. 
(Ord. 212 § 11, 1956: Ord. 60 § 22, 1945) 
2.76.230 - Duty disability-Retirement before voluntary retirement age. 
A.  Upon his or her retirement prior to his or her voluntary retirement age, on account of disability as provided in Section 2.76.210, a member shall receive a disability pension equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her final average compensation. His or her disability pension shall begin as of the date of his or her disability, but in no case more than six months before the date his or her application for disability retirement is filed with the board, nor prior to the date his or her name last appeared on a city payroll with pay, whichever is later, and shall continue to his or her attainment of his or her voluntary retirement age, or recovery from disability or death prior thereto; provided, that the annual rate of the disability pension shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the annual rate of compensation of a lieutenant in the police or fire department of the city, whichever compensation is higher, as fixed in the city budget for the fiscal year in which the member retired; provided further, that the disability pension shall be subject to Sections 2.76.270 and 2.76.280. 
B.  Upon attaining his or her voluntary retirement age the disability retirant shall receive a pension computed according to Section 2.76.180, and he or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 2.76.200; provided, that in computing his or her pension he or she shall be given service credit for the period he or she was in receipt of a disability pension provided for in subsection A of this section. In addition to his or her pension he or she shall, upon attaining his or her voluntary retirement age, receive an annuity equivalent to the annuity he or she would have received had he or she continued his or her contributions to the annuity savings fund; the contributions to be based upon his or her final compensation at the time of his or her retirement. 
C.  During the period a disability retirant is receiving a disability pension provided for in subsection A of this section, his or her contributions to the annuity savings fund shall be suspended and his or her balance standing to his or her credit in the fund shall remain therein and shall be accumulated at regular interest. Upon attaining his or her voluntary retirement age his or her accumulated contributions shall be transferred from the annuity savings fund to the annuity reserve fund. If the retirant dies before attaining his or her voluntary retirement age his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the annuity savings fund shall be paid as provided in Section 2.76.290. 
(Ord. 212 § 12, 1956: Ord. 146 § 3, 1953: Ord. 96 § 2, 1948: Ord. 60 § 23, 1945) 
2.76.240 - Nonduty disability. 
    Upon the application of a member, or his or her department head, a member who is in the service of the city, and has ten or more years of service credited to his or her service account, becomes totally and permanently incapacitated for duty to the city as the result of causes occurring not in the actual performance of duty to the city, may be retired by the board; provided, the medical director after a medical examination of such member shall certify that such member is mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty to the city, and that such incapacity is likely to be permanent, and that such member should be retired. 
(Ord. 60 § 24, 1945) 
2.76.250 - Nonduty disability-Retirement after voluntary retirement age. 
    Upon his or her retirement on or after his or her voluntary retirement age, on account of disability as provided in Section 2.76.240, a member shall receive a retirement allowance computed according to Section 2.76.180, and he or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 2.76.200. 
(Ord. 212 § 13, 1956: Ord. 60 § 25, 1945) 
2.76.260 - Nonduty disability-Retirement allowance. 
    Upon his or her retirement before his or her voluntary retirement age, on account of disability as provided in Section 2.76.240, a member shall receive a disability retirement allowance computed according to Section 2.76.180; provided, that the pension portion of his or her retirement allowance payable to his or her attainment of his or her voluntary retirement age shall be subject to Sections 2.76.270 and 2.76.280. Upon attaining his or her voluntary retirement age he or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 2.76.200. 
(Ord. 212 § 14, 1956: Ord. 117 § 4, 1950: Ord. 96 § 3, 1948: Ord. 60 § 26, 1945) 
2.76.270 - Pensions offset by compensation benefits. 
    Any amounts which may be paid or payable under the provisions of any workmen's compensation, or pension or similar law, including any pensions allowed and payable by the federal or state governments on account of service performed in the armed forces of the United States or the state, to a member, retirant or beneficiary on account of any disability or death shall be offset against and payable in lieu of any pensions payable from funds of the retirement system on account of the same disability or death. In case the present value of the total benefits payable under the workmen's compensation, pension or similar law, or the federal or state pension, is less than the pension reserves for pensions payable from funds of the retirement system, then the present value of the benefits so payable shall be deducted from the pension reserves and such pensions as may be provided by the pension reserves so reduced shall be payable under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 212 § 15, 1956: Ord. 60 § 27, 1945) 
2.76.280 - Reexamination of disability retirants. 
A.  Once each year during the first five years a disability retirant is receiving a disability retirement allowance or pension, and at least once in each three-year period thereafter, the board may, and upon the retirant's application shall, require any disability retirant who has not attained his or her voluntary retirement age to undergo a medical examination to be made by or under the direction of the medical director at the residence of the retirant or other place mutually agreed upon. Should any such retirant refuse to submit to such medical examination in any such period his or her disability retirement allowance or pension may be discontinued by the board, and should such refusal continue for one year, all his or her rights in and to his or her disability retirement allowance or pension may be revoked by the board. If upon such medical examination of a retirant, the medical director reports that such retirant is physically able and capable of resuming employment with the city, and his or her report is concurred in by the board, then such retirant shall be returned to active service in the employ of the city and his or her disability retirement allowance or pension shall be discontinued. 
B.  A disability retirant who has returned or shall return to active service in the employ of the city, as provided in subsection A shall from the date of his or her return again become a member of the retirement system and he or she shall contribute to the retirement system in the same manner as prior to his or her retirement. His or her credited service at the time of his or her retirement shall be restored to full force and effect. He or she shall be given membership service credit for the period he or she was receiving a disability pension provided for in Section 2.76.230; he or she shall not be given service credit for the period he or she was receiving a retirement allowance provided for in Section 2.76.260. 
C.  If a disability retirant, who has not attained his or her voluntary retirement age, is or becomes engaged in a gainful occupation, business or employment, and the total of his or her pay or earnings from such occupation, business or employment, and his or her disability pension payable from funds of the retirement system exceeds his or her final compensation, then his or her pension payable from funds of the retirement system shall be reduced to an amount which when added to the amount so earned by him or her shall not exceed his or her final compensation. 
(Ord. 212 § 16, 1956: Ord. 60 § 28, 1945) 
2.76.290 - Refund of accumulated contributions. 
A.  Should a member cease to be an employee of the city before becoming eligible to retire with a benefit payable from funds of the retirement system, he or she shall be paid all or part of his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the annuity savings fund as he or she shall demand in writing on forms furnished by the board. 
B.  In the event a member dies before his or her retirement becomes effective, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the annuity savings fund at the time of his or her death shall be paid to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If there is no such designated person or persons surviving the member his or her accumulated contributions shall be paid to his or her legal representative. No refunds shall be made under this subsection on account of the death of a member if any benefits are paid under Section 2.76.200 on account of his or her death. 
C.  If a member dies intestate, without heirs, and without having nominated a beneficiary as provided in this section, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the annuity savings fund at the time of his or her death may be used to pay his or her burial expenses, not to exceed a reasonable sum to be determined by the board, provided he or she leaves no other estate sufficient for such purpose. 
D.  Payment of refunds of accumulated contributions may be made in a single sum, or in equal installments, according to such rules and regulations as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
(Ord. 212 § 17, 1956: Ord. 60 § 29, 1945) 
2.76.300 - Annuity savings fund-Established. 
A.  The annuity savings fund is created. The annuity savings fund shall be the fund in which shall be accumulated at regular interest the contributions from the compensations of members to provide for their annuities. 
B.  The normal contributions of a member to the annuity savings fund shall be five percent of his or her compensation paid by the city. In the event a member made supplemental contributions, in addition to his or her normal contributions, his or her supplemental contributions shall be returned to him. 
C.  The officer or officers responsible for making up the payroll shall cause the contributions provided for in subsection B to be deducted from the compensation of each member on each and every payroll, for each and every payroll period, so long as he or she remains a member in the employ of the city. The members' contributions provided for herein shall be made notwithstanding that the minimum compensation provided for by law for any member shall be changed thereby. Every member shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made and provided for herein and the receipt for his or her full compensation, and payment of his or her compensation less the deduction shall be a full and complete discharge and acquittance of all claims and demands whatsoever for the services rendered by such person during the period covered by such payment, except as to benefits provided by this chapter. When deducted, the contributions provided for herein shall be paid into the annuity savings fund and shall be credited to the individual accounts of the members from whose compensations the contributions were made. 
D.  In addition to the contributions deducted from the compensations of a member, as provided for in subsection B, a member shall deposit in the annuity savings fund, by a single contribution or by an increased rate of contribution as approved by the board, all amounts he or she may have previously withdrawn from, and not repaid to, the annuity savings fund, together with regular interest computed from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. In no case shall any member be given credit for service rendered prior to the date he or she withdrew his or her accumulated contributions until he or she repays to the annuity savings fund all amounts due the fund by him or her. 
E.  Upon retirement of a member, his or her accumulated contributions shall be transferred from the annuity savings fund to the annuity reserve fund. At the expiration of a period of three years from the date an employee ceases to be a member, any balance of accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the annuity savings fund unclaimed by such member shall be transferred from the annuity savings fund to the pension reserve fund. 
(Ord. 212 § 18, 1956: Ord. 146 § 4, 1953: Ord. 117 § 5, 1950: Ord. 60 § 30, 1945) 
2.76.310 - Annuity reserve fund. 
    The annuity reserve fund is created. It shall be the fund from which shall be paid all annuities, and benefits in lieu of annuities, payable as provided in this chapter. If a disability retirant returns to active service in the employ of the city his or her annuity reserve at that time shall be transferred from the annuity reserve fund to the annuity savings fund and shall be credited to his or her individual account therein. 
(Ord. 212 § 19, 1956: Ord. 60 § 31, 1945) 
2.76.320 - Pension reserve fund. 
    The pension reserve fund is created. It shall be the fund in which shall be accumulated reserves for the payment of all pensions payable from contributions made by the city and any of its appropriating divisions, and from which shall be paid all pensions payable as provided in this chapter. Upon the basis of such mortality and other tables of experience, and regular interest, as the board shall from time to time adopt, the actuary shall annually compute the pension reserves for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries and covering service rendered and to be rendered by members. The pension reserves shall be financed by appropriations, to be made by the council, determined according to subsections A, B and C of this section. 
A.  The appropriation for members' current service shall be a percent of their annual compensations which will produce an amount which if paid annually by the city during their future service will be sufficient to provide the reserves, at the time of their retirements, for the portions of the pensions to be paid them based upon their future service; and 
B.  The appropriation for members' accrued service shall be a percent of their annual compensations which will produce an amount which if paid annually by the city over a period of years, to be determined by the board, will amortize, at regular interest, the unfunded pension reserves for the accrued service portions of the pensions to which they may be entitled; and 
C.  The appropriation for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries shall be a percent of the annual compensations of members which will produce an amount which if paid annually by the city over a period of years, to be determined by the board, will amortize, at regular interest, the unfunded pension reserves for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries. 
D.  Contributions to the retirement system of the city to the extent necessary to provide payment of pensions and other benefits to beneficiaries of and members employed by an instrumentality of the city shall be made from the revenues of the instrumentality of the city. 
(Ord. 212 § 20, 1956: Ord. 60 § 32, 1945) 
2.76.330 - Expense fund. 
    The expense fund shall be the fund to which shall be credited all money provided by the city to pay the administration expense of the retirement system, and from which shall be paid all expenses necessary in connection with the administration of the retirement system. The board shall annually certify to the appropriating authorities of the city, according to legal budget procedure, the amount of appropriation necessary to administer the retirement system during each ensuing fiscal year, and the city shall appropriate such amount to the credit of the expense fund. 
(Ord. 60 § 33, 1945) 
2.76.340 - Fund management. 
    The board shall be the trustees of the funds of the retirement system and shall have full power to invest and reinvest such funds subject to all terms, conditions, limitations and restrictions imposed by the law of the state upon life insurance companies in the making and disposing of their investments, except that notes, bonds, or obligations of any county, city, village, or district in the state shall not be subject to the limitations or restrictions. The board shall have the power to purchase notes, bonds, or other obligations of the city before or after the same are offered to the public and with or without advertising for bids. There shall be kept on deposit available cash not exceeding ten percent of the total assets of the retirement system. 
    All funds of the retirement system shall be held for the sole purpose of meeting disbursements for pensions, annuities, and for making other payments authorized by the provisions of this chapter, and shall be used for no other purpose. The description of the various funds of the retirement system, as provided in this chapter, shall be interpreted to refer to the accounting records of the retirement system and not to the segregation of moneys in the funds of the retirement system. 
(Ord. 60 § 34, 1945) 
2.76.350 - Allowance of regular interest. 
    The board annually shall allow regular interest on the mean amount of assets credited to the annuity savings fund, annuity reserve fund, and the pension reserve fund; provided, however, that interest on contributions of members credited to the annuity savings fund within any one fiscal year shall begin on the first day of the fiscal year next following, and shall be computed at the end of the fiscal year. The amounts of interest so allowed shall be due and payable to the funds or the retirement system and shall be annually credited thereto by the board from interest and other earnings on moneys of the retirement system. Any additional amount necessary to allow regular interest on the funds of the retirement system shall be paid from the pension reserve fund, and all interest and other earnings on deposits and investments of the funds of the retirement system not required for the allowance of regular interest shall be credited to the pension reserve fund. 
(Ord. 60 § 35, 1945) 
2.76.360 - Assignments prohibited. 
    The right of a person to an annuity, a pension, a retirement allowance to the return of accumulated contributions, the annuity, the pension, or the retirement allowance itself, any optional benefit, any other right accrued or accruing to any member, retirant, or beneficiary under the provisions of this chapter, and the moneys belonging to the retirement system shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of bankruptcy or insolvency law, or any other process of law whatsoever, and shall be unassignable, except as is specifically provided in this chapter; provided, that the city shall have the right of setoff for any claim arising from embezzlement by or fraud of a member. 
(Ord. 212 § 21, 1956: Ord. 60 § 36, 1945) 
2.76.370 - Correction of error. 
    Should any change in the records result in any member, retirant, or beneficiary receiving from the retirement system more or less than he or she would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, the board shall correct such error, and as far as practicable shall adjust the payment in such manner that the actual equivalent of the benefit to which the member, retirant or beneficiary was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Ord. 212 § 22, 1956: Ord. 60 § 37, 1945) 
Chapter 2.80 - 1968 RETIREMENT PLAN 
Sections: 

2.80.010 - Retirement system continued. 
    The city employees' retirement system, created and established effective July 1, 1945, is hereby continued. 
(Ord. 455 § 1, 1968) 
2.80.020 - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases as used in this chapter, unless a different meaning is clearly indicated by the context, shall have the following meanings: 
A.  "Accumulated contributions" means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member and credited to his or her individual account in the members' savings fund, together with regular interest thereon. 
B.  "Beneficiary" means any person, except a retirant, who is in receipt of, or who is designated to receive, a pension or other benefit by the retirement system. 
C.  "Board" means the board of trustees of the city retirement system. 
D.  "City" means the city of Hazel Park, Michigan. 
E.  "Compensation" means the salary or wages paid a member for personal services rendered to the city, including cost-of-living payments, longevity pay, vacation pay, shift differential, fill-in time, holiday pay, sick leave pay while absent from work, reimbursement on the annual option for sick time in excess of one hundred (100) days (or equivalent), and deferred compensation. Compensation does not include overtime pay, allowances for clothing, equipment, food, travel and other similar items, reimbursement of expenses incurred, bonuses, termination or severance pay, final payout of unused sick leave, final payment of unused vacation, the value of any other fringe benefit, and salary, wages, and other items which are the basis of benefits under another retirement program, or items of a similar nature. 
F.  "Council" means the city council of the city. 
G.  "Credited service" means the number of years and months of service credited a member by the board pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
H.  "Early retirement age" means age fifty-five (55) years for general members, and age fifty (50) years for police officer and firefighter members. 
I.  "Final average compensation" means the average of the highest annual compensations received by a member for a period of two consecutive years of his or her credited service contained within his or her ten years of credited service immediately preceding the date his or her city employment last terminates. If he or she has less than two years of credited service his or her final average compensation shall be the average of his or her annual compensation for his or her total period of service. 
J.  "General member" means any member except a police officer or firefighter member. 
K.  "Member" means any person who is included in the membership of the retirement system. 
L.  "Normal retirement age" means age sixty (60) years for general members, and age fifty-five (55) years for police officers and firefighters members. 
M.  "Overtime" means hours in excess of forty (40) hours for those who work forty (40) hours per week and hours in excess of thirty-seven and one-half (37-1/2) hours for those who work thirty-seven and one-half (37-1/2) hours per week and hours in excess of fifty-six (56) hours for those whose workweek is fifty-six (56) hours per week. 
N.  "Pension" means an annual amount payable, by the retirement system, in equal monthly installments throughout the future life of a person, or for a temporary period, as provided in this chapter. 
O.  "Pension reserve" means the present value of all payments to be made on account of any pension, and shall be computed upon the basis of such tables of experience, and regular interest, as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
P.  "Police officer or firefighter member" or "police officers or firefighters members" means any officer or employee in the police or fire department of the city holding the rank of patrol officer or firefighter, as the case may be, or higher rank; but in no case shall include any person who is privately employed as a police officer or firefighter, nor any person who is temporarily employed as a police officer or firefighter for an emergency, nor any civilian employee in either the police or fire department. 
Q.  "Police command officer" means any police officer member who holds the rank of sergeant or lieutenant in the police department. 
R.  "Regular interest" means such rate or rates of interest per year, compounded annually, as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
S.  "Retirant" means a member who retires with a pension payable by the retirement system. 
T.  "Retirement" means a member's withdrawal from city employment with a pension payable by the retirement system. 
U.  "Retirement system" or "system" means the city employees retirement system. 
V.  "Service" means personal service rendered to the city by an officer or employee of the city. In the case of the transfer to the city of the functions of any department in the government of Royal Oak Township, the employees of the department as of the date of such transfer, who become employed by the city within six months from and after the date of such transfer, shall have their Royal Oak Township service rendered from and after June 30, 1945, credited them as city service; provided, that the person deposits in the members' savings fund, prior to July 1, 1953, the accumulated contributions credited to him or her in the employees' savings fund of the retirement system established by Act No. 135 of the Public Acts of 1945, and is not entitled to a deferred retirement allowance provided by the Act No. 135 retirement system. 
(Ord. 673 § 1, 1982; Ord. 630 §§ 1, 2, 1980; Ord. 627 §§ 1, 2, 1980; Ord. 626 §§ 1, 2, 1980; Ord. 455 §§ 1, 2, 1969: Ord. 445 § 2, 1968) 
2.80.030 - Board of trustees-Members. 
A.  The authority and responsibility for the administration, management and operation of the retirement system, and for construing and making effective the provisions of this chapter, except such powers as are retained by the council, are vested in a board of trustees. The board of trustees shall consist of seven trustees, as follows: 
1.  Council trustees: two members of the council to be selected by the council, and to serve at the pleasure of the council; 
2.  The city manager, to serve by virtue of his or her position; 
3.  Police officers and firefighters trustees: a police officer member to be elected by the police officer members, and a firefighter member to be elected by the firefighters members; 
4.  General member trustees: a general member who is a member of a union having a contract with the city to be elected by the general members who are members of a union having a contract with the city, and a general member who is not a member of a union having a contract with the city to be elected by the general members who are not members of a union having a contract with the city including 43rd District Court Employees. 
B.  The member trustees, provided in subsection A of this section shall be elected under such rules and regulations as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
(Ord. 765 § 1, 1989; Ord. 689 § 1, 1984: Ord. 445 § 3, 1968) 
2.80.040 - Board-Vacancy filling. 
    If a vacancy occurs in the office of a member trustee, the city manager shall, within thirty (30) days after the date of the vacancy, appoint a qualified person to fill the vacancy for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Ord. 445 § 4, 1968) 
2.80.050 - Term of office-Compensation. 
    The terms of office of a member trustee shall be four years, one such term to expire annually in the order determined by the board. Each trustee shall, within ten days after his or her election or appointment, take an oath of office to be administered by the city clerk. The member trustees shall serve without additional compensation for their services as trustees. 
(Ord. 445 § 5, 1968) 
2.80.060 - Meetings. 
    The board shall hold meetings regularly, at least monthly, and shall designate the time and place thereof. Four trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board. Each attending trustee shall be entitled to one vote on each question before the board and at least four concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision by the trustees. The board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the board shall be public. 
(Ord. 445 § 6, 1968) 
2.80.070 - Retirement system officers. 
A.  The board shall elect from its own number a chairman and a vice-chairman. 
B.  The city clerk shall be secretary to the board, and he or she shall be the administrative officer of the retirement system. 
C.  The city treasurer shall be treasurer of the retirement system and the custodian of its assets. All payments from the moneys of the system shall be made only upon warrant checks signed by the city manager and the city clerk and countersigned by the city treasurer. No payment from the moneys of the system shall be made unless it has been previously authorized by a specific or continuing resolution of the board. 
D.  The city attorney shall be the legal advisor to the board. 
E.  The board shall appoint an actuary who shall be the technical advisor to the board on matters regarding the operation of the retirement system. He or she shall perform such other duties as are required of him or her under this chapter. 
F.  The board shall appoint as medical director a physician who is not eligible to membership in the retirement system. He or she shall be responsible to and shall hold office at the pleasure of the board. He or she shall arrange for and pass upon all medical examinations required under this chapter, he or she shall investigate all essential statements and certificates of a medical nature made by or on behalf of a member or retirant in connection with a disability claim, and he or she shall report in writing to the board his or her conclusion on medical matters referred to him or her by the board. 
G.  The board may employ such professional and other services as are required for the proper operation of the retirement system. 
(Ord. 445 § 7, 1968) 
2.80.075 - Refund of contributions for forfeited service. 
    A former member entitled to a deferred retirement pension may, upon approval of the board, forfeit a portion of his or her credited service by withdrawing a portion of his or her accumulated contributions for the service forfeited, provided that the forfeited service will be used as credited service in another state or municipal retirement system. The amount of contributions to be refunded for the forfeited service shall be determined by multiplying the former member's total accumulated contributions by the ratio of months of forfeited service to months of total service. The former member shall continue to be entitled to a deferred retirement pension based on his or her remaining credited service provided that the remaining credited service is not less than ten years. 
(Ord. 690 § 1, 1985) 
2.80.080 - Records-Report. 
    The secretary shall keep, or cause to be kept, such data as is necessary for an actuarial valuation of the assets and liabilities of the retirement system. The board shall annually render a report to the council showing the fiscal transactions of the system for the year ending the preceding June 30th, and the last balance sheet showing the financial condition of the system by means of an actuarial valuation of its assets and liabilities. 
(Ord. 445 § 8, 1968) 
2.80.090 - Adoption of experience tables-Regular interest. 
    The board shall from time to time adopt such mortality and other tables of experience, and a rate or rates of regular interest, as are necessary in the operation of the retirement system on an actuarial basis. 
(Ord. 445 § 9, 1968) 
2.80.100 - Membership of retirement system. 
    The membership of the retirement system shall include all officers and employees of the city, all persons who become officers or employees of the city and effective July 1, 1983, all employees of the Hazel Park Branch of the 43rd District Court. The membership of the system shall not include any person whose services are compensated on a contractual or fee basis, nor any person employed by the city on June 30, 1969, whose compensation paid by the city averages less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year, nor any person, except an elected official, who enters the employ of the city after June 30, 1969, in a position normally requiring less than one thousand six hundred (1,600) hours of work per year. 
    In any case of doubt, the board shall decide who is a member within the meaning of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 454 § 1, 1969; Ord. 445 § 10, 1968) 
2.80.110 - Termination of membership. 
A.  Should any member leave the employ of the city, for any reason except the member's retirement, disability or death, the member shall thereupon cease to be a member and the member's credited service at that time shall be forfeited by the member if that member withdraws his or her money from the pension fund when he or she leaves. In the event a member is reemployed by the city the member shall again become a member. 
B.  A member who is employed by the city at the time of enactment of this amendment, who left the employ of the city for any reason except retirement, disability or death, and who has been reemployed by the city prior to the effective date of passage of the amendment codified in this section may have the previous credited service restored to the member's credit; provided, that the member returns within one year of the date of enactment of this amendment to the members' savings fund the amount, if any, that the member withdrew from said fund, together with interest on said amount at the actuarial assumed rate of return during the period that said member had left the employ of the city, from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. 
(Ord. 764 § 1, 1989) 
2.80.120 - Service credit. 
A.  In accordance with such rules and regulations as the board shall from time to time adopt, consistent with the provisions of this chapter, the board shall credit each member with the number of years and months of service rendered by him or her; provided, that in no case shall less than ten days of service rendered by him or her in any calendar month be credited as a month of service nor shall less than nine months of service rendered by him or her in any calendar year be credited as a year of service, nor shall more than one year of service be credited any member for all service rendered by him or her in any calendar year. 
B.  Each member who was an employee as of July 1, 1983, of the Hazel Park Branch of the 43rd District Court, shall be credited with service for prior years of service as an employee of the Hazel Park Branch of the 43rd District Court; provided, that: 
1.  Such member elects in writing before June 30, 1984 to receive credit for such service; 
2.  Such member pays to the members' savings fund the amount of member contributions the member would have made during each year of service as an employee before July 1, 1983, of the Hazel Park Branch of the 43rd District Court together with regular interest from the date payment would have been made to the date of actual payment; and 
3.  The amount of payment shall be made within five years of electing to receive credit for this service. The member shall not receive credit for service under this subsection until the entire amount of member contributions plus regular interest are paid to the member's savings fund. 
(Ord. 689 § 3, 1984: Ord. 445 § 12, 1968) 
2.80.130 - Military service credit. 
    An employee who, while employed by the city, entered or enters any armed service of the United States, and who has been or shall be on active duty in such armed service during time of war or period of compulsory military service, such armed service actually required of him or her shall be credited as city service; provided, that: 
A.  He or she is reemployed by the city within one year from the date of termination of such armed service actually required of him or her; 
B.  He or she returns to the members' savings fund the amount, if any, he or she withdrew therefrom at the time he or she entered or while in such armed service, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment; and 
C.  In no case shall more than six years of city service be credited any member for all such armed service rendered by him or her. In any case of doubt as to the period of such armed service to be credited any member, the board shall have final power to determine such period. During the period of such armed service and until his or her reemployment by the city his or her contributions to the retirement system shall be suspended and his or her balance, if any, in the members' savings fund shall be accumulated at regular interest. 
(Ord. 445 § 13, 1968) 
2.80.131 - Military service preemployment. 
    Any city employee who is an honorably separated veteran may purchase prior active military service time rendered to the United States government as a pension service credit so long as he or she meets the following conditions: 
A.  An employee shall have two and one-half years from the effective date of passage of the ordinance codified in this section to elect to purchase time served in the military prior to becoming an employee. Persons becoming employees thereafter shall have two and one-half years from date of hire to elect to so purchase the aforenoted time, and he or she shall be so notified. 
B.  The election to purchase the aforenoted service time shall be accompanied by an election to pay for such time either in a lump sum, or by paying for same through a payroll deduction which shall be paid within five years, accompanied by interest on the unpaid balance of seven percent per year from and after the date of the election to purchase the time. 
C.  The purchase price of the time purchased shall be in an amount equal to five percent of the full-time or equated full-time base salary of the member of the fiscal year in which payment is made to the retirement system multiplied by the years of service that the member wishes to purchase up to the maximum applicable. 
D.  The final average compensation shall continue to be computed only on the basis of actual service rendered to the city. 
E.  Credit for military service under this section shall be for pension purposes only. 
F.  Each employee shall be allowed to purchase up to a maximum of five years' military time under this section. 
G.  Purchase of military time shall be in full monthly increments. 
H.  An employee who purchases military time under this section may not withdraw his or her contribution for the military service time under the annuity withdrawal position. 
I.  The board of trustees shall promulgate such other and further rules to effectuate the purpose of this section. 
J.  In determining pension benefit amounts, the credit for military service time shall be assumed to have been rendered on the day of the election to purchase same. 
K.  The requirements and limitations of MCLA 38.355(1)(g) shall be controlling. 
(Ord. 748 § 1, 1988) 
2.80.140 - Voluntary retirement. 
A.  A general member may retire after his or her attainment of age fifty-five (55) years if he or she has fifteen (15) or more years of credited service or after his or her attainment of age sixty (60) years if he or she has ten or more years of credited service, or after his or her attainment of age fifty (50) years if he or she has twenty (20) or more years of credited service, upon written application filed with the board setting forth at what time, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof, he or she desires to be retired. Upon his or her retirement he or she shall receive a pension provided in Section 2.80.160. 
B.  A police officer or firefighter member may retire after his or her attainment of fifty (50) years if he or she has twenty-five (25) or more years of credited service or after his or her attainment of age fifty-five (55) years if he or she has ten or more years of credited service, upon his or her written application filed with the board setting forth at what time, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof, he or she desires be retired. Upon his or her retirement he or she shall receive a pension provided in Section 2.80.170. 
C.  Effective June 30, 1990, any age for patrol unit members only if the member has twenty-five (25) or more years of total credited service with the city. 
(Ord. 822 § 5, 1991; Ord. 625 § 1, 1980; Ord. 445 § 14, 1968) 
2.80.150 - Compulsory separation from city employment. 
    Any police officer or firefighter member shall be separated from city employment the first day of the calendar month next following the month in which he or she attains age sixty (60) years, and a general member, except an elected officer of the city, shall be separated from city employment the first day of the calendar month next following the month in which he or she attains age sixty-five (65) years. Any member, with ten or more years of credited service, who leaves city employment as provided in this section shall be retired and he or she shall receive a pension provided in Section 2.80.160 if he or she is a general member or as provided in Section 2.80.170 if he or she is a police officer or firefighter member. 
(Ord. 445 § 15, 1968) 
2.80.160 - Pension-General member. 
    Upon retirement, as provided in this chapter, a general member shall receive a straight life pension equal to 1.75 percent of final average compensation multiplied by the number of years, and fraction of a year, for all credited service prior to June 30, 1986. A general member shall be credited at the rate of 2.00 percent of final average compensation multiplied by the number of years, and fraction of a year for all credited service after July 1, 1986. The increased cost of Section 2.80.160 shall be assumed and paid by the city. 
(Ord. 721 § 1, 1987) 
2.80.170 - Pension-Police officer or firefighter member. 
A.  Upon his or her retirement, as provided in this chapter any police command officer, police captain, police chief and the fire chief shall receive a straight life pension equal to the sum of two percent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the first twenty-five (25) years of his or her credited service, plus one percent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the number of years, the fraction of a year, of his or her credited service, which is in excess of twenty-five (25) years. Prior to the date of his or her retirement, he or she may elect to receive his or her pension under an option provided in Section 2.80.200 in lieu of a straight life pension. 
B.  For all service prior to October 1, 1979, a police officer or firefighter member, except all police command officers, police captain, police chief and fire chief, upon retirement, shall receive a straight life pension equal to the sum of two per- cent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the first twenty-five (25) years of his or her credited service, plus one percent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the number of years, the fraction of a year, of his or her credited service which is in excess of twenty-five (25) years. The provisions of this subsection shall apply for all years of service prior to October 1, 1979. Prior to the date of his or her retirement, he or she may elect to receive his or her pension under an option provided in Section 2.80.200 in lieu of a straight life pension. 
C.  Beginning October 1, 1979, and applying prospectively only, a police officer or firefighter member, except all police command officers, police captain, police chief and fire chief, upon retirement shall receive a straight life pension equal to the sum of two and one-half percent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the years of credited service after October 1, 1979, to a maximum of thirty (30) years of service. The thirty (30) year maximum service credit shall include total service under both subsections A and B.
