The provisions of subsection C shall supersede and replace the provisions of subsection B above, for years of service after October 1, 1979. Prior to the date of his or her retirement, he or she may elect to receive his or her pension under an option provided in Section 2.80.200 in lieu of a straight life pension. 
D.  Effective July 1, 1978, upon retirement as provided in this chapter, a police command officer, the police captain, the police chief and the fire chief, shall receive a straight life pension equal to the sum of two percent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the first twenty-five (25) years or fraction of a year, of his or her credited service, plus two and one-half percent of his or her final average compensation multiplied by the number of his or her credited years of service in excess of twenty-five (25) years for all such credited service prior to July 1, 1978. Commencing July 1, 1978, and continuing thereafter, all police command officers, the police captain, the police chief and fire chief shall receive a straight life pension based upon the sum of two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by the years of service, or fraction of a year, credited after July 1, 1978, to a maximum of seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. Any police officer member who is promoted to police command officer after July 1, 1978, shall not receive any of the above described pension benefits retroactively but shall receive any benefits which are applicable prospectively from the effective date of promotion to command officer. 
(Ord. 630 § 3, 1980: Ord. 627 § 3, 1980; Ord. 626 § 3, 1980; Ord. 618 § 1, 1979: Ord. 445 § 17, 1968) 
2.80.180 - Terminal payment. 
    In the event a retirant dies before he or she has received in straight life pension payments an aggregate amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' savings fund at the time of his or her retirement, the differences between his or her accumulated contributions and the aggregate amount of straight life pension payments received by him or her shall be paid to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If no such designated person survives the retirant, such difference, if any, shall be paid to his or her estate. No benefits shall be paid under this section on account of the death of a retirant if he or she elected an option provided in Section 2.80.200. 
(Ord. 445 § 18, 1968) 
2.80.190 - Deferred retirement. 
    Should any member who has ten or more years of credited service leave the employ of the city prior to his or her normal retirement date for any reason except his or her retirement or death, and does not withdraw his or her accumulated contributions from the members' savings fund, he or she shall be entitled to a pension computed according to Section 2.80.160 if he or she is a general member, or Section 2.80.170 if he or she is a police officer or firefighter member, as the applicable section was in effect at the date his or her city employment last terminated. His or her pension shall begin thirty (30) days after the date his or her application for same is filed with the board on or after the date he or she satisfies the age and service requirements for retirement provided in Section 2.80.140. He or she shall not receive service credit for the period of his or her absence from city employment, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. During the period of his or her absence from city employment his or her balance in the members' savings fund shall be accumulated at regular interest. 
(Ord. 445 § 19, 1968) 
2.80.200 - Pension options. 
A.  Any qualifying member may, prior to the date of his or her retirement, but not thereafter, elect to receive his or her pension as a straight life pension payable throughout his or her life, or he or she may elect to receive the actuarial equivalent, at that time, of his or her straight life pension in a reduced pension payable throughout his or her life, and nominate a beneficiary, in accordance with the provisions of options A, B, C, D, or E set forth as follows: 
    Option A-Pension for Ten Years Certain and Life Thereafter. Under option A a retirant shall receive a reduced pension payable throughout his or her life with the provision that if he or she dies before he or she has received one hundred twenty (120) monthly pension payments the payments shall be continued for the remainder of the period of one hundred twenty (120) months to such person or persons, in equal shares, as the retirant shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If no such designated person survives the retirant such remaining monthly pension payments shall be continued to the retirant's estate. 
    Option B-One Hundred (100) Percent Survivor Pension. Under option B, formerly called option II, upon the death of a retirant, his or her reduced pension shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person, having an insurable interest in his or her life, as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to the date of his or her retirement. For firefighters, police patrol officers, and police command officers retiring after July 1, 1987, when the designated beneficiary predeceases the retirant, the retirant's monthly income for life shall revert to one hundred (100) percent of the amount provided as a straight life pension provided for herein at Section 2.80.170(C) 
    Option C-Fifty (50) Percent Survivor Pension. Under option C, formerly called option III, upon the death of a retirant, one-half of his or her reduced pension shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person, having an interest in his or her life, as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to the date of his or her retirement. For firefighters, police patrol officers, and police command officers retiring after July 1, 1987, when the designated beneficiary predeceases the retirant, the retirant's monthly income for life shall revert to one hundred (100) percent of the amount provided as a straight life pension provided for herein at Section 2.80.170(C) 
    Option D-Seventy-five (75) Percent Survivor Pension. Under option D, a retiring general member, police officer, firefighter, police command officer, police captain, police chief, and the fire chief who elects to reduce his or her pension by five percent shall, upon his or her death, have seventy-five (75) percent of the reduced pension continued throughout the life of and paid to such person having an insurable interest in his or her life, as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to the date of his or her retirement. The increased cost of Section 2.80.200A shall be assumed and paid by the city as it pertains to general members. For firefighters, police patrol officers, and police command officers retiring after July 1, 1987, when the designated beneficiary predeceases the retirant, the retirant's monthly income for life shall revert to one hundred (100) percent of the amount provided as a straight life pension provided for herein at Section 2.80.171(C) 
    Option E-Straight Life Pension to Surviving Police Command Officer Retirants, Police Captain, and Police and Fire Chiefs. Under option E, if a police command officer, police captain, police chief or fire chief retirant elected option B, C, or D as provided in this subsection, and survives the designated beneficiary, the retirant's retirement allowance shall thereafter be increased and paid as if the straight life form of payment had been elected. A retiree electing this option shall pay for this benefit by taking a larger reduction to his or her pension than the regular option B, C, or D reduction, as determined necessary by the actuary. 
    Option F-For Police Command Officers Only-Annuity Withdrawal. Any police command member who retires on or after July 1, 1984, may elect to receive a refund of all or part of his or her accumulated contributions (including interest) standing to his or her credit in the reserve for member contributions at the effective date of his or her retirement. Upon election of this refund provision, the retiring police command member's straight life pension shall be reduced by an amount which is actuarially equivalent to the refunded accumulated contributions. The actuarial equivalent amount shall be computed on the base of the mortality table specified by the board for use in optional benefit determinations and the interest rate adopted by the board for use in the annual actuarial valuation. The city will allow at least two police command members to make this election during any one quarter of its fiscal year. The cost, if any, of implementing the annuity withdrawal option using the valuation interest rate shall be borne by the city. 
    Option G-For Fire Department Employees Only-Annuity Withdrawal. Any member employed by the fire department who retires on or after July 1, 1985, may elect to receive a refund of all or part of his or her accumulated contributions (including interest) standing to his or her credit in the reserve for member contributions at the effective date of his or her retirement. Upon election of this refund provision, the retiring fire department member's straight life pension shall be reduced by an amount which is actuarially equivalent to the refunded accumulated contributions. The actuarial equivalent amount shall be computed on the basis of the mortality table specified by the board for use in optional benefit determinations and the interest rate, as published monthly by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation for use in converting a series of monthly annuity payments into a lump sum value, in effect at date of retirement. The city will allow at least three members of the fire department to make this election during any fiscal year. 
B.  If the retirant, who elected option B or C provided in subsection A of this section, and his or her beneficiary both die before the total of the pension payments received by them equals the amount of accumulated contributions standing to the retirant's credit in the members' savings fund at the time of his or her retirement, the difference between his or her accumulated contributions and the total amount of pensions paid shall be paid to the estate of the survivor of the retirant and his or her beneficiary. 
(Ord. 822 §§ 1-3, 1991; Ord. 721 §§ 2, 3, 4, 1987; Ord. 630 §§ 4-6, 1980; Ord. 627 §§ 4-6, 1980; Ord. 626 §§ 4-6, 1980; Ord. 445 § 20, 1968) 
2.80.210 - Survivor pensions. 
A.  Any member who continues in the employ of the city on or after the date he or she either acquires fifteen (15) years of credited service, or attains age fifty-five (55) years and has ten or more years of credited service, may at any time prior to the date of his or her retirement elect option B provided in Section 2.80.200, and nominate a beneficiary whom the board finds to be dependent upon him or her for at least fifty (50) percent of his or her financial support. Prior to the date of his or her retirement, a member may revoke his or her election of option B and nomination of beneficiary and he or she may again, prior to the date of his or her retirement, elect option B and nominate a beneficiary as provided in this subsection. Upon the death of a member who has an option B election in force, his or her beneficiary shall immediately receive a pension computed according to Sections 2.80.160 and 2.80.200 if he or she is a general member, or Sections 2.80.170 and 2.80.200 if he or she is a police officer or firefighter member, in the same manner as if he or she had retired the day preceding the date of his or her death, notwithstanding that he or she might not have satisfied the age and service requirements for retirement provided in Section 2.80.140. If a member has an option B election in force at the time of his or her retirement, his or her election of option B and nomination of beneficiary shall thereafter continue in force, unless prior to the date of his or her retirement he or she elects to receive his or her pension as a straight life pension or under another option provided in Section 2.80.200. 
B.  When any member who continues in the employ of the city on or after the date he or she either acquires fifteen (15) years of credited service, or attains age fifty-five (55) years and has ten or more years of credited service, and does not have an option B election in force as provided in subsection A of this section, dies while in city employment, and leaves a spouse, his or her spouse shall immediately receive a pension computed according to Sections 2.80.160 and 2.80.200 if the member was a general member, or Sections 2.80.170 and 2.80.200 if the member was a police officer or firefighter member, in the same manner as if the member had: 
1.  Retired the day preceding the date of his or her death, notwithstanding that he or she might not have satisfied the age and service requirements for retirement provided in Section 2.80.140; 
2.  Elected option B provided in Section 2.80.200; and 
3.  Nominated his or her spouse as beneficiary. 
    Upon the remarriage or death of the beneficiary his or her pension shall terminate. 
(Ord. 445 § 21, 1968) 
2.80.215 - Duty death pension. 
    A member who is a firefighter or police patrol unit employee member who dies while in the employ of the city, whose death is found to be the natural and proximate result of a personal injury or disease arising out of and in the course of the member's duties as an employee of the city, regardless of the number of years of credited service earned by the member as of the date of death, shall have paid to his or her surviving spouse a monthly retirement income. The amount of the retirement income shall be computed in accordance with Section 2.80.170 based upon (1) his or her rank at death and (2) the years of credited service which shall equal the number of years, including any fraction of a year, of credited service he or she has acquired by the date of death, plus, the number of years, including any fraction of a year, from the date of death until the member would have reached age fifty-five (55). Effective July 1, 1988, the previously provided equal sharing of the increased cost, the shared two percent of payroll and the city's obligation to pay four percent of each fire employee's contribution to the pension plan are hereby deleted on and after July 1, 1988 employee contributions shall be at the rate of five and one-half percent of payroll. 
(Ord. 822 § 4, 1991) 
2.80.220 - Disability-Retirement. 
    Upon the application of a member, or his or her department head, a member who becomes totally and permanently disabled for duty in the employ of the city as the natural and proximate result of a personal injury or disease arising out of and in the course of his or her actual performance of duty as an employee of the city, may be retired by the board; provided, the medical director after a medical examination of the member, certifies to the board that the member is mentally or physically totally disabled for duty in the employ of the city, and that such disability will probably be permanent; provided, further, that the board concurs in the report of the medical director. 
(Ord. 445 § 22, 1968) 
2.80.230 - Disability-Pension. 
A.  Upon a general member's retirement on account of disability, as provided in Section 2.80.220, he or she shall receive a disability pension computed according to Section 2.80.160, subject to Sections 2.80.260 and 2.80.270. In computing his or her disability pension the service credit used shall be the sum of his or her credited service in force at the time of his or her retirement and the number of years, and fraction of a year, in the period from the date of his or her retirement to the date he or she would attain age sixty (60) years. His or her straight life disability pension payable to his or her attainment of age sixty (60) years, if he or she retired prior thereto, shall not be less than fifty (50) percent of his or her final average compensation. Prior to the date of his or her retirement he or she may elect to receive his or her pension under an option provided in Section 2.80.200 in lieu of a straight life pension. 
B.  Upon a police officer or firefighter member's retirement on account of disability, as provided in Section 2.80.220, he or she shall receive a disability pension computed according to Section 2.80.170, subject to Sections 2.80.260 and 2.80.270. In computing his or her disability pension the service credit used shall be the sum of his or her credited service in force at the time of his or her retirement, and the number of years, and fraction of a year, in the period from the date of his or her retirement to the date he or she would attain age fifty-five (55) years. His or her straight life disability pension payable to his or her attainment of age fifty-five (55) years, if he or she retired prior thereto, shall not be less than fifty (50) percent of his or her final average compensation. Prior to the date of his or her retirement he or she may elect to receive his or her pension under an option provided in Section 2.80.200 in lieu of a straight life pension. 
(Ord. 445 § 23, 1968) 
2.80.240 - Disability-Nonduty. 
    Upon the application of a member, or his or her department head, a member, with ten or more years of credited service, who becomes totally and permanently disabled for duty in the employ of the city as the result of causes occurring not in his or her actual performance of duty in the employ of the city, may be retired by the board; provided, the medical director, after a medical examination of the member, certifies to the board that the member is mentally or physically totally disabled for duty in the employ of the city, and that such disability will probably be permanent. 
(Ord. 445 § 24, 1968) 
2.80.250 - Disability-Nonduty-Pension. 
    Upon his or her retirement on account of disability, as provided in Section 2.80.240, a member shall receive a pension computed according to Section 2.80.160 if he or she is a general member, or Section 2.80.170 if he or she is a police officer or firefighter member, subject in either case to Sections 2.80.260 and 2.80.270. Prior to the date of his or her retirement he or she may elect to receive his or her pension under an option provided in Section 2.80.200 in lieu of a straight life pension. 
(Ord. 445 § 25, 1968) 
2.80.260 - Disability or survivor's pension-Conditions. 
    If a pension is paid or will become payable pursuant to the provisions of Sections 2.80.210, 2.80.230, and 2.80.250, then the total amount of pensions payable, before giving effect to any option election provided in Section 2.80.200, shall not exceed the difference between eighty (80) percent of the disabled or deceased member's final average compensation and the total of the following amounts: 
A.  Workmen's compensation on account of such disability or death. Workmen's compensation shall be converted to an annual basis, for the purposes of this section, in accordance with such rules as the board shall adopt. 
B.  Benefits, if any, from the Federal Social Security Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance System on account of such disability or death. 
(Ord. 549 § 1, 1974: Ord. 445 § 26, 1968) 
2.80.270 - Reexamination of disability retirants. 
A.  Once each year during the first five years a retirant is receiving a disability pension, and at least once in each three-year period thereafter, the board may require the retirant, if he or she has not attained his or her early retirement age, to undergo a medical examination to be made by or under the direction of the medical director. If the retirant refuses to submit to such medical examination in any such period his or her disability pension may be suspended by the board until his or her withdrawal of such refusal. Should such refusal continue for one year his or her disability pension may be terminated by the board. If, upon such medical examination of a retirant, the medical director reports to the board that the retirant is physically able and capable of resuming employment with the city, and his or her report is concurred in by the board, he or she shall be returned to city employment and his or her disability pension shall terminate. 
B.  A disability retirant who returns to the employ of the city shall from the date of his or her return again become a member of the retirement system. His or her credited service in force at the time of his or her retirement shall be restored to his or her credit. He or she shall be given service credit for the period he or she was receiving a disability pension provided in Section 2.80.230; he or she shall not be given service credit for the period he or she was receiving a disability pension provided in Section 2.80.250. 
C.  If a disability retirant, who has not attained his or her early retirement age, becomes engaged in a gainful occupation, business, or employment, his or her disability pension shall not exceed the difference between his or her annual rate of compensation at the time of his or her retirement and his or her annual pay and earnings from such occupation, business, or employment. 
(Ord. 445 § 27, 1968) 
2.80.280 - Refund of accumulated contributions. 
A.  Should a member cease to be employed by the city before he or she has satisfied the age and service requirements for retirement provided in Section 2.80.140, for any reason except his or her disability retirement, he or she shall be paid his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' savings fund upon his or her request in writing filed with the board. 
B.  In the event a member dies and leaves no beneficiary entitled to a pension payable by the retirement system, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' savings fund at the time of his or her death shall be paid to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If no such designated beneficiary survives the member, or if he or she made no such nomination of beneficiary, his or her accumulated contributions shall be paid to his or her estate. 
C.  The return of accumulated contributions, as provided in this section, may be made in a single sum, or in installments, according to such rules and regulations as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
(Ord. 445 § 28, 1968) 
2.80.290 - Members' savings fund. 
A.  The members' savings fund, formerly called annuity savings fund, shall be the fund in which is accumulated, at regular interest, the contributions deducted from the compensations of members, and from which shall be made refunds and transfers of accumulated contributions, as provided in this chapter. 
B.  The contributions by a member of the retirement system shall be five percent of the compensation paid him or her by the city, except that effective July 1, 1988, the contributions by the fire chief, police chief, police command officers, police patrol unit members, and firefighter employees shall be five and one-half percent of the compensation paid him or her by the city. 
C.  The officer responsible for preparing the payroll shall cause the contribution provided in subsection B to be deducted from the compensation of each member on each and every payroll, for each and every payroll period, so long as he or she remains a member. Each of such amounts when deducted shall be paid to the retirement system and shall be credited to the member's individual account in the members' savings fund. The member's contributions provided herein shall be made notwithstanding that the minimum compensation provided by law for any member shall be thereby changed. Each member shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made and provided for herein. Payment of his or her compensation less such deduction shall be a full and complete discharge and acquittance of all claims and demands whatsoever for the service rendered by such payment, except as to benefits provided by the retirement system. 
D.  In addition to the contributions deducted from the compensation of a member, as hereinbefore provided, he or she shall deposit in the members' savings fund, by a single sum or by an increased rate of contribution as approved by the board, the amount, if any, he or she withdrew from the fund, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. In no case shall any member be given credit for service rendered prior to the date he or she withdrew his or her accumulated contributions until he or she returns to the members' savings fund all amounts due the fund by him or her. 
E.  Upon the retirement of a member, or upon his or her death if a pension becomes payable by the retirement system on account of his or her death, his or her accumulated contributions shall be transferred from the members' savings fund to the retirement reserve fund. At the expiration of a period of three years from the date a member ceases to be a member any balance of accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' savings fund, unclaimed by him or her or his or her legal representative, shall be transferred to the income fund; provided, that he or she does not have entitlement to a deferred pension provided in Section 2.80.190. 
(Ord. 822 § 6, 1991; Ord. 445 § 29, 1968) 
2.80.300 - Retirement reserve fund. 
A.  The retirement reserve fund shall be the fund from which shall be paid all pensions payable as provided in this chapter. In the case of a disability retirant who returns to the employ of the city, his or her pension reserve, computed as of the date of his or her return, shall be transferred from the retirement reserve fund to the members' savings fund and pension reserve fund in the same proportion that his or her pension reserve, as of the date of his or her retirement, was transferred from the members' savings fund and pension reserve fund to the retirement reserve fund. The amount transferred to the members' savings fund shall be credited to the member's individual account therein. 
B.  The balance in the former annuity reserve fund shall be transferred to the retirement reserve fund and hereafter all annuities formerly payable from the annuity reserve fund shall be payable from the retirement reserve fund. 
(Ord. 445 § 30, 1968) 
2.80.310 - Pension reserve fund. 
A.  The pension reserve fund shall be the fund to which shall be credited contributions made by the city to the retirement system, and from which shall be made transfers as provided in this section. 
B.  Upon the basis of such mortality and other tables of experience, and regular interest, as the board shall from time to time adopt, the actuary shall annually compute the pension reserves for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries, and for service rendered and to be rendered by members. The pension reserves so computed, less applicable assets, shall be financed by city appropriations to be made by the council, determined as follows: 
1.  The city's annual appropriation for members' current service shall be a percent of their annual compensations which will be an amount which if paid annually by the city during their future service will be sufficient to provide the pension reserves at the time of their retirements for the city-financed portions of the pensions to be paid them based upon their future service. 
2.  The city's annual appropriation for members' accrued service shall be a percent of their annual compensations which will be an amount which if paid annually by the city over a period of years, to be determined by the board, will amortize at regular interest the unfunded pension reserves, if any, for the accrued service portions of the pensions to be paid them upon their retirements. 
3.  The city's annual appropriation for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries shall be a percent of the annual compensations of members which will be an amount which if paid annually by the city over a period of years, to be determined by the board, will amortize at regular interest the unfunded pension reserves, if any, for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries. 
C.  Upon the retirement of a member, or at the time of his or her death if a pension becomes payable on account of his or her death, the difference between the pension reserve for the pension payable and his or her accumulated contributions, shall be transferred from the pension reserve fund to the retirement reserve fund. The board may from time to time transfer from the pension reserve fund to the retirement reserve fund such additional amounts as it determines to be necessary. 
D.  Contributions to the retirement system by the city on account of the participation in the system of employees of a revenue-supported department of the city shall be made from the revenues of the department. 
E.  Prior to December 31, 1968, the pension reserves for pensions being paid from the pension reserve fund shall be transferred to the retirement reserve fund and thereafter all such pensions shall be paid from the retirement reserve fund. 
(Ord. 445 § 31, 1968) 
2.80.320 - Expense payments. 
    The board may use a portion of the income of the system to defray the costs of investing, managing and protecting the assets of the system and may pay reasonable compensation for those services. 
(Ord. 825 § 1, 1991) 
2.80.330 - Trustees of system's assets-Investment authority. 
A.  The board shall be the trustees of the assets of the retirement system. It shall have full power and authority to invest and reinvest such assets subject to the provisions of Act No. 314 of the Public Acts of 1965 as amended, and as it might from time to time be amended or replaced by successor acts. The board shall have full power to hold, sell, purchase, assign, transfer and dispose of any securities and investments in which any moneys of the system have been invested, as well as the proceeds of the investments and any moneys belonging to the system. There shall be kept on deposit available cash not to exceed five percent of the total assets of the system. 
B.  All assets of the retirement system shall be held for the sole purpose of meeting disbursements authorized by this chapter and shall be used for no other purpose. The description of the various funds of the system shall be interpreted to refer to the accounting records of the system and not to the segregation of assets in the funds of the system. 
(Ord. 445 § 33, 1968) 
2.80.340 - Income fund-Allowance of regular interest. 
A.  The income fund shall be the fund to which is credited all interest, dividends, and other income derived from investments of the retirement system, all gifts and bequests received by the system, all unclaimed accumulated contributions as provided in this chapter, and all other moneys received by the system the disposition of which is not specifically provided for in this chapter. There shall be paid from the income fund all investment expense and all amounts required to credit regular interest to the funds of the system as provided in this chapter. Whenever the balance in the income fund is more than sufficient to cover current charges to the fund, such excess amount, or any part thereof, may be used to provide contingency reserves or to meet special requirements of the other funds of the system as the board shall determine. Whenever the balance in the income fund is insufficient to meet the charges to the fund the amount of the insufficiency shall be transferred from the pension reserve fund to the income fund. A member's accumulated contributions transferred from the members' deposit fund to the income fund may be paid from the income fund upon proper claim for same approved by the board. 
B.  The board shall, at the end of each fiscal year, allow and credit regular interest to each member's individual account in the members' savings fund; such interest to be computed on the member's balance at the beginning of the fiscal year after deducting any withdrawal of accumulated contributions made by him or her during the year. The board shall, at the end of each fiscal year, allow and credit regular interest to the retirement reserve fund and pension reserve fund; such interest to be computed on the mean balances in the respective funds during the year. The amounts of interest so allowed and credited shall be paid from the income fund. 
(Ord. 445 § 34, 1968) 
2.80.350 - Assignments prohibited. 
A.  The right of a person to a pension, to the return of accumulated contributions, the pension itself, any other right accrued or accruing under the provisions of this chapter, and the moneys belonging to the retirement system, shall be unassignable and shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of bankruptcy or insolvency law, or any other process of law whatsoever, except as is specifically provided in this chapter. 
B.  The city shall have the right of setoff for any claim arising from embezzlement by or fraud of a member, retirant, or beneficiary. 
C.  If a member is covered by a group insurance or prepayment plan participated in by the city, and should he or she be permitted to, and elect to, continue such coverage as a retirant, he or she may authorize the board to have deducted from his or her pension the payments required of him or her to continue coverage under such group insurance or prepayment plan. 
(Ord. 445 § 35, 1968) 
2.80.360 - Correction of errors. 
    Should any error in the records of the city or the retirement system result in any person receiving more or less than he or she would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, the board shall correct such error, and as far as practicable shall adjust the payment in such manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which the person was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Ord. 445 § 36, 1968) 
2.80.370 - Accrued rights unimpaired. 
    In no case shall the accrued rights of any member, retirant, or beneficiary, under Ordinance 60, codified as Chapter 2, as amended by Ordinances 96, 117, 146, 212, 246 and 372, be impaired or diminished by the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 445 § 37, 1968) 
Chapter 2.100 - 1989 RETIREMENT PLAN 
Sections: 

2.100.010 - Amendment of the retirement ordinance and trust. 
A.  Pursuant to city ordinance (the "retirement ordinance"), the city of Hazel Park ("city") established the Hazel Park employee retirement system ("retirement system") effective July 1, 1945. It has been maintained continuously since then, subject to certain amendments. The city now wishes to amend and restate the retirement ordinance in order to comply with changes in applicable federal income tax laws relating to qualified defined benefit plans and trusts, and in order to generally improve the retirement system. 
    The retirement ordinance is therefore amended and restated in its entirety as hereinafter set forth. The provisions of the amended and restated retirement ordinance shall be effective as of July 1, 1989 except as otherwise specified herein. If a participant (or person claiming a benefit with respect to a participant) terminated employment, died, became disabled, or otherwise became entitled to a benefit prior to July 1, 1989 (or other applicable effective date), benefits under the retirement system shall be determined and paid in accordance with the retirement ordinance as in effect as of the date the termination of employment, death, disability, or other benefit entitlement occurred. 
B.  The city hereby amends and restates its defined benefit pension plan and trust previously known as the "1968 retirement plan," which effective July 1, 1989 shall be known as the 1989 retirement plan (the "retirement ordinance"). This retirement ordinance is intended to be a qualified plan and trust pursuant to Sections 401(a) and 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code ("Code") as such rules apply to "governmental plans" (as defined at Section 414(d) of the Code.). 
    Notwithstanding the general effective date, this restated 1989 plan was not adopted by city council until February 28, 1994. Thus, while the tax qualification provisions of the amended and restated retirement ordinance are generally effective July 1, 1989, the non-tax qualification design changes, specifically deletion of the workers' compensation offset provision of the 1968 plan, should be and hereby is prospective on February 28, 1994, the date of effective adoption of the amended and restated plan by the city council. General coverage plan participants who seek to redeem workers' compensation benefits and who terminate employment prior to February 28, 1994 will be subject to the workers' compensation offset of the 1968 plan. 
    Neither the amended and restated retirement ordinance nor any subsequent amendment shall diminish or impair any participant's accrued financial benefits (in violation of Article 9, Section 24 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963, as amended) under the retirement ordinance as constituted prior to such amendment and restatement (or subsequent amendment). If at any time it shall appear that this restated retirement ordinance (or a subsequent amendment) would diminish or impair benefits contrary to the preceding sentence, the board of trustees shall construe the terms of this amended and restated ordinance to achieve, as nearly as possible, the same result as would have occurred under the retirement ordinance prior to amendment and restatement (or subsequent amendment). 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.020 - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases as used in this chapter shall have the following meaning, unless a different meaning is clearly indicated by the context: 
A.  "Accumulated participant contributions" means for a participant the total of the participant's accumulated individual contributions made pursuant to the participant contribution rate of the applicable coverage plan, and including Investment Earnings credited thereon pursuant to Section 2.100.380. Prior to the first paychecks issued in January, 1999, such contributions were deducted from participant's compensation and made on an after-tax basis. Beginning with the first paychecks issued in January, 1999, for non-union employees, and union groups which elect the change, such contributions are made on a pre-tax basis, pursuant to the "pick-up" feature of Section 2.100.370. 
B.  "Administrative subcommittee" means a subcommittee of the board of trustees established for purposes of handling administrative, ministerial, and other non-decisional matters. It shall consist of three members from the pension board of trustees to be appointed by a majority vote of the board, pursuant to rules and regulations established by the board for purposes of administering the retirement system. 
C.  "Beneficiary" means any person or persons designated as such by the participant on a form supplied by the board to receive benefits payable under the provisions of Section 2.100.290 of this chapter. If no such designation is in effect at the time of the death of the participant, or if no person so designated shall survive the participant, the beneficiary shall be the spouse of the participant if then living, otherwise the participant's surviving children in equal shares, or if the deceased participant has no surviving spouse or children, the legal representative of such deceased participant; or if there shall be such legal representative duly appointed and qualified within six months of the date of death of such deceased participant, then such persons as, at the date of the participant's death, would be entitled to share in the distribution of such deceased participant's personal estate under the provisions of the statute governing the descent of intestate property, then in force and effect in the state of Michigan. The determination by the board of the identity of such person or persons shall be final, conclusive and binding on all persons, and the board and the retirement system shall be fully protected and shall incur no liability regardless of any error that it may make in such determination. 
D.  "Board of trustees" or "board" means the board of trustees provided for in this chapter. 
E.  "City" means the city of Hazel Park, Michigan. 
F.  "Code" means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended from time to time and including applicable regulations. 
G.  "Compensation" shall have the meanings set forth below: 
1.  For participants in the general coverage plan (2.100.230), the fire chief coverage plan (2.100.260B) or the firefighters coverage plan (2.100.270), the base salary or wages paid a participant for personal services rendered the city. Compensation includes: 
a.  Longevity pay, shift premiums and fill-in time; 
b.  Vacation pay and holiday pay which is paid to an active employee for time off actually used; 
c.  Cost of living payments; 
d.  Reimbursement to an active employee on the annual option for sick time in excess of one hundred days (or such other number of hours as shall apply pursuant to labor agreement or personnel policy); 
e.  Base salary or wages while absent from work with pay or on account of illness; 
f.  City contributions on behalf of the participant on a salary reduction basis to a deferred compensation program maintained pursuant to Section 457 of the Code; 
g.  Workers compensation wage loss benefits paid to a participant and relating to the participant's period as an active employee; 
h.  Educational premium payments; 
i.  Payments upon termination of employment for accrued but unused sick time which are included in compensation under the applicable coverage plan. 
2.  For participants in the patrol officers coverage plan (2.100.240), the police command officers coverage plan (2.100.250), or the police chief coverage plan (2.100.260A). 
a.  For participants who terminate employment with the city prior to July 1, 2001 "compensation" shall have the meaning set forth at subsection (G)(1) of this section; 
b.  For participants who terminate employment with the city on or after July 1, 2001, "compensation" shall mean all amounts subject to federal income tax withholding, as reported by the city on the participant's wage and tax statement (Form W-2), including the amounts, if any, which are contributed by the city pursuant to a salary reduction agreement and which are not includable in the gross income of the participant under Code Sections 125, 132(f)(4), or 457(b). Notwithstanding the foregoing, amounts paid to a participant upon termination of employment for accrued but unused sick time in excess of the amount included in "compensation" pursuant to the applicable coverage plan shall not be included in "compensation" under subsection (G)(2) of this section, even though such amounts are reported on a participant's W-2. 
    Compensation shall not include any salary, wage or other remuneration not specifically designated in this section as included in compensation unless otherwise provided in Sections 2.100.230, 2.100.240, 2.100.250, 2.100.260A, 2.100.260B and 2.100.270 of this chapter. 
    Annual compensation in excess of the following amounts shall not be taken into account for any purpose of the retirement ordinance: 
i.  Two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000), for plan years beginning after December 31, 1988 but before January 1, 1994; 
ii.  One hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000), for plan years beginning after December 31, 1993 but before January 1, 2002; and 
iii.  Two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000), for plan years beginning after December 31, 2001. 
    The limitations in subsections (G)(2)(b)(i), (ii), and (iii) of this section shall be adjusted for cost-of-living in such manner as the Secretary of the Treasury may prescribe pursuant to Section 401(a)(17) of the Code. 
    If the period for determining compensation used in calculating a participant's accrual for a determination period is a short plan year (i.e., shorter than twelve (12) months), the annual adjusted limitation is an amount equal to the otherwise applicable annual limitation multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of months in the short plan year, and the denominator of which is twelve (12). 
    In determining the compensation of a participant for purposes of this limitation for plan years beginning before January 1, 1997, the family aggregation rules under Section 414(q)(6) of the Code shall apply, except that in applying such rules, the term "family" shall include only the spouse of the participant and any lineal descendants of the participant who have not attained age nineteen (19) before the close of the plan year. If, as a result of the application of such rules, the adjusted limitation is exceeded, then the limitation shall be prorated among the affected individuals in proportion to each such individual's compensation as determined under this section prior to the application of this limitation. Effective for plan years beginning on or after January 1, 1997, the family aggregation rules under Section 414(q) of the Code shall not apply in determining a participant's compensation for purposes of this limitation. 
H.  "Coverage plan" means the coverage plan applicable to a participant as provided in Sections 2.100.230, 2.100.240, 2.100.250, 2.100.260 and 2.100.270. 
I.  "Credited service" means a participant's years of service, to the nearest one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) year, determined pursuant to Section 2.100.060 of this chapter. 
J.  "Employee" means an individual who is employed by the city in a position subject to withholding of federal income tax, including appointed officials. Effective November 28, 1995, "Employee" means an individual who is employed by the city, the 43rd district court or the library board on a full-time basis in a position subject to withholding of federal income tax, including appointed officials. 
K.  "Highly compensated participant" means as follows: 
1.  For plan years beginning before January 1, 1997, a highly compensated participant shall be any participant who, during the current plan year or the preceding plan year: 
a.  Received 415 compensation from the city in excess of seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) (or such greater amount as determined by the Secretary of the Treasury pursuant to Section 414(q) of the Code; or 
b.  Received 415 compensation from the city in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) (or such greater amount as determined by the Secretary of the Treasury pursuant to Section 414(q) of the Code) and was in the top-paid group of employees for such year. 
2.  For plan years beginning on or after January 1, 1997, a highly compensated participant shall be any participant who, during the preceding plan year: 
a.  Received 415 compensation from the city in excess of eighty thousand dollars ($80,000.00) (or such greater amount as determined by the Secretary of the Treasury pursuant to Section 414(q) of the Code); and 
b.  Was in the top-paid group of employees for such year. 
c.  For purposes of this subsection K, the following definitions shall apply: 
(i)  "415 compensation" means compensation as defined in Section 415(c)(3) of the Code and in Section 2.100.670 of this retirement ordinance. 
(ii)  "Top-paid group of employees" means the top twenty (20) percent of city employees when ranked on the basis of 415 compensation received during the current plan year or the preceding plan year, as applicable. For purposes of determining the city employees to be ranked, employees described in Treasury Regulation Section 1.414(q)-1T, Q&A-9(b)(1)(i), (ii), and (iii)(B) shall be disregarded. 
3.  The determination of who is a highly compensated participant shall be made in accordance with Section 414(q) of the Code and applicable treasury regulations and other guidance of general applicability issued thereunder. 
L.  "Investment earnings" means additions to a participant's contribution account as determined by the board of trustees pursuant to Section 2.100.380; provided that effective for investment earnings credited after June 30, 2001, for participants of the patrol officers coverage plan, police command officers coverage plan and police chief coverage plan, "investment earnings" means additions to a participant's contribution account at an interest rate equal to the actuarial rate of return as defined in Section 2.100.410 of this chapter, but in no event less than 7.25%. 
M.  "Participant" means an employee in the retirement system who has met the requirements as provided in Section 2.100.030. 
N.  "Participant contribution rate" means the percentage of compensation contributed by a participant pursuant to the applicable coverage plan. 
O.  "Participant contributions" means the principal amount contributed by a participant pursuant to the participant contribution rate of the applicable coverage plan. 
P.  "Participant's contribution account" shall be an individual participant's account within the participant contribution fund, consisting of the participant's accumulated participant contributions. 
Q.  "Pension" means a series of monthly payments to a retired participant or survivor pension beneficiary from the retirement system. 
R.  "Plan year" means the twelve (12) consecutive month period beginning with July 1 and ending on June 30. 
S.  "Retired participant" means an individual who is being paid a pension on account of participation in the retirement system. 
T.  "Retirement system" means the retirement program maintained in accordance with the provisions of the retirement ordinance. 
U.  "Retirement system administrator" means the city clerk. 
V.  "Spouse" means the person who is legally married to a participant on the earlier of (a) the date benefit payments commence or (b) the date of death of the participant. 
W.  "Survivor pension beneficiary" means a natural person who has been designated pursuant to this chapter to be paid a pension as a result of the death of a participant or retired participant. In the case of benefit options Section 2.100.300(A) through (F) of this chapter, the designation must be a single survivor pension beneficiary. In the case of benefit option Option C120 under Section 2.100.300(H) of this chapter the designation may include a single survivor pension beneficiary or beneficiaries. 
X.  "Trustee" means the persons, board or corporation appointed pursuant to Section 2.100.540 to manage the funds of the retirement system. 
Y.  "Trust fund" or "fund" means all money, securities and other property held by the board of trustees as trustee pursuant to this retirement ordinance. 
Z.  "Vested former participant" means a former participant who terminates city employment without entitlement to an immediate pension, but who retains entitlement to a normal retirement pension as provided in Section 2.100.140. 
AA.  Effective November 28, 1995, "participating employer" means the city, the 43rd district court, or the library board. 
BB.  "Person" or "persons" shall refer to natural persons only. For example, and not by way of limitation, the term "person" shall not refer to a trust. 
(Ord. 03-05 § 3 (part), 2005; Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 04-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999; Ord. 938 (part), 1998; Ord. 924 (part), 1997; Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.030 - Participation in retirement system-Participation mandatory. 
    Each employee of the city as defined in Section 2.100.020 and effective July 1, 1983, each employee of the Hazel Park branch of the 43rd district court shall be a participant in the retirement system unless excluded from participation in accordance with Section 2.100.040. Effective November 28, 1995, library employees shall participate in the retirement system pursuant to the terms of Section 2.100.880 unless otherwise excluded from participation in accordance with Section 2.100.040. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999; Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.040 - Participation in retirement system-Exclusions from participation. 
    The following employees are excluded from participation: 
A.  Employees designated by the city as being employed in a position normally requiring less than one thousand six hundred (1,600) hours of work per year. 
B.  Effective July 8, 1991 by resolution of the city council, the city manager may elect to be excluded from membership in the retirement system. The election shall be irrevocable and shall be made in writing, at the time of hire, in the form prescribed by the board of trustees. An individual who elects to be excluded from membership as provided in this subsection may not thereafter become a participant of the retirement system on account of employment by the city nor shall any service rendered the city while the individual was excluded from membership be credited to the individual under Section 2.100.100. 
    The city manager serving on July 8, 1991 did elect to be excluded from membership in the retirement system. Since that individual was then a participant in the retirement system, the following conditions shall apply to him only: 
1.  The individual shall be paid his accumulated participant contributions and all credited service shall be forfeited. 
2.  The individual may not thereafter become a participant of the retirement system on account of employment by the city. 
3.  The individual's forfeited credited service and any service rendered the city while the individual was excluded from membership shall never be reinstated or credited to the individual under any circumstances. 
    Effective June 28, 1999, any employee who, at the time of hire, is designated by notice to the board and the employee as being in a non-benefit eligible position. Any such designation shall be made by the employee's participating employer, and must be consistent with any applicable collective bargaining agreement. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999; Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.050 - Participation in retirement system-Termination of participation. 
    An individual shall no longer be a participant upon ceasing to be an employee or upon becoming excluded from participation as provided in Section 2.100.040 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.060 - Credited service-Requirements for credit. 
    A participant shall receive credited service each plan year for service as an active employee with the city which includes periods of employment in which duties are performed and the participant is paid, and periods of employment for which the participant is paid but in which no duties are performed by reason of vacation, holiday, illness, jury duty and such other instances as may be prescribed by the board of trustees. A participant receiving workers compensation benefits shall continue to accrue credited service for pension purposes. In no case shall a participant be credited with more than one year of service for all service performed during a plan year. Service shall be credited to the nearest one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) year. No participant shall receive an additional month of credited service for having worked ten or more days in a calendar month, nor shall a participant be penalized for having worked less than ten days in a calendar month. Credited service shall continue to accrue on the basis of months, years, and days worked from the date of hire to the date of termination. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.070 - Credited service-Intervening military service. 
    Any participant who leaves the employ of the city for reason of service or training in the Armed Forces of the United States (whether inducted or enlisted, including Reserves and National Guard) and who leaves a position (other than a temporary position) in order to perform such training and service, shall be entitled to such reemployment rights as required by law, provided the participant makes application for reemployment within the period prescribed by law, and shall have the period of armed service included in the participant's credited service (subject to any limitation prescribed by law) if each of the following conditions is met: 
A.  The participant is reemployed by the city within the period during which the right to reemployment is guaranteed under the laws of the state of Michigan or of the United States (effective December 12, 1994, in accordance with the Uniformed Service Employment and Reemployment Rights Act ("USERRA") and Section 414(u) of the Code), or if there is no such law, within one year of the date of termination of required armed service. 
B.  The participant reinstates any credited service which was forfeited at the time of or during the period of armed service. 
    The participant shall be required to make accumulated participant contributions for the period of credited service granted on account of intervening military service. Payments of such accumulated participant contributions may, at the discretion of the board, be made by regular deduction from the participant's pay and paid to the retirement system. If, at the time a benefit is first payable to the participant or a beneficiary, the full amount of accumulated participant contributions has not been paid by the participant (or by a beneficiary), pro rata credited service shall be provided in the ratio of: 
1.  The principal amount of accumulated participant contributions which have been paid, over. 
2.  The total principal amount of accumulated participant contributions which were to be paid. 
    Such repayment must be made during the period beginning with the date of reemployment, and ending on the shorter of (i) five years, or (ii) three times the period of military service. 
    Effective December 12, 1994, this section shall be administered in accordance with USERRA and Code Section 414(u). 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.080 - Credited service-Nonintervening military service. 
A.  Any participant who, prior to becoming an employee, served in the Armed Forces of the United States (whether inducted or enlisted, including Reserves or National Guard), was called for active military service and receives a certificate relating to the satisfactory completion of active military service as prescribed under the laws of the United States, shall have the period of active service, not to exceed five years, included in the participant's credited service if all of the following conditions are met: 
1.  The participant elects to purchase such active military time within two and one-half years from date of hire or two and one-half years from April, 1988 whichever is later. 
2.  The participant pays to the pension reserve fund designated in Section 2.100.440 of this chapter, five percent of the participant's base salary such base salary determined as of the date of the election set forth at subsection B of this section for each month or credited service being claimed. 
B.  The election to purchase full monthly increments of the aforenoted active military service time shall be made in writing on a form prescribed by the board of trustees, filed with the retirement system administrator, and signed by the participant, on which the participant shall choose to pay for such time either in a lump sum, or by paying for same through a payroll deduction which shall be paid within five years, accompanied by interest on the unpaid balance of seven percent per year from and after the date of the election to purchase the time. 
C.  An employee who purchases active military service under this subsection may not withdraw his/her contribution for the active military service time under form of payment LS specified in Section 2.100.300 of this chapter. 
D.  In determining pension benefit amounts, the credit for active military service time shall be assumed to have been rendered on the day of the written election to purchase same. 
E.  Credited service shall not be given for periods of active service which have been used or are usable to obtain or increase a benefit from another retirement program. 
F.  The board of trustees shall promulgate such other and further rules to effectuate the purpose of this subsection. 
G.  Credit for military service under this section shall be for pension purposes only. 
H.  Final average compensation shall continue to be computed only on the basis of actual service rendered to the city. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.090 - Credited service-Forfeiture of credited service. 
A.  Upon termination of employment with the city, there shall be paid to a former participant who is not a vested former participant, his accumulated participant contributions standing to his credit at that time in his participant's contribution account, and his credited service shall be forfeited. The forfeiture of credited service and automatic payment of accumulated participant contributions required by this section shall not apply in the following cases: 
1.  The participant is absent on account of service in an armed service of the United States and returns to city employment within the period during which the right to reemployment is guaranteed under the laws of the state of Michigan or of the United States, or, if there is no such law, within one year of the date of termination of required armed service. 
2.  The participant is absent on account of an authorized unpaid leave of absence and returns to work on or before the end of the period of authorized leave of absence. 
3.  The participant terminates employment with the city but elects in accordance with procedures prescribed by the board to leave his accumulated participant contributions on deposit with the city. 
B.  Credited service for which a participant has made accumulated participant contributions shall be forfeited if the participant's accumulated participant contributions are paid to the participant prior to the participant's date of retirement (pursuant to Section 2.100.160), or to the participant's beneficiary (pursuant to Section 2.100.320(E)). 
C.  A former non-vested participant at the time a break in participation occurs, may elect under subsection (A)(3) of this section to leave his accumulated participant contributions on deposit in the retirement system. Such former participant shall not be entitled to a pension under this chapter unless the former participant returns to the city employment and thereby becomes vested in a pension, or unless the former participant becomes retroactively vested in a pension under this chapter by reason of subsequent credited service earned at a reciprocal unit under the provisions of the Michigan Reciprocal Retirement Act, hereinafter RRA, (MCLA Section 38.1101 et seq.). See Section 2.100.740 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.100 - Credited service-Reinstatement of forfeited credited service. 
    Credited service forfeited by reason of Section 2.100.090 or Section 2.100.160 shall be reinstated if all of the following conditions are met: 
A.  The participant pays the retirement system all accumulated participant contributions previously refunded to the participant, plus compound interest at the rates which were established by the board of trustees and calculated from the date of the refund of accumulated participant contributions to the date of the repayment to the retirement system. The time period in which repayment must be completed is as follows: 
1.  In the case of a rehired participant, repayment must be completed within one year of resumption of participation, 
2.  In the case of a participant who is not rehired, but who wishes to reinstate credited service for purposes of complying with the RRA, as same may be amended, repayment shall be completed within five years after the date the former participant first becomes employed by a succeeding reciprocal unit as defined in the RRA. 
    If the participant has not fully repaid the accumulated participant contributions at the time of the participant's subsequent retirement, disability, death or termination of employment: 
B.  Such participant shall receive a pro rata portion of his credited service based on the ratio of the accumulated participant contributions (including interest) which have been repaid over the total which was to be repaid; 
C.  Such participant, or the beneficiary of a deceased participant, may repay the unpaid balance of the participant's accumulated participant contributions, with interest, but in no event later than one year from the participant's resumption of employment following the participant's termination of employment, at which time all of the participant's previously forfeited credited service will be reinstated; 
D.  Effective for repayments of accumulated participant contributions after December 31, 2001, a participant who wishes to have forfeited credited service reinstated may make a direct trustee-to-trustee transfer of benefits from- 
(a)  An annuity contract described in Section 403(b) of the Code, or 
(b)  An eligible plan under Section 457(b) of the Code which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state, or any agency or instrumentality of a state or political subdivision of a state to repay the accumulated participant contributions to the retirement system, as permitted by Sections 403(b)(13)(B) and 457(e)(17)(B) of the Code, respectively; 
E.  Effective for repayments of accumulated participant contributions beginning on or after July 1, 2005, the cost to review and prepare documentation necessary to accomplish the repayment of accumulated participant contributions under this section, by a former employee or a participant to the retirement system to reinstate credited service forfeited by reason of Section 2.100.090 or Section 2.100.160 of this chapter shall be paid by the former employee or participant. The costs must be paid in full prior to the retirement system accepting a transfer or other monies, whether by deposit or wire transfer, to reinstate prior forfeited credited service. 
(Ord. 07-05 § 3 (part), 2005; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.110 - Normal retirement-Eligibility. 
    A participant or vested former participant may retire upon fulfilling all of the following requirements: 
A.  The participant or vested former participant meets an age and service requirement for normal retirement as specified in the coverage plan applicable to the participant or vested former participant; 
B.  The participant or vested former participant selects a date of retirement; 
C.  The participant or vested former participant makes a written application for normal retirement, on the form or forms prescribed by the board of trustees, and files it with the retirement system administrator prior to the selected date of retirement; and 
D.  Employment by the city in a position involving participation in the retirement system is terminated prior to the selected date of retirement. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.110A - Withdrawal of application for retirement. 
    Upon filing the application for retirement, the retirement system administrator shall date stamp the application and copies evidencing the application for retirement shall be returned to the participant. The participant shall have seven days from the date of application as shown on the date stamp in which to withdraw the application for retirement, provided that a participant in the police command or police patrol coverage plans shall have thirty (30) days in which to withdraw the application. The withdrawal of an application for retirement shall be in writing on a form prescribed by the board of trustees, filed with the retirement system administrator, date stamped with a copy to the participant as described above. Absent a request for withdrawal of the application for retirement within the seven-day (or thirty (30)-day) window period, the participant's application for retirement shall be irrevocable and final, subject to the following: 
A.  The board in its discretion may allow a later withdrawal at the request of a participant upon a showing of changed circumstances which creates an undue hardship on the participant. 
B.  Provided that in no event may a retirement application be withdrawn once pension payments begin. 
    Upon filing the application for retirement, provided that for a participant in the police command or patrol officers coverage plans such application is filed six months in advance with the police chief, the retirement system administrator shall date stamp the application and copies evidencing the application for retirement shall be returned to the participant. The participant shall have seven days from the date of application as shown on the date stamp in which to withdraw the application for retirement, provided that a participant in the police command or patrol coverage plans shall have thirty (30) days in which to withdraw the application. The withdrawal of an application for retirement shall be in writing on a form prescribed by the board of trustees, filed with the retirement system administrator, date stamped with a copy to the participant as described above. Absent a request for withdrawal of the application for retirement within the seven-day (or thirty (30)-day) window period, the participant's application for retirement shall be irrevocable and final, subject to the following: 
A.  The board in its discretion may allow a later withdrawal at the request of the participant upon a showing of changed circumstances which creates an undue hardship on the participant. 
B.  In the case of a participant in the police command or police patrol officer coverage plans, upon expiration of the thirty (30)-day window period and upon the request of such participant, the withdrawal of the retirement application may occur with the concurrence of the police chief and the city manager; Provided that in no event may a retirement application be withdrawn once pension payments begin. 
    The provisions of this section with respect to participants in the police command or patrol officer coverage plans shall be effective July 1, 1996. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002) 
2.100.120 - Normal retirement-Amount of pension. 
    Except as otherwise provided by this chapter and the provisions of Section 415 of the Code applicable to public employee retirement plans, the amount of normal retirement pension, under the standard form of payment, is determined in accordance with the coverage plan applicable to the participant or vested former participant. See Sections 2.100.860 and 2.100.870 for the pension of participants who transfer employment within the same participating employer or from one participating employer to another. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.130 - Rehired retiree. 
    If a retired participant is re-employed by a participating employer, his pension shall continue to be paid to him during his period of reemployment. During such rehired retired participant's re-employment- 
A.  He shall earn an additional, separate pension based solely on compensation and credited service during his period of re-employment pursuant to the terms of the applicable coverage plan, and 
B.  He shall be credited with credited service earned prior to his first retirement solely for purposes of vesting in the additional pension earned during his re-employment. 
    The amount of the additional pension shall be paid in the standard form of payment as provided in Section 2.100.290 or in an optional form of payment as elected by the participant in accordance with Sections 2.100.280 and 2.100.300. The participant may elect a different form of payment for the additional separate pension earned during the participant's re-employment. To the extent practicable, the amount of the additional pension shall be added to the amount of the original pension when such rehired retired participant again retires. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.140 - Vested termination of participation-Eligibility for vested termination. 
    A participant who ceases to be a participant for a reason other than death or retirement shall be a vested former participant if the participant meets all of the following requirements: 
A.  The participant meets the service requirement for vested termination of participation specified in the coverage plan applicable to the participant; and 
B.  The participant does not elect pursuant to Section 2.100.160 to be paid the participant's accumulated participant contributions in the retirement system at the time of termination of employment. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.150 - Vested termination of participation-Eligibility for normal retirement and pension. 
    Eligibility of a vested former participant for normal retirement, and the amount of normal retirement pension, shall be determined according to the provisions of the retirement ordinance in effect at the time of termination of participation. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.160 - Vested termination of participation-Forfeiture of vested pension. 
    A vested former participant may elect to be paid accumulated participant contributions at any time after termination of employment and before commencement of his pension benefits, which election and payment shall result in forfeiture of credited service and all rights to any benefits of the retirement system other than payment of the accumulated participant contributions. Such election must be made in writing, on a form prescribed by the board of trustees, filed with the retirement system administrator prior to the commencement of pension benefits. 
    Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this section, a participant who becomes vested in all or part of his accrued benefit pursuant to a qualified transfer under Section 2.100.460A, who does not receive a cashout pursuant to Section 2.100.460B, shall be entitled to a pension from the retirement system subject to all other terms and conditions of the retirement ordinance. If such participant withdrew his accumulated participant contributions, the amount of his pension shall be determined by subtracting the actuarial equivalent of his accumulated participant contributions from his accrued benefit. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 14-00 (part), 2000: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.170 - Disability retirement-Conditions for retirement. 
    The board of trustees may retire a participant on account of disability (as described at Section 2.100.180), if all of the following requirements are met: 
A.  The participant meets the service requirement for disability retirement specified in the coverage plan applicable to the participant, or the board of trustees determines the disability to have been the natural and proximate result of causes arising out of and in the course of the participant's employment by the city in which case the service requirement shall be waived; 
B.  The participant was a participant at the time the disability was incurred; 
C.  A written application for disability retirement, on the form prescribed by the board of trustees, has been filed with the retirement system administrator by the participant or the participant's department head; 
D.  The participant's employment with the city is terminated prior to the selected date of disability retirement; 
E.  The participant submits to all medical examinations and tests, and furnishes copies of all medical reports, requested by the board of trustees; and 
F.  The medical examiner makes the certification required under Section 2.100.180. 
    In addition to the conditions set forth at Section 2.100.170 for a disability retirement, the participant shall also satisfy the following condition: 
G.  File with the retirement system administrator, on a form prescribed by the board of trustees, a written release authorizing the disclosure of any medical evaluation/report and accompanying documentation. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.180 - Disability retirement-Medical certification required. 
A.  A condition for disability retirement is a written certification by the medical examiner to the board of trustees that: 
1.  The participant is totally incapacitated and unable to perform the duties of his or her employment as a result of a mental or physical condition; and 
2.  The incapacity is likely to be permanent. 
B.  The medical examiner shall be one or more licensed physicians selected by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.190 - Disability retirement-Amount of pension. 
    The amount of a disability retirement pension shall be determined according to the provisions specified in the coverage plan applicable to the participant. Disability pensions are subject to the limitations specified in Sections 2.100.210 and 2.100.220 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.200 - Re-evaluation of disability retired participant-Termination of pension. 
A.  The board of trustees may require a disability retired participant to undergo a medical evaluation or other re-evaluation by a medical examiner satisfactory to the board not more frequently than once a year, at the retirement system's expense, or to submit acceptable evidence of continuation of disability, if the participant has not met the age requirement for normal retirement as specified in the coverage plan applicable to the participant. Therefore, the participant shall have no claim of physician patient privilege with respect to the medical evaluation. The medical evaluation requested by the board of trustees shall not be for the purpose of obtaining information in order that the medical examiner/physician be able to render medical advice or treatment on behalf of the participant. The medical evaluation shall be for the express purpose of determining initial and/or continuing eligibility for a disability pension benefit as a participant in the retirement system. Medical examinations or other re-evaluations not specifically required by the board of trustees shall be solely at the retired participant's expense. 
B.  The board of trustees may suspend payment of a disability pension if the disability retired participant refuses to submit to re-evaluation. If the refusal continues for one year, the board of trustees may, at the board's discretion, terminate the disability retirement pension and revoke the disability retired participant's right to the disability retirement pension. 
C.  A disability pension shall be terminated if the medical examiner reports that the disability retired participant is capable of resuming the participant's duties of employment with the city.
