A former disability retired participant who returns to the employ of the city shall again be a participant, and credited service at time of disability retirement shall be restored to the participant' s credit. Credited service shall not be granted for the period of disability retirement unless the board of trustees has found the disability to have been the natural and proximate result of causes arising out of and in the course of the participant's employment by the city. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.210 - Disability retired participant-Earnings from gainful employment. 
A.  The provisions of this section apply only to a disability retired participant who has not met the age requirement for normal retirement. The amount of a disability pension shall not exceed the difference between (i) one hundred percent (100%) of the retired participant's annual base rate of compensation at the time of disability increased proportionately for changes in the rate of compensation for the rank, grade, or position held at time of disability retirement; and (ii) the annual amount of the retired participant's considered income. The retired participant's considered income is compensation obtained as a result of the participant's own personal services but shall not include passive income, from investments, for example. As a condition of continuing eligibility for an unreduced disability pension benefit, a disability retired participant shall inform the board annually in writing on a form prescribed by the board of the annual amount of income obtained as a result of gainful employment, as described above. 
    Upon receipt of the information, the administrative committee shall determine whether an adjustment to the amount of disability pension is necessary and inform the board of trustees of its determination. In the event an adjustment is necessary, the administrative committee shall engage the actuary to recalculate the pension applying the limitation to the disabled retiree pension. Application of the limitation shall be to the amount of pension under form of payment option SL. The effect of an election of any other form of payment option shall be taken into account after application of the limitation to the amount of pension under form of payment option SL. 
B.  "Compensation" for purposes of this section shall mean the base salary or wages paid a participant for personal services rendered to the city at the time of disability. Compensation includes: 
1.  Longevity pay, shift premiums and fill-in time; 
2.  Vacation pay and holiday pay; 
3.  Cost of living payments; 
4.  Reimbursement on the annual option for sick time in excess of one hundred (100) days (or equivalent); 
5.  Base salary or wages while absent from work with pay or on account of illness; 
6.  City contributions on behalf of the participant to a deferred compensation program maintained pursuant to Section 457 of the Internal Revenue Code; 
7.  Educational premium payments. 
C.  In no event shall the amount of a retired participant's disability pension payable prior to age fifty-five (55) (or age sixty (60) in the case of a participant in the general coverage plan) be reduced below fifty percent (50%) of final average compensation. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.220 - Workers' compensation-Police or fire participant election between workers' compensation and pension benefits. 
A.  Police or fire participants who qualify for workers' compensation benefits may totally waive receiving a disability retirement benefit under the retirement system and instead elect workers' compensation benefits as provided in Section 161 of the Workers' Disability Compensation Act of 1969, MCLA Section, 418.161, et seq. ("Workers' Compensation Act"). 
B.  A police or fire participant who elects to receive workers' compensation benefits in lieu of a disability retirement benefit shall, within ninety (90) days of becoming eligible for workers' compensation benefits, give written notice on a form prescribed by the board of trustees and filed with the retirement system administrator. The waiver shall be irrevocable until the participant reaches the age or level of service, or combination thereof, which shall allow such participant to receive a retirement benefit under the retirement ordinance not conditioned on his disability. 
C.  Upon meeting the requirements for a service-based or age- and service-based pension benefit, such a benefit shall not constitute "like benefits" under the Workers' Compensation Act. The participant need no longer choose between workers' compensation or pension benefits. However, such pension benefits shall not commence under the retirement system until the participant makes written application on a form prescribed by the board of trustees and filed with the retirement system administrator. At such time, pension benefits shall be paid on a prospective basis only, and subject to all provisions of the retirement ordinance applicable to the pension benefit in question. 
D.  Under the terms of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, it is intended that pension benefits be primary and workers' compensation benefits secondary such that workers' compensation benefits shall be reduced by any pension benefits payable. However, if a participant waives pension benefits under subsection A of this section, receives a lump sum redemption of workers' compensation benefits, and thereafter becomes entitled to an age- or service-based pension under subsection C of this section, such age or service pension must be coordinated with the lump sum redemption award to avoid a duplication of payments prohibited by Section 354 of the Workers' Compensation Act. 
    Therefore, the age- or service-based pension shall be reduced by the portion of a lump sum redemption relating to wage loss and applicable to the time period commencing with the age- or service-based pension, to the extent such redemption has not been reduced by reason of the age- or service-based pension to which the participant is eligible. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.230 - General coverage plan. 
A.  The general coverage plan is applicable to all participants who are not participants of the patrol officers coverage plan, police command officers coverage plan, firefighters coverage plan or the police chief and fire chief coverage plan. 
B.  A participant covered by the general coverage plan shall contribute five percent of the participant's annual compensation. The city manager serving on June 9, 1997, shall be entitled to have the city make this contribution on his behalf. The contribution shall be made directly to the participant contribution fund, and credited as an accumulated participant contribution on behalf of the serving city manager. All contributions shall be made on a pre-tax basis, and excluded from the city manager's gross income in the year in which the amounts are contributed, since such contributions are being directly deposited in the retirement system in the city. 
C.  Final average compensation is one-half of the total amount of compensation paid a participant for the two consecutive years of credited service in which the total amount of compensation paid is highest. For this purpose both retroactive pay increases and longevity payments which have accrued to the participant but have yet to be paid shall be counted; provided, however, that up to twenty-four (24) days of accrued but unused sick days shall be converted, paid as compensation, and counted for purposes of final average compensation for the employee groups set forth below, subject to the effective dates described below: 
1.  July 1, 1999 for the Supervisor's Union Local 1917 and the Non-Union Employees; and 
2.  July 1, 2000 for the Michigan Association of Public Employees (MAPE) and the Clerical Chapter Local 998. 
    The two consecutive years of service shall be contained within the ten years of credited service immediately preceding the participant's last termination of participation. If the participant does not have two years of credited service, final average compensation is the aggregate amount of compensation paid the participant divided by the participant's period of credited service. 
D.  The age and service requirements for normal retirement are: 
1.  Age fifty (50) with twenty (20) or more years of credited service; 
2.  Age fifty-five (55) with fifteen (15) or more years of credited service; 
3.  Age sixty (60) with ten or more years of credited service; provided, however, a general coverage plan participant who was hired prior to January 1, 1975 and who is a member of the Supervisors' Union Local 1917 bargaining unit as of July 1, 1996 may retire with twenty-five (25) years of service without regard to age. Effective July 1, 1996, participants who are members of Teamster Local 214 may retire with twenty-five (25) years of service without regard to age. Effective July 1, 2000 participants who are members of the MAPE may retire with twenty-five (25) years of service without regard to age. 
    General coverage plan participants who are members of Supervisor's Union Local 1917, Teamster Local 214 or Clerical Chapter 998 shall file an application for retirement with the retirement system administrator not less than thirty (30) days no more than ninety (90) days prior to the participant's selected date of retirement. The withdrawal of an application for retirement shall be governed by Section 2.100.110A. 
E.  Subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under the standard form of payment is two percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service earned after July 1, 1986, plus one and three-quarters of final average compensation multiplied by credited service earned prior to June 30, 1986. 
    For the employee groups described below, on the effective dates described below, and subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under the standard form of payment is two and two-tenths percent of final average compensation multiplied by all years of credited service. The provision of this paragraph shall apply to participants in the Supervisors' Union Local 214 and non-union city employees on July 1, 1999. For participants who are in the Clerical Chapter 998, MAPE this provision shall be effective July 1, 2000. For participants who are in the Teamsters Local 214 this provision shall be effective July 1, 2001. 
F.  The service requirement for vested termination of participation is ten or more years of credited service. 
G.  The service requirement for non-duty disability retirement is ten or more years of credited service. 
H.  The amount of a non-duty disability pension shall be calculated in the same manner as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of non-duty disability retirement. 
I.  The amount of duty disability pension shall be calculated as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of duty disability retirement plus service credit for the period from the date of duty disability retirement to the date the participant would attain age sixty (60) years. The duty disability pension payable prior to attainment of age sixty (60) years under form of payment SL shall not be less than fifty (50) percent of final average compensation. The participant may request payment under one of the optional forms of payment specified in Section 2.100.300 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.240 - Patrol officers coverage plan. 
A.  The patrol officers coverage plan is applicable to any police participant represented by holding the rank of patrolman. 
B.  A participant covered by the patrol officers coverage plan shall contribute five and one-half percent of participant's annual compensation. Effective as of July 30, 1997, and for the next thirty (30) years, a participant covered by the patrol officers coverage plan shall contribute 8.5% of annual compensation, after which time the contribution rate shall be reduced to 7.38% of a participant's annual compensation. Effective as of July 1, 2001, a participant covered by the patrol officers coverage plan shall contribute 10.35% of annual compensation. 
C.  Final average compensation is one-half of the total amount of compensation paid a participant for the two consecutive years of credited service in which the total amount of compensation paid is highest. For this purpose both retroactive pay increases and longevity payments which have accrued to the participant but have yet to be paid shall be counted; provided, however, that effective July 1, 2000, up to one hundred ninety-two (192) hours of accrued but unused sick time shall be converted, paid as compensation, and counted for purposes of final average compensation. The two consecutive years of credited service shall be contained within the ten years of credited service immediately preceding the participant's last termination of participation. If the participant does not have two years of credited service, final average compensation is the aggregate amount of compensation paid the participant divided by the participant's total period of credited service. 
D.  The age and service requirements for normal retirement are: 
1.  Twenty-five (25) years of service regardless of age (effective for participants who terminate employment with the city on or after July 1, 2001, twenty-five (25) years of service shall be reduced to twenty (20) years of service); or 
2.  Age fifty-five (55) with ten or more years of service. 
E.  Subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is the sum of (i) two percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service, to a maximum of twenty-five (25) years of credited service, plus, one percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years for all service rendered prior to October 1, 1979, plus (ii) two and one-half percent of final average compensation times years of service rendered after October 1, 1979, maximum total service before and after October 1, 1979 is thirty (30) years. 
    Participants with pension credits calculated at lower than 2.5 multiplier factor may, at their own expense, purchase credits for all city time to a maximum of 2.5 multiplier factor for all years served in the city's employment. 
    Effective July 1, 2001, subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is equal to three percent of final average compensation multiplied by years of credited service, provided that the pension under option SL shall not exceed seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. 
F.  The service requirement for vested termination of participation is ten or more years of credited service. 
G.  The service requirement for non-duty disability retirement is ten or more years of credited service. 
H.  The amount of a non-duty disability pension shall be calculated in the same manner as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of non-duty disability retirement. 
I.  The amount of duty disability pension shall be calculated as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of duty disability retirement plus service credit for the period from the date of duty disability retirement to the date the participant would attain age fifty-five (55) years. The duty disability pension payable prior to attainment of age fifty-five (55) years under form of payment SL shall not be less than fifty (50) percent of final average compensation. The participant may request payment under one of the optional forms of payment specified in Section 2.100.300 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.250 - Police command officers coverage plan. 
A.  The police command officers coverage plan is applicable to any police participant who holds the rank of sergeant or lieutenant in the police department. 
B.  A participant covered by the police command officers coverage plan shall contribute five and one-half percent of participant's annual compensation. Effective July 28, 1997, a participant covered by the police command officers coverage plan shall contribute 10.35% of annual compensation. 
C.  Final average compensation is one-half of the total amount of compensation paid a participant for the two consecutive years of credited service in which the total amount of compensation paid is highest. For this purpose both retroactive pay increases and longevity payments which have accrued to the participant but have yet to be paid shall be counted, provided, however, that effective July 1, 2001, up to one hundred ninety-two (192) hours of accrued but unused sick time shall be converted, paid as compensation, and counted for purposes of final average compensation. The two consecutive years of credited service shall be contained within the ten years of credited service immediately preceding the participant's last termination of participation. If the participant does not have two years of credited service, final average compensation is the aggregate amount of compensation paid the participant divided by the participant's total period of credited service. 
D.  The age and service requirements for normal retirement are: 
1.  Twenty-five (25) years of service regardless of age (effective for participants who terminate employment with the city on or after July 1, 2001, twenty-five (25) years of service shall be reduced to twenty (20) years of service); or 
2.  Age fifty-five (55) with ten or more years of service. 
E.  Subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is equal to the sum of (i) two percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service, to a maximum of twenty-five (25) years of credited service, plus, two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years for all years of service rendered prior to July 1, 1978, plus (ii) two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service earned after July 1, 1978 to a maximum of seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. 
    Participants with pension credits calculated at lower than 2.5 multiplier factor may, at their own expense, purchased credits for all city time to a maximum of 2.5 multiplier factor for all years served in the city's employment. 
    Effective July 1, 2001, subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is equal to three percent of final average compensation multiplied by years of credited service, provided that the pension under option SL shall not exceed seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. 
F.  The service requirement for vested termination of participation is ten or more years of credited service. 
G.  The service requirement for non-duty disability retirement is ten or more years of credited service. 
H.  The amount of a non-duty disability pension shall be calculated in the same manner as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of non-duty disability retirement. 
I.  The amount of duty disability pension shall be calculated as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of duty disability retirement plus service credit for the period from the date of duty disability retirement to the date the participant would attain age fifty-five (55) years. The duty disability pension payable prior to attainment of age fifty-five (55) years under form of payment SL shall not be less than fifty (50) percent of final average compensation. The participant may request payment under one of the optional forms of payment specified in Section 2.100.300 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.260A - Police chief coverage plan. 
A.  The police chief coverage plan is applicable to the police chief. 
B.  A participant covered by the police chief coverage plan shall contribute five and one-half percent of participant's annual compensation. Effective April 22, 2000, a participant covered by the police chief coverage plan shall contribute 5.35% of participant's annual compensation, and the city shall contribute as participant contributions five percent of such participant's annual compensation. 
C.  Final average compensation is one-half of the total amount of compensation paid a participant for the two consecutive years of credited service in which the total amount of compensation paid is highest. For this purpose both retroactive pay increases and longevity payments which have accrued to the participant but have yet to be paid shall be counted; provided, however, that effective July 1, 2001, up to one hundred ninety-two (192) hours of accrued but unused sick time shall be converted, paid as compensation, and counted for purposes of final average compensation. The two consecutive years of credited service shall be contained within the ten years of credited service immediately preceding the participant's last termination of participation. If the participant does not have two years of credited service, final average compensation is the aggregate amount of compensation paid the participant divided by the participant's total period of credited service. Total amount of compensation may include eligible accumulated sick time as provided by the bargaining agreement in effect at time of retirement. 
D.  The age and service requirements for normal retirement are: 
1.  Any age with twenty-five (25) years of service (effective for participants who terminate employment with the city on or after July 1, 2001, twenty-five (25) years of service shall be reduced to twenty (20) years of service); or 
2.  Age fifty-five (55) with ten or more years of service. 
E.  Subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is equal to the sum of (i) two percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service, to a maximum of twenty-five (25) years of credited service, plus, two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, and (ii) two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service earned after July 1, 1978 to a maximum of seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. 
    Effective July 1, 2001, subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is equal to three percent of final average compensation multiplied by years of credited service, provided that the pension under option SL shall not exceed seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. 
F.  The service requirement for vested termination of participation is ten or more years of credited service. 
G.  The service requirement for non-duty disability retirement is ten or more years of credited service. 
H.  The amount of a non-duty disability annuity pension shall be calculated in the same manner as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of non-duty disability retirement. 
I.  The amount of duty disability pension shall be calculated as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of duty disability retirement plus service credit for the period from the date of duty disability retirement to the date the participant would attain age fifty-five (55) years. The duty disability pension payable prior to attainment of age fifty-five (55) years under form of payment SL shall not be less than fifty (50) percent of final average compensation. The participant may request payment under one of the optional forms of payment specified in Section 2.100.300 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002)

A.  The fire chief coverage plan is applicable to the fire chief.

For this purpose both retroactive pay increases and longevity payments which have accrued to the participant but have yet to be paid shall be counted, provided, however, that effective July 1, 2000, the fire chief shall have up to one hundred ninety-two (192) hours of accrued but unused sick time converted, paid as compensation and counted for purposes of final average compensation. The two consecutive years of credited service shall be contained within the ten years of credited service immediately preceding the participant's last termination of participation. If the participant does not have two years of credited service, final average compensation is the aggregate amount of compensation paid the participant divided by the participant's total period of credited service. Total amount of compensation may include eligible accumulated sick time as provided by the bargaining agreement in effect at time of retirement. 
D.  The age and service requirements for normal retirement are:

2.  Age fifty-five (55) with ten or more years of service. 
E.  Subject to the maximum benefit limitations as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is equal to the sum of (i) two percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service, to a maximum of twenty-five (25) years of credited service, plus, two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, and (ii) two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by credited service earned after July 1, 1978 to a maximum of seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. 
    Effective July 1, 1996 for the fire chief and subject to the maximum benefit limitation as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is equal to 2.8% of final average compensation multiplied by years of credited service, limited to a maximum seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. 
F.  The service requirement for vested termination of participation is ten or more years of credited service. 
G.  The service requirement for non-duty disability retirement is ten or more years of credited service. 
H.  The amount of a non-duty disability annuity pension shall be calculated in the same manner as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of non-duty disability retirement. 
I.  The amount of duty disability pension shall be calculated as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of duty disability retirement plus service credit for the period from the date of duty disability retirement to the date the participant would attain age fifty-five (55) years. The duty disability pension payable prior to attainment of age fifty-five (55) years under form of payment SL shall not be less than fifty (50) percent of final average compensation. The participant may request payment under one of the optional forms of payment specified in Section 2.100.300 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002)

    Effective July 1, 1996, subject to the maximum benefit limitation as set forth in Code Section 415, the amount of a normal retirement pension under form of payment option SL is equal to 2.8% of final average compensation multiplied by years of credited service, limited to a maximum seventy-five (75) percent of final average compensation. 
F.  The service requirement for vested termination of participation is ten or more years of credited service. 
G.  The service requirement for non-duty disability retirement is ten or more years of credited service. 
H.  The amount of a non-duty disability pension shall be calculated in the same manner as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of non-duty disability retirement. 
I.  The amount of duty disability pension shall be calculated as a normal retirement pension based on credited service as of the date of duty disability retirement plus service credit for the period from the date of duty disability retirement to the date the participant would attain age fifty-five (55) years. The duty disability pension payable prior to attainment of age fifty-five (55) years under form of payment SL shall not be less than fifty (50) percent of final average compensation. The participant may request payment under one of the optional forms of payment specified in Section 2.100.300 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.280 - Election of form of payment option. 
A.  The request for payment under another form of payment option must be made in writing on a form furnished by the board of trustee and filed with the retirement system administrator prior to the date the first pension payment is made under the standard form of payment and must designate the survivor pension beneficiary for benefit options under Section 2.100.300(A) through (F) of this chapter, or in the event benefit Option C120 under Section 2.100.300(H) of this chapter is elected, then a survivor pension beneficiary or beneficiaries may be designated. 
B.  A form of payment selection may not be changed after the date the first pension payment is made. A named survivor pension beneficiary may not be changed after the date the first pension payment is made. 
C.  Pension payments under each form of payment option provided by this section shall be actuarially equivalent to the standard form of payment, computed as of the effective date of retirement except where specifically stated otherwise. 
(Ord. 03-05 § 3 (part), 2005; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.290 - Standard form of payment. 
    The retired participant is paid a straight life pension for life under the standard form of payment. All payments to the retired participant stop upon payment for the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. If the participant died prior to receiving an aggregate amount of pension payments which is less than the participant's accumulated participant contributions, the difference between the amount of the participant's accumulated participant contributions and the aggregate amount of pension payments shall be paid to the participant's beneficiary. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.300 - Form of pension payment options. 
A.  Option one hundred (100) percent JS. The retired participant is paid the actuarial equivalent reduced pension for life under form of payment one hundred (100) percent JS. The last payment to the retired participant is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The named survivor pension beneficiary, if living on the first day of the month following the death of the retired participant, is then paid the same amount of pension for life. The first payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The last payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the survivor pension beneficiary. No payment is made to the survivor pension beneficiary if the death of the retired participant and the death of the survivor pension beneficiary occur in the same month. If the named survivor pension beneficiary dies prior to the retired participant there is no change in the amount payable to the retired participant. 
B.  Option fifty (50) percent JS. The retired participant is paid the actuarial equivalent reduced pension for life under form of payment fifty (50) percent JS. The last payment to the retired participant is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The named survivor pension beneficiary, if living on the first day of the month following the death of the retired participant, is then paid fifty (50) percent of the reduced pension for life. The first payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The last payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the survivor pension beneficiary. No payment is made to the survivor pension beneficiary if the death of the retired participant and the death of the survivor pension beneficiary occur in the same month. If the named survivor pension beneficiary dies prior to the retired participant there is no change in the amount payable to the retired participant. 
C.  Option seventy-five (75) percent JS. The retired participant is paid the reduced pension for life under form of payment option seventy-five (75) percent JS. The reduction is five percent and is not an actuarial equivalent reduction. The last payment to the retired participant is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The named survivor pension beneficiary, if living on the first day of the month following the death of the retired participant, is then paid seventy-five (75) percent of the reduced pension for life. The first payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The last payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the survivor pension beneficiary. No payment is made to the survivor pension beneficiary if the death of the retired participant and the death of the survivor pension beneficiary occur in the same month. 
D.  Option one hundred (100) percent JS - Pop-Up. The retired participant is paid the actuarial equivalent reduced pension for as long as the retired participant and the named survivor pension beneficiary are both alive under the form of payment option one hundred (100) percent JS - Pop-Up. The actuarial equivalent reduced pension is determined as if option one hundred (100) percent JS had been elected. The last payment to the retired participant is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The named survivor pension beneficiary, if living on the first day of the month following the death of the retired participant, is then paid the same amount of pension for life. The first payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The last payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the survivor pension beneficiary. No payment is made to the survivor pension beneficiary if the death of the retired participant and the death of the survivor pension beneficiary occur in the same month. If the named survivor pension beneficiary dies prior to the retired participant, the amount of the retired participant's pension shall change to the amount that would be payable had payment been made under the standard form of payment. The change in amount shall start with the payment for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the named survivor pension beneficiary. This Option D is available to participants of the firefighters coverage plan, patrol officers coverage plan, police command officers coverage plan, and police chief and fire chief coverage plan retiring after July 1, 1987, and general coverage plan participants of the Local 1917 Supervisor's Union, Local 998 Clerical Union and non-union employees retiring after July 1, 2000 and general coverage plan participants of the Michigan Association of Public Employees (M.A.P.E.) retiring on or after January 1, 2002. 
E.  Option fifty (50) percent JS - Pop-Up. The retired participant is paid the actuarial equivalent reduced pension for as long as the retired participant and the named survivor pension beneficiary are both alive under the form of payment option fifty (50) percent JS - Pop-Up. The actuarial equivalent reduced pension is determined as if option fifty (50) percent JS had been elected. The last payment to the retired participant is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The named survivor pension beneficiary, if living on the first day of the month following the death of the retired participant, is then paid fifty (50) percent of the reduced pension for life. The first payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The last payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the survivor pension beneficiary. No payment is made to the survivor pension beneficiary if the death of the retired participant and the death of the survivor pension beneficiary occur in the same month. If the named survivor pension beneficiary dies prior to the retired participant, the amount of the retired participant's pension shall change to the amount that would be payable had payment been made under the standard form of payment. The change in amount shall start with the payment for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the named survivor pension beneficiary. This Option E is available to participants of the firefighters coverage plan, patrol officers coverage plan, police command officers coverage plan, and police chief and fire chief coverage plan retiring after July 1, 1987, and general coverage plan participants of Local 1917 Supervisor's Union, Teamsters Local 214, Local 998 Clerical Union and non-union employees retiring after July 1, 2000 and general coverage plan participants of the Michigan Association of Public Employees (M.A.P.E.) retiring on or after January 1, 2002. 
F.  Option seventy-five (75) percent JS - Pop-Up. The retired participant is paid the actuarial equivalent reduced pension for as long as the retired participant and the named survivor pension beneficiary are both alive under the form of payment option seventy-five (75) percent JS - Pop-Up. The actuarial equivalent reduced pension is determined as if option seventy-five (75) percent JS had been elected. The last payment to the retired participant is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The named survivor pension beneficiary, if living on the first day of the month following the death of the retired participant, is then paid seventy-five (75) percent of the reduced pension for life. The first payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. The last payment to the survivor pension beneficiary is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the survivor pension beneficiary. No payment is made to the survivor pension beneficiary if the death of the retired participant and the death of the survivor pension beneficiary occur in the same month. If the named survivor pension beneficiary dies prior to the retired participant, the amount of the retired participant's pension shall change to the amount that would be payable had payment been made under the standard form of payment. The change in amount shall start with the payment for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the named survivor pension beneficiary. This Option F is available to participants of the firefighters coverage plan, patrol officers coverage plan, police command officers coverage plan, and police chief and fire chief coverage plan retiring after July 1, 1987, and general coverage plan participants of Local 1917 Supervisor's Union, Teamsters Local 214, Local 998 Clerical Union and non-union employees retiring after July 1, 2000 and general coverage plan participants of the Michigan Association of Public Employees (M.AP.E.) retiring on or after January 1, 2002. 
G.  Option LS. Under form of payment LS, the retired participant is paid a lump sum amount of the participant's choice equal to one of the following amounts of the retired participant's accumulated participant contributions: 
1.  One hundred (100) percent of participant's accumulated contributions (principal amount plus investment earnings); 
2.  Participant's accumulated contributions only; or 
3.  Investment earnings only. 
    This option is not available to general coverage plan participants. If a participant chooses form of payment LS, his straight life pension shall be reduced by the actuarial equivalent of the lump sum payment. The remaining amount of pension shall be paid in the standard form of payment (straight life) unless the participant chooses another form, as provided at Section 2.100.280 of this chapter. 
H.  Option C120. The retired participant is paid an actuarial equivalent reduced pension for life under form of payment Option C120. The last payment to the retired participant is the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. If less than one hundred twenty (120) monthly pension payments are made to the retired participant, payment shall be continued to the named survivor pension beneficiary or beneficiaries (including any contingent survivor pension beneficiary or beneficiaries after the death of the first named survivor pension beneficiary) until a total of one hundred twenty (120) monthly pension payments have been made. The first payment to a named survivor pension beneficiary is for the month following the month in which occurs the death of the retired participant. Payment of the pension shall be divided equally among living named survivor beneficiaries with simultaneous interests. Should the death of the retired participant and all named survivor beneficiaries occur before one hundred twenty (120) monthly pension payments are made, the remainder of the one hundred twenty (120) payments shall be converted to a lump sum using the applicable interest rate prescribed at Section 2.100.680 of this chapter and shall be paid to the estate of the last to survive of the retired participant and the named survivor beneficiaries. 
(Ord. 03-05 § 3 (part), 2005: Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.310 - Required distribution date. 
A.  Notwithstanding anything in the retirement ordinance to the contrary, distribution of a participant's benefits hereunder shall be made or commence to be paid not later than April 1 of the year following the year in which the later of the following occurs: 
1.  The participant attains age seventy and one-half (70 1/2); or 
2.  The participant retires. 
    The later of these events shall be the participant's "required distribution date." 
B.  Benefit payments, if not made in a lump sum, may only be made over one of the following periods (or a combination thereof): 
1.  The life of the participant; 
2.  The life of the participant and a designated beneficiary as that term is defined in Section 401(a)(9)(E) of the Code; 
3.  A period certain not extending beyond the life expectancy of the participant; or 
4.  A period certain not extending beyond the joint and last survivor expectancy of the participant and a designated beneficiary. 
    If the participant's entire interest is to be distributed in a manner other than a lump sum, then the amount to be distributed each year must be at least an amount equal to the quotient obtained by dividing the participant's entire interest by the life expectancy of the participant or joint and last survivor expectancy of the participant and designated beneficiary. Life expectancy and joint and last survivor expectancy are computed by the use of the return multiples contained in Treasury Regulation Section 1.72-9. For purposes of this computation, a participant's life or a participant's and spouse's expectancy may be recalculated no more frequently than annually; however, the life expectancy of a non-spouse beneficiary may not be recalculated. If the participant's spouse is not the designated beneficiary, the method of benefit payment selected must assure that at least fifty (50) percent of the present value of the amount available for distribution is paid within the life expectancy of the participant. Effective October 1, 2005, if the participant's spouse is not the designated beneficiary, the method of payment selected must assure that the periodic annuity payable to the designated beneficiary must not at any time on or after the participant's required beginning date, as defined in the applicable Treasury Regulations exceed the applicable percentage of the annuity payment payable to the participant using the table prescribed in the applicable provisions of Treasury Regulation 1.401(a)(9)-6. 
C.  Upon the death of a participant, the following benefit payment provisions shall apply: 
1.  If the participant dies after distribution of his interest has commenced, the remaining portion of such interest will continue to be distributed at least as rapidly as under the method of distribution being used prior to the participant's death. 
2.  If the participant dies before distribution of his interest commences, the participant's entire interest will be distributed by December 31 of the calendar year containing the fifth anniversary of the participant's death except to the extent that an election is made to receive distributions in accordance with: 
a.  If any portion of the participant's interest is payable to a designated beneficiary, distributions may be made in substantially equal installments over the life or life expectancy of the designated beneficiary commencing on or before December 31 of the calendar year immediately following the calendar year in which the participant's death occurs; or 
b.  If the designated beneficiary is the participant's surviving spouse, the date distributions are required to begin in accordance with subsection (C)(1) of this section shall not be earlier than the December 31 of the calendar year in which the participant would have attained age seventy and one-half (70 1/2), and if the spouse dies before payments begin, subsequent distributions shall be made as if the spouse had been the participant. 
3.  For purposes of subsection (C)(2) of this section, payments will be calculated by use of the return multiples specified in Treasury Regulation Section 1.72-9. Life expectancy of a surviving spouse may be recalculated annually, however, in the case of any other designated beneficiary, such life expectancy will be calculated at the time payment first commences without further recalculation. 
4.  For purposes of subsections (C)(1), (C)(2), and (C)(3) of this section any amount paid to a child of the participant will be treated as if it had been paid to the surviving spouse if the amount becomes payable to the surviving spouse when the child reaches the age of majority. 
(Ord. 02-06 § 3, 2006; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.320 - Pre-retirement survivor pension to survivor pension beneficiary-Automatic designation of spouse. 
A.  A pension shall be paid to the survivor pension beneficiary of a deceased participant who dies before receiving any benefits under this retirement ordinance if all of the following requirements are met: 
1.  The participant, at time of death, had fifteen (15) or more years of credited service or was age fifty-five (55) years or older and had ten or more years of credited service; and 
2.  The designated survivor pension beneficiary files written application on a form prescribed by the board of trustees for the pension with the retirement system administrator. 
    The age and service requirement is waived for participants of the firefighters and patrol officers coverage plans if the board of trustees finds the participant's death to have been the result of a personal injury or disease arising out of and in the course of the deceased participant's performance of duty in the employ of the city. 
B.  The amount of pension is the deceased participant's normal retirement pension computed in the same manner as if the participant had (a) retired the day preceding the date of death, notwithstanding that the participant might not have satisfied the age and service requirements for retirement as specified in the applicable coverage plan; and (b) elected form of payment option one hundred (100) percent JS with the spouse or children of the deceased participant as determined under subsection D of this section as the survivor pension beneficiary. For participants of the firefighters coverage plan, patrol officers coverage plan, and the fire chief, the amount of the pension is based on service credit the deceased participant would have earned had the participant lived to age fifty-five (55). 
C.  Payment of the pension shall commence the first day of the month following the month in which written application on a form prescribed by the board of trustees is filed with the retirement system administrator. The last pension payment shall be the payment for the month in which occurs the death of the named beneficiary. 
D.  A participant may designate a survivor pension beneficiary on a form prescribed by the board of trustees, and filed with the retirement system administrator at any time. A participant may revoke such designation at any time by filing a new designation. The most recent designation received by the retirement system administrator before the participant's death shall be deemed to revoke all prior designations. A participant who is married at time of death shall be presumed to have designated the spouse as beneficiary if no valid written designation is on file with the retirement system administrator. In the event no spouse survives the participant, this benefit shall be paid to the participant's natural born or legally adopted children ("child" or "children") as follows: 
    The age of the youngest child on the participant's date of death shall be used as the measuring life for the Pre-Retirement Survivor Pension ("PRSB"). The PRSB as so calculated shall be converted to an actuarial equivalent lump sum pursuant to Section 2.100.680 of this chapter. The resulting lump sump shall be divided equally among surviving children (if more than one child survives) or paid to the surviving child (or in either case, paid to a conservator or other proper legal representative for any child who has not reached age eighteen (18) as of the date of payment. 
    If the deceased participant is not survived by a spouse or child, no PRSB is payable. 
E.  A participant's beneficiary may elect to withdraw the participant's accumulated participant contributions in a lump sum in lieu of the pre-retirement survivor pension described above in this section. Such election must be made in writing, on a form prescribed by the board of trustees, filed with the retirement system administrator prior to the commencement of the pre-retirement survivor pension. 
(Ord. 03-05 § 3 (part), 2005: Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.330 - Disability benefit and OASDI-Amount of disability benefit. 
    The amount of a disability pension payable before consideration of an option election or a surviving beneficiary pension payable pursuant to Section 2.100.320 of this chapter shall not exceed the difference between eighty (80) percent of the disabled or deceased participant's final average compensation and benefits from the Federal Social Security Old-Age Survivors, and Disability Insurance System on account of such disability or death. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.340 - Residual benefits-Refund upon termination of participation. 
    The accumulated participant contributions of a vested former participant, former participant or a participant on leave of absence from the city as a consequence of the entry into active duty with the Armed Forces of the United States shall be paid to the individual upon written request on a form prescribed by the board of trustees and filed with the retirement system administrator. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.350 - Residual benefits-Refund upon death and no pension is payable. 
    If a participant, vested former participant or former participant dies prior to retirement and no pension is or will be paid, the deceased's unexpended accumulated participant contributions shall be paid to the participant's beneficiary. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.360 - Participant contributions-Deduction from salary. 
    The city shall cause the participant contributions specified by the coverage plan applicable to a participant to be deducted from the compensation of the participant. The city shall remit the deducted participant contributions to the retirement system within five working days. Each participant shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made and provided for in this section by continuing employment with the city. A participant receiving workers' compensation wage loss benefits shall make any necessary arrangements to accomplish the deductions called for by Sections 2.100.360, 2.100.370, and by the coverage plan applicable to the participant. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.370 - City pick-up of participant contributions. 
    Prior to the first paychecks issued in 1999, participant contributions were made on an after-tax basis. 
    Effective with the first paychecks issued in 1999, the city shall pick up the participant contributions for non-union employee participants, and participants in the Supervisors' Local 1917, Clerical Chapter 998, MAPE, Teamsters Local 214 and Firefighters union groups for all compensation earned after that date. The contributions so picked up shall be treated as city contributions in determining participants' tax treatment under the code. The city shall pick up the participant contributions from funds established and available for participant salaries, which funds would otherwise have been designated as participant contributions and paid to the pension fund. In no event shall a participant have a right to receive the participant contribution in cash in lieu of having such monies contributed to the plan. Participant contributions picked up by the city pursuant to this subsection shall be treated for all other purposes of this and other laws of the city in the same manner and to the same extent as participant contributions made prior to the effective date of this subsection. The participant contributions so picked up shall not be included in gross income for tax purposes until such time as they are distributed by refund or benefit payment. 
(Ord. 04-04 § 3 (part), 2004: Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002) 
2.100.380 - Investment earnings credited accumulated participant contributions. 
    The board of trustees shall, not less often than once each plan year, credit investment earnings to each participant's account in the participant contribution fund. The board of trustees shall determine the rate of investment earnings to be credited for the plan year. If a pension becomes payable, the applicable accumulated participant contributions shall be transferred to the pension reserve fund, whereupon the accumulated participant contributions shall no longer share in investment earnings. A participant's accumulated participant contributions shall continue to share in investment earnings so long as they remain in the participant contribution fund. If (a) a participant's accumulated participant contributions are transferred to the pension reserve fund or paid to a former participant or beneficiary prior to the crediting of investment earnings for the entire period ending on the date of such transfer, or (b) if a participant first establishes an account in the participant contribution fund after the first day of an investment crediting period, such payee shall receive a portion of the investment earnings for the investment crediting period including the date of such transfer (or date of account establishment, as the case may be) based on the ratio of (c) the number of days during the crediting period that the participant maintained an account, to (d) the number of days in the crediting period. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.390 - Remittance of city contributions. 
    The city shall remit its contributions to the retirement system for a fiscal year no later than the last day of the fiscal year. City contributions shall be credited to the pension reserve fund as set forth in Section 2.100.440 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.400 - Funding objective-Level cost funding. 
    The funding objective for the retirement system is to establish and receive during each fiscal year city contributions which are sufficient to (a) cover the actuarial cost of benefits likely to be paid allocated to the current fiscal year, as determined by the actuarial cost method (the normal cost); and (b) amortize the unfunded actuarial cost of benefits likely to be paid allocated to prior fiscal years, as determined by the actuarial cost method (unfunded actuarial accrued liability), over a period of years determined by the board of trustees, but not to exceed forty (40) years. 
    Effective July 1, 2006, the forty (40) year maximum amortization period referenced in this section shall be reduced to an amortization period not to exceed thirty (30) years. 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.410 - Actuarial valuations. 
    City contributions shall be determined by an annual actuarial valuation using an actuarial cost method, interest, mortality and other experience assumptions that meet the standards of the Actuarial Standards Board/American Academy of Actuaries. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.420 - Appropriation required. 
    The city shall appropriate and cause the contribution to be paid to the retirement system. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.430 - Mandatory accounting funds. 
    The mandatory accounting funds of the retirement system are the "pension reserve fund" and the "participant contribution fund" and the "health benefit fund." The board of trustees may establish such additional funds and accounts as it deems appropriate or as are required for compliance with applicable laws and accounting standards. The maintenance of separate accounting funds and accounts shall not require the actual segregation of the assets of the retirement system among the accounting funds and accounts. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.440 - Pension reserve fund. 
A.  The "pension reserve fund" is the accounting fund which shall be credited with contributions by the city, transfers of accumulated participant contributions from the participant contribution fund as provided in this retirement ordinance, participant contributions for service purchased under Section 2.100.080 of this chapter, investment earnings of the retirement system not specifically allocated to the fund; and which shall be charged with pension payments, following transfers of accumulated participant contributions, residual refunds of accumulated participant contributions of deceased retired participants, expenses incurred in the operation of the retirement system and investment earnings allocated to the participant contribution fund and not credited directly to the fund. If a disability pension is terminated for a reason other than the death of the retired participant before an amount equal to the retired participant's accumulated participant contributions has been paid, and the retired participant returns to employment with the city, the unexpended balance of the accumulated participant contributions shall be transferred from the pension reserve fund to the former retired participant's contribution account. 
B.  If the disability pension is terminated for a reason other than the death of the retired participant before an amount equal to the retired participant's accumulated participant contributions has been paid, the retired participant does not return to employment with the city, and the participant lacks sufficient credited service to qualify for an age and service retirement, the unexpended balance of the accumulated participant contributions shall automatically be distributed to the participant. 
C.  If the disability pension is terminated for a reason other than the death of the retired participant before an amount equal to the retired participant's accumulated participant contributions has been paid, the retired participant does not return to employment with the city, and the participant has sufficient credited service to qualify for an age and service retirement, the participant shall have the option of electing one of the following: 
1.  The participant may elect to withdraw the unexpended balance of his accumulated participant contributions, which shall result in the forfeiture of credited services as described in Section 2.100.160. 
2.  The participant may elect to leave the unexpended balance of his accumulated participant contributions in the plan, in which case the participant shall be treated as a vested former participant eligible for a pension under Section 2.100.140. In the event a participant fails to make an election under this section, the unexpended balance of his accumulated participant contributions shall remain in the retirement system and the participant shall be treated as a vested former participant eligible for a pension under Section 2.100.140. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.450 - Participant contribution fund. 
    The participant contribution fund is the accounting fund which shall be credited with participant contributions, repayments of accumulated participant contributions including any applicable interest charges, any investment earnings allocated to the participant contribution fund; and which shall be charged with refunds and transfers of accumulated participant contributions as provided in this chapter including the single payment under form of payment option LS. A participant's or vested former participant's accumulated participant contributions shall be transferred to the pension reserve fund if a pension becomes payable upon the retirement or death of the participant or vested former participant. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.460 - Health benefit fund. 
    The health benefit fund is the accounting fund which shall be credited with (a) contributions by the city for the purpose of funding all or a portion of the cost of providing health insurance coverage to eligible retired participants and eligible survivor pension beneficiaries, and (b) investment experience allocated to the health benefit fund, and which shall be charged with all, or a portion of, applicable premiums or contract charges for such coverage. Eligibility for coverage and the portion of the premium or contract charge to be paid from the health benefit fund shall be as determined in accordance with Section 2.100.810. Except as provided at Section 2.100.460A, contributions to the health benefit fund by the city, when added to any city contributions for life insurance protection provided by the retirement system, shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the total actual contributions to the retirement system (other than contributions to fund past service) after the later of the adoption or effective date of the health benefit fund and shall be reasonable and ascertainable. Amounts allocated to the health benefit fund may only be used for retiree health benefits described in Section 2.100.810 and in the city of Hazel Park retiree health benefit plan, and may not be used for any purpose other than providing such retiree health benefits or until the satisfaction of all liabilities under Section 2.100.810, at which time any amount remaining in the health benefit fund shall be returned to the city. Amounts in the health benefit fund shall be allocated to separate 401(h) subaccounts which shall be established for any key employee (as defined in Code Section 416(i)(1)) of the city, and benefits may be paid only from such key employee's subaccount. The city shall not contribute any amounts to the health benefit fund or a welfare benefit fund (as defined in Code Section 419(e)(1)) with respect to qualified current retiree health liabilities as defined in Code Section 420(e)(1)(A) for which transferred assets are required to be used as described in subsection (A)(3) of Section 2.100.460A of this chapter. 
(Ord. 04-04 § 3 (part), 2004: Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 14-00 (part), 2000: Ord. 865 (part), 1994)) 
2.100.460A - Code Section 420 transfer of excess assets to the health benefit fund. 
A.  In addition to contributions made directly by the city under Section 2.100.460, the health benefit fund may be funded by a "qualified transfer" of "excess assets" of the retirement system to the health benefit fund. "Excess assets" means the excess (if any) of the retirement system's assets (determined as the lesser of actual market value or actuarial value determined in accordance with Code Section 412(c)(2)) over the greater of the (i) full funding limit; or (ii) one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the retirement system's current liability (as described in Code Section 412(c)(7)(B). The "qualified transfer" of assets does not otherwise count against the limits on city contributions described in Section 2.100.460 to the health benefit fund. The "qualified transfer" of excess assets is subject to the requirements described below: 
1.  Limitation on Number of Qualified Transfers Per Taxable Year. No more than one transfer of excess assets under this section during a taxable year of the city; provided that in no event shall any such "qualified transfer" be made after December 31, 2005. 
2.  Limit on Amount of Transfer. The amount of excess assets transferred from the retirement system to the health care fund shall not exceed the amount reasonably estimated to be paid during the tax year of the transfer for "qualified current retiree health liabilities" as defined in Code Section 420(e)(1)(A). The amount to be transferred shall be reduced by the ratio of (i) assets (as of June 30 preceding the plan year of the transfer) previously set aside to pay for the qualified current retiree health liabilities (as defined in Code Section 420(e)(1)(B)(i)), to pay for the qualified current retiree health liabilities, to (ii) the present value of the qualified current retiree health liabilities for all plan years (as defined in Code Section 420(e)(1)(B)(ii)). In the event the amount transferred exceeds the amount used to pay qualified current retiree health liabilities, the excess (including income thereon) shall be returned from the health benefit fund to the retirement system. 
3.  Use of Transferred Assets. Any assets (and any income allocable thereto) of the retirement system transferred to the health benefit fund shall be used only to pay reasonably estimated current retiree health liabilities (other than liabilities of key employees not taken into account under Section 420(e)(1)(D)) for the taxable year of the transfer. For purposes of this section, any amount paid out of the health benefits fund shall be treated as first being paid out of excess assets transferred to the health benefit fund pursuant to this section and income thereon. 
4.  Accelerated Vesting Requirement. 
(a)  An employee who is a participant in the retirement system on the date of the transfer shall be one hundred (100) percent vested on the date of the qualified transfer in his then currently accrued benefit in the retirement system, in the same manner as if the plan had terminated immediately before the qualified transfer. 
(b)  A participant who separated from service at the city during the one-year period ending on the date of the qualified transfer shall be one hundred (100) percent vested in his then currently accrued benefit as if the plan had terminated immediately before his separation from service. 
    A participant who vests in an accrued benefit under this Section 2.100.460A(4) shall nonetheless be subject to the vesting requirements of the applicable coverage plan at Section 2.100.230, 2.100.240, 2.100.250, or 2.100.260 with respect to future benefit accruals in the retirement system. In the case of a participant who becomes vested pursuant to Section 2.100.460A for (b) above, which participant has been paid his accumulated participant contributions and has accordingly forfeited his credited service, such participant shall have his accrued benefit based upon his previously forfeited credited service retroactively reinstated and vested, provided that the vested accrued benefits so reinstated and vested shall be reduced by the actuarial equivalent of his accumulated participant contributions previously paid to him. 
5.  Maintenance of Applicable Employer Retiree Health Costs. As more fully set forth at Section 2.100.940A of the city of Hazel Park retiree health benefits plan, in the event of a qualified transfer, the city shall maintain levels of applicable employer retiree health costs during the cost maintenance period, as such terms are defined in Section 2.100.940A of the city of Hazel Park retiree health benefits plan. 
6.  Key Employees Excluded. Assets transferred to the health benefits fund cannot be used to pay the retiree health benefits of any participant who was a key employee (within the meaning of Code Section 416(i)(11)) at any time during the plan year ending within the tax year of the city in which the qualified transfer was made. If an employee is a key employee with respect to any plan year, such employee shall not be taken into account in computing qualified current retiree health liabilities for such taxable year, or in calculating applicable employer retiree health costs during the cost maintenance period as such terms are defined in Section 2.100.940A of the city of Hazel Park retiree health benefit plan. 
7.  Limitation of city deductions. The city shall not be entitled to a deduction for amounts transferred to the health benefit fund or where amounts are used from the health benefit fund to pay retiree health benefits which otherwise would have been deductible in a tax year had the expenses been paid directly by the city. 
B.  State law limitations. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this chapter, excess amounts transferred under Section 2.100.460A(2), "Limit on Amount of Transfer" shall not exceed state law limitations as set forth in Michigan Compiled Laws Annotation (MCLA) 38.571 which section is incorporated by reference in this retirement plan. 
(Ord. 04-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 14-00 (part), 2000) 
2.100.460B - Cashouts of accelerated vested accrued benefit pursuant to a Code Section 420 transfer under Section 2.100.460A or pursuant to the Reciprocal Retirement Act. 
A.  This section shall only apply to a participant who becomes vested in his accrued benefit: 
1.  Pursuant to a qualified transfer under Section 2.100.460A; or 
2.  By reason of the Reciprocal Retirement Act. 
    This section shall not apply to any participant who completes ten years of credited service with the city. 
B.  Upon termination of such a participant's employment, the following shall apply: 
1.  Involuntary Cashout. If the present value of the vested normal retirement pension of a participant described in subsection A of this section is seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) or less, then the retirement system administrator shall pay an immediate lump sum distribution of the greater of: 
(a)  The present value of such participant's vested normal retirement pension; or 
(b)  His accumulated participant contributions, and such participant's credited service and all rights to any further benefits of the retirement system shall be forfeited. With respect to distributions under this subsection made on or after January 1, 2006, the seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) threshold for a mandatory distribution is reduced to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
2.  Voluntary Cashout. If the present value of the vested normal retirement pension of a participant described in subsection A of this section is more than seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) and less than or equal to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), then such participant may elect to receive his benefits in an immediate lump sum distribution. In such event, the retirement system administrator shall pay an immediate lump sum distribution of the greater of: 
(a)  The present value of such participant's vested normal retirement pension; or 
(b)  His accumulated participant contributions, and such participant's credited service and all rights to any further benefits of the retirement system shall be forfeited. 
(c)  With respect to a voluntary cashout distribution under this subsection on or after January 1, 2006, the minimum threshold amount of seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) is reduced to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
    If such participant elects not to receive an immediate lump sum distribution, he shall be treated as a vested former participant entitled to a deferred pension in accordance with Sections 2.100.140 and 2.100.150. 
3.  Other Participants. If the present value the vested normal retirement pension of a participant described in subsection A of this section is more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), such participant shall be treated as a vested former participant entitled to withdraw his accumulated participant contributions in accordance with Section 2.100.160 or to receive a deferred pension in accordance with Sections 2.100.140 and 2.100.150. 
4.  Present Value. For purposes of the foregoing, present value shall be calculated using the interest rate for actuarial equivalencies described in Section 2.100.680, and shall be determined on the later of (i) the date of distribution or (ii) the date of a qualified transfer under Section 2.100.460A. 
5.  Service Upon Reemployment. If a vested participant who received a distribution pursuant to this section is reemployed by the city, his years of credited service for vesting shall be reinstated. The credited service which related to the distribution shall not be reinstated unless he repays to the plan the benefit he received together with interest at a rate of 7.25% from the date of payment to him to the date of repayment to the retirement system. Repayments under subsection (B)(3) of this section shall be made in accordance with Section 2.100.100. 
    If a vested participant who received a distribution pursuant to this section becomes employed by another governmental employer, his years of credited service for purposes of the Reciprocal Retirement Act shall be reinstated if he repays to the retirement system the benefit he received, together with interest at a rate of 7.25% from the date of payment to him to the date of repayment to the retirement system. Repayments under subsection (B)(3) of this section shall be made in accordance with Section 2.100.100. 
6.  Timing. All cashout distributions made pursuant to this section shall be made as soon as administratively feasible following the later of: 
(a)  The participant's termination of employment; or 
(b)  The date of a qualified transfer under Section 2.100.460A. 
(Ord. 07-05 § 3 (part), 2005; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 14-00 (part), 2000) 
2.100.460C - Vested termination of participation-Forfeiture of vested pension. 
    A vested former participant may elect to be paid accumulated participant contributions at any time after termination of employment and before commencement of his pension benefits, which election and payment shall result in forfeiture of credited service and all rights to any benefits of the retirement system other than payment of the accumulated participant contributions. Such election must be made in writing, on a form prescribed by the board of trustees, filed with the retirement system administrator prior to the commencement of pension benefits. 
    Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this section, a participant who becomes vested in all or part of his accrued benefit pursuant to a qualified transfer under Section 2.100.460A, who does not receive a cashout pursuant to Section 2.100.460B, shall be entitled to a pension from the retirement system subject to all other terms and conditions of the retirement plan. If such participant withdrew his accumulated participant contributions, the amount of his pension shall be determined by subtracting the actuarial equivalent of his accumulated participant contributions from his accrued benefit. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002) 
2.100.470 - Board of trustees-General function. 
A.  The operation of the retirement system shall be carried out by the board of trustees. As further enumerated in this chapter, the board of trustees shall have the following general powers and duties: 
1.  Retirement Ordinance Design. The board of trustees shall be responsible for the proposal and initiation of changes to the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, resulting from collective bargaining agreements, changes in applicable laws or regulations, or for any other reason deemed appropriate by the board. However, it is recognized that the retirement system is maintained pursuant to ordinance of the city of Hazel Park, and accordingly design changes in the retirement system must ultimately be adopted by the Hazel Park city council. 
2.  Administration. The board shall be responsible for the day-to-day operation of the retirement system. 
3.  Asset Management and Investment. The board shall constitute the trustees of the trust fund which holds the assets of the retirement system. Assets of the trust fund are separate from the assets of the city, and shall not be commingled with city assets. 
B.  The board shall also have the powers enumerated in this chapter with respect to post-employment benefits other than pensions which are provided to qualifying retired participants, their spouses, beneficiaries, dependents, or other persons as the case may be. Any such non-pension retiree benefits shall be the subject of separate welfare plan documents, provided that to the extent the benefits under any such separate welfare plans are funded through accounts maintained within or pursuant to the retirement system, such accounts shall be described in the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.480 - Retirement ordinance design. 
    Since the retirement system is maintained pursuant to an ordinance of the city, the city council of Hazel Park shall have the sole and final authority to adopt amendments to the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter.
