However, it is recognized that the board maintains an expertise in the retirement system, and is most involved in its operations. Accordingly, it shall be the duty of the board to propose amendments to the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter for any reason the board deems proper, including but not limited to changes in any applicable law or regulation, or collective bargaining. It is recognized that collective bargaining agreements constitute enforceable contracts between the city and the collective bargaining agents, however it shall be the board's function to propose appropriate modifications to the retirement system in order to implement collectively-bargained changes, provided that the city council shall have the sole authority to adopt such changes. It is recognized that in the course of administering the retirement system, the board is authorized to adopt rules, procedures and forms. Provided that these things do not contravene the provisions of the retirement ordinance, as codified, they shall be binding on all affected parties. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.490 - Retirement system administration. 
    The general administration of the retirement system shall be placed in the board of trustees. The board shall have exclusive authority to control and manage the operation and administration of the retirement system. The board and any fiduciary under this chapter may serve in more than one fiduciary capacity under the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter and may employ legal counsel, accountants, consultants, advisors and investment managers, and may delegate administrative functions to any person or persons. The decision of the board upon any questions of fact, interpretation, definition or administration under the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter shall be final, binding and conclusive, but shall be made in a nondiscriminatory manner. The regularly kept records of the board shall be conclusive and binding upon all persons with respect to the employees' credited service, date and length of employment, time and amount of compensation and the manner of payment thereof, type and length of any absence from work and all other matters contained therein relating to employment. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.500 - Powers and duties. 
    The board of trustees in administering the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter shall have all the powers necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter including, in addition to any specific powers provided for in the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the power: 
A.  To administer the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter so as not to discriminate in favor of highly compensated participants; 
B.  To administer oaths; 
C.  To create and maintain records; 
D.  To make and adopt such reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary or convenient to carry out the duties of the board and activities of the retirement system, including any rules and regulations necessary to preserve the status of the retirement system as a qualified pension plan under the provisions of the code, or under successor or related provisions of law; 
E.  To adopt such interest and mortality tables as may be necessary for the administration of the retirement system; 
F.  To designate committees and to designate committee members, including individuals who may not be participants in the retirement system; 
G.  To employ such personal and other services as are necessary to comply with the provisions of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter; 
H.  To pay the expenses of operating the retirement system from the current or accumulated income of the trust fund of the retirement system, to the extent such expenses are not paid directly by the city; 
I.  To interpret the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter and determine all questions arising in the administration, interpretation, and application of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, including but not limited to, questions of eligibility and the status and rights of participants, beneficiaries and other persons. Any such determination by the board of trustees shall be conclusive and binding on all parties claiming benefits under the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter. The records of the city shall be conclusive and binding upon all persons with respect to an employee's credited service, date and length of employment, time and amount of compensation and the manner of payment thereof, type and length of any absence from work and all other matters contained therein relating to employees. All rules and determinations of the board of trustees shall be uniformly and consistently applied to all persons in similar circumstances; and 
J.  To correct any defect, supply any omissions or reconcile any inconsistencies in the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, such action to be conclusive and binding on all persons claiming benefits under the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.510 - Claim procedure. 
    Claims for benefits under the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter shall be made in writing to the board. In the event a claim for benefits is wholly or partially denied by the board, the board shall, within a reasonable period of time, but not later than ninety (90) days after receipt of the claim, notify the claimant in writing of the denial of the claim. If the claimant shall not be notified in writing of the denial of the claim within ninety (90) days after it is received by the board, the claim shall be deemed denied. A notice of denial shall be written in a manner calculated to be understood by the claimant, and shall contain (i) the specific reason or reasons for denial of the claim, (ii) a specific reference to the pertinent retirement ordinance provisions upon which the denial is based, (iii) a description of any additional material or information necessary for the claimant to perfect the claim, together with an explanation of why such material or information is necessary, and (iv) an explanation of the retirement ordinance's review procedure. Within sixty (60) days of the receipt by the claimant of the written notice of denial of the claim, or within sixty (60) days after the claim is denied as set forth above, if applicable, the claimant may file a written request with the board that it conduct a full and fair review of the denial of the claimant's claim for benefits, including the conducting of a hearing, if deemed necessary by the board. In connection with the claimant's appeal of the denial of his benefit, the claimant may review pertinent documents and may submit issues and comments in writing. The board of trustees shall render a decision on the claim appeal promptly, but not later than sixty (60) days after the receipt of the claimant's request for review, unless special circumstances (such as the need to hold a hearing, if necessary), require an extension of time for processing, in which case the sixty (60) days prior may be extended to one hundred and twenty (120) days. The board shall notify the claimant in writing of any such extension. The decision upon review shall (i) include specific reasons for the decision, (ii) be written in a manner calculated to be understood by the claimant and (iii) contain specific references to the pertinent retirement ordinance provisions upon which the decision is based. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.520 - Board-Indemnity of board of trustees in administering the retirement ordinance. 
    The city shall indemnity and defend each member of the board and each of its other employees against any and all claims, loss, damages, expenses (including reasonable attorneys fees), and liability arising in connection with the administration of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, except when the same is judicially determined to be due to the gross negligence or wilful misconduct of such member or other employee. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.530 - Board-Asset management and investment. 
    The board shall serve as trustee of the trust fund, which funds the benefits under the retirement system. The board's powers and duties in this regard are more fully described in this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.540 - Board-Composition. 
    The board of trustees shall consist of the following ten individuals: 
A.  The mayor of the city of Hazel Park; 
B.  The city manager; 
C.  Two members of the city council to be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the city council; 
D.  Five participants of the retirement system designated as follows: 
1.  One participant of the general coverage plan who is not a member of a union having a contract with the city, to be elected by such participants of the general coverage plan, 
2.  One participant of the general coverage plan who is a member of a union having a contract with the city (other than a union representing 43rd district court employees), to be elected by such participants of the general coverage plan, 
3.  One participant of the general coverage plan who is a member of a union representing 43rd district court employees having a contract with the city, to be elected by such participants of the general coverage plan, 
4.  One participant of the patrol officers, police command officers, or police chief coverage plan, to be elected by participants of such coverage plans, and 
5.  One participant of the firefighters coverage plan or fire chief coverage plan, to be elected by participants of such coverage plans; 
E.  One member of the Hazel Park association of retired city employees, to be elected by that association, and who shall sit as a nonvoting ex officio trustee. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 898, 1997: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.550 - Board-Term of office-Elections. 
A.  The regular term of office of a trustee shall be four years. A trustee shall take office immediately following his or her qualification. Trustees holding office on the effective date of the restated retirement ordinance codified in this chapter shall continue in office for the balance of their term or until replaced as provided in the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter. 
B.  Subject to Section 2.100.560, elections of participant elected trustees shall be held in the month of November. The board of trustees shall make rules and provisions for the elections. 
C.  A trustee shall qualify for office by taking an oath of office for faithful performance of the duties of trustee. The oath of office shall be administered by the city clerk. 
D.  A participant trustee who retires during the course of his regular term may, subject to the provisions of Section 2.100.570, continue in office for the balance of his regular term of office. However, upon completion of the term of office, he shall no longer be eligible for election as a participant trustee. The vacancy created by the participant trustee's departure shall be filled pursuant to provisions described at Section 2.100.560. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.560 - Board-Vacancies. 
    A vacancy in the office of trustee shall be filled within thirty (30) days of the date of the vacancy, for the unexpired term, in the same manner as the position was previously filled. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.570 - Board-Meetings-Quorum-Removal from office. 
A.  All meetings shall be held in accordance with the Michigan Open Meetings Act, M.C.L.A. Section 15.261 et seq., which act is incorporated by reference in this chapter. 
B.  The board of trustees shall hold monthly meetings and shall designate the date, time and place thereof by posted written notice. All meetings of the board of trustees shall be public. The board of trustees shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a written record of its proceedings. 
C.  Four trustees authorized to vote shall constitute a quorum. Four concurring votes are required for a decision of the board of trustees. Effective November 7, 2000, the number of voting trustees required for a quorum shall be increased from four to five, and the number of concurring votes required for a decision of the board of trustees is increased from four to five. 
D.  A trustee shall be removed from office if the trustee is recalled by recall election by his or her membership defined at Section 2.100.540-3. prior to his or her expiration of term. (City Council may similarly remove and replace the Trustees designated pursuant to Section 2.100.540-1. or 2.) If, by reason of a change in employment status other than retirement, a participant trustee during a term of office is no longer employed in a position within the coverage groups he or she was elected to represent, such participant trustee shall be deemed to have resigned from the pension board effective immediately at the time the participant trustee's employment status officially changes. The vacancy in the office of trustee created by the deemed resignation shall be filled in accordance with the procedures set forth at Section 2.100.560. At the request of the city, upon removal or resignation of any trustee, such trustee shall file with the city a final account. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 16-00, 2000; Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.580 - Board-Expenses of office. 
    Members of the board of trustees shall serve without additional compensation for their services as trustees. They shall be reimbursed for necessary, reasonable and proper expenses, and participant members shall suffer no loss of compensation in fulfilling their duties as a trustee. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.590 - Board-Right to employ agents and counsel. 
    The board of trustees may employ such providers of services as it requires for the proper performance of its duties. The board of trustees may pay reasonable compensation for those services from the current or accumulated income of the trust fund. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.600 - Board-Miscellaneous. 
    The board of trustees shall elect from its membership a chairperson and a vice-chairperson. The city clerk shall be the secretary of the board of trustees. The city treasurer shall be the treasurer of the retirement system. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.610 - Investment of funds-Michigan law applies-Prudent investor rule. 
A.  The board of trustees of the retirement system may invest and reinvest the assets of the retirement system trust fund subject to the terms, conditions, limitations and restrictions imposed by the provisions of P.A. 165. No. 314, as amended, being Section 38.1132 et seq. of Michigan Compiled Laws Annotated (the "Investment Funds of Public Employee Retirement Systems Act"), or any superseding law regulating the same subject matter. 
B.  In exercising its discretionary authority with respect to the management of the money and other assets of the trust fund, the board of trustees shall exercise the care, skill, prudence, and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing, that a prudent person, acting in a similar capacity and familiar with those matters, would use in the conduct of a similar enterprise with similar aims. 
C.  The trustee shall have the right, subject to the approval of the board in their role as administrator of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, to employ suitable agents and counsel, and to pay their reasonable compensation and expenses. The trustee shall not be liable for any neglect, omission or wrongdoing of any such agent or counsel, and shall not be deemed imprudent by reason of its acting or refraining from acting in reliance on advice of counsel, provided that reasonable care shall have been exercised in selecting such agent or counsel for such employment. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.620 - Indemnification of trustees. 
    The city shall indemnify and defend each person acting as trustee against any and all claims, loss, damages, expenses (including reasonable attorneys fees), and liability arising in connection with the administration of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, except when the same is judicially determined to be due to the gross negligence or wilful misconduct of such person. If there exists insurance coverage which covers the subject matter of this indemnity by the city, such insurance shall be primary and the city's obligation to indemnify shall be secondary to such insurance, and shall be in the nature of excess coverage for any claims covered by such insurance. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.630 - Rights of trustee. 
    In the event of the appointment or election of a new trustee, such trustee will succeed the former trustee as of the date of taking his or her oath of office to all the rights, title and estate of the succeeded trustee, and no instrument of transfer, conveyance or assignment or order of any court shall be necessary in connection therewith. Notwithstanding the foregoing, however, the succeeded trustee shall deliver to the successor trustee such instruments of transfer, conveyance, assignment and further assurance as he or she may reasonably require. No successor trustee shall be personally liable for any act or omission which occurred prior to the time the successor became a trustee. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.640 - Custodian of assets. 
A.  The city treasurer shall be the custodian of the assets of the retirement system unless the board of trustees designates a corporate custodian. To be eligible for designation, a corporate custodian shall be a federal or state licensed bank, a clearing corporation, or a trust company. 
B.  As custodian of all of the assets and funds of this trust, the city treasurer (or corporate custodian, as the case may be) shall accept and receive all sums of money paid to it from time to time by the city pursuant to the terms of this retirement ordinance, and shall hold and administer those monies and the increment earnings and income thereof as the trust fund for the exclusive benefit of participants and their beneficiaries. 
C.  All payments by the retirement system shall be authorized in advance by a specific or continuing resolution of the board of trustees. 
D.  Effective July 1, 2002, the board of trustees established a trust disbursing account under the exclusive control of the board of trustees. Such account was, and shall continue to be, an account with checkwriting privileges and maintained at a state or federally chartered bank, a clearing corporation, or a trust company. At least two authorized signatures shall be required for any disbursements from the disbursing account. Such authorized signers shall be the chairperson and vice chairperson of the board of trustees, the city manager (in his or her capacity as a trustee), and one other trustee, to be designated from time to time. Effective July 1, 2002, all contributions to the retirement system (under Section 2.100.360 or 2.100.390), and any other amounts to be received by the retirement system, and any disbursements from the retirement system, shall be made directly to or from the trust accounts, and in the case of disbursements specifically, shall be made from the disbursing account hereby established. Effective for all obligations incurred on or after July 1, 2002, all receipts and disbursements of the retirement system shall be made by means of actual transfers of cash or other funds, and (for example) shall not be made by means of offsetting obligations. 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004: Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.650 - Investment manager. 
A.  The board of trustees shall have the right to name and delegate investment authority and duty to an investment manager. Upon such action by the board of trustees the investment manager shall assume from the trustee the authority and duty to direct the investment and management of all or a portion of the trust fund; provided, however, that: 
1.  A written acknowledgment by the investment manager shall be delivered to the board whereupon the investment manager shall be the fiduciary with respect to the investment and management of the trust fund (or designated portion thereof) and the board shall have no responsibility therefor; 
2.  Any transfer of investment and management authority to an investment manager may be revoked by the board, or by written resignation of the investment manager upon receipt by the board of same; 
3.  The appointment, selection and retention of a qualified investment manager shall be solely the responsibility of the board. 
B.  For purposes of this section, the term "investment manager" means any fiduciary (other than the board or any other person named herein as a fiduciary) who: (a) has the power to manage, acquire or dispose of any property of the trust; (b) is (i) registered as an investment adviser under either the Investment Advisors Act of 1940 or the Uniform Securities Act as set forth in Public Acts of 1964, No. 265, being Sections 451.501 and 457.818 of Michigan Compiled Laws; (ii) a bank as defined under the Investment Advisors Act of 1940; or (iii) an insurance company qualified to perform services described in clause (a) under the laws of more than one state; and (c) has acknowledged in writing that he/it is a fiduciary with respect to the assets of the retirement system. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.660 - Assignments prohibited-Nonalienation of benefits. 
A.  Benefits under this retirement ordinance shall be subject to the Michigan Public Employee Retirement Benefit Protection Act (the "Benefit Protection Act"), Michigan Compiled Laws 38.1681-38.1689. Neither the principal of the trust fund nor any of the income therefrom, nor interest in the trust whatever, shall be subject to any conveyance, transfer or assignment by any participant or survivor pension beneficiary, nor shall the same be pledged as collateral by any participant or survivor pension beneficiary, nor shall the same be subject to any claim of any creditor of any participant or survivor pension beneficiary through legal process or otherwise. The preceding sentence shall also apply to the creation, assignment, or recognition of a right to any benefit payable with respect to a participant pursuant to a domestic relations order, except as specifically provided for eligible domestic relations orders ("EDROs") pursuant to the Michigan Compiled Laws 38.1701-38.1711 and except as provided for domestic relations orders described in the Benefit Protection Act which comply with the requirements set forth in subsection (C)(1) of this section. It is the intention to place the absolute title to all property which shall constitute the assets of the trust in the trustee, with power to pay out the same and distribute the trust assets as provided in this retirement ordinance. Any attempted sale, conveyance, assignment or pledge of any of the funds or properties held in trust, or any part thereof, or of any income from the trust, by any participant, beneficiary or survivor pension beneficiary shall be null and void, and shall not be recognized by the board of trustees. 
B.  Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, a participant who is convicted of or enters a plea of nolo contendere accepted by the court for a felony as defined in P.A. No. 350 of 1994, as amended, and which arises out of his service as a public employee may, by order of the court, have all or part of his pension forfeited. If a court orders such a forfeiture the order shall comply with the legal requirements of P.A. No. 350 of 1994, as amended, which are incorporated by reference. 
C.  Benefits under the retirement system may be assigned pursuant to a domestic relations order in accordance with Michigan Compiled Laws 38.1681-38.1689, provided that such domestic relations order meets the requirements of Section 414(q) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, and the regulations thereunder (as if the retirement ordinance were the qualified retirement plan of a private employer rather than of a government) (a "QDRO") in whichever of the following methods is specified in such order: 
1.  Unless the participant has already commenced to receive benefits in an annuity form, a QDRO may divide the value of the participant's benefits between the participant and the alternate payee, in which case, the value of the benefits payable to the alternate payee shall be deducted from the participant's benefits. The alternate payee shall have the right to receive such benefits in any form available to a participant, except a joint and survivor annuity for the alternate payee and his or her subsequent spouse, and commencing at any time after the participant attains his earliest retirement age (as specified in Section 2.100.230(D) for participants in the general coverage plan, in Section 2.100.240(D) for participants in the patrol officers coverage plan, in Section 2.100.250(D) for participants in the police command officers plan, in Section 2.100.260(D) for participants in the police chief and fire chief coverage plan, and in Section 2.100.270(D) for participants in the firefighters coverage plan) but prior to the participant's required distribution date (as defined in Section 2.100.310) and, as specified in the QDRO or as specified by the alternate payee if the QDRO does not specify a form and/or time for payment. Benefits awarded to the alternate payee in the QDRO shall be paid whether or not the participant dies prior to such payment, and the alternate payee shall have the right to designate a beneficiary to receive his or her benefits in the event of his or her death to the extent permitted for a participant electing the same form of payment, unless the QDRO provides otherwise. 
2.  If a participant has already started to receive his or her benefits, the form of payment may not be changed and, if the form of payment is a joint and survivor annuity, the joint annuitant may not be changed. However, the QDRO may order that all or any portion of the annuity payments be paid to the alternate payee, and may specify that any amounts not paid to the alternate payee may be paid to the participant or the participant's subsequent spouse after the participant's death, but only over the life of the joint annuitant named at the commencement of the participant's benefits, for a joint and survivor annuity. 
3.  An order shall not be an EDRO or a QDRO unless it includes directions with respect to the participant's accumulated participant contributions. An order shall (a) direct that all, any, or no portion of the accumulated participant contributions be awarded to the alternate payee; (b) direct the form of payment of the alternate payee's share of the accumulated participant contributions, which may only be as an annuity if the order is an EDRO, but which may be an annuity or a lump sum refund pursuant to Section 2.100.350, if the order is a QDRO. 
4.  The retirement system may, in the sole discretion of the board of trustees, charge for the cost to review the EDRO or QDRO by the retirement system's actuary or attorney. An order shall not be an EDRO or QDRO unless it includes directions on who will pay such charges. In the event a portion of a participant's benefit is assigned to an alternate payee pursuant to an EDRO or an order meeting the requirements of a QDRO, the alternate payee's choice of a form of payment shall not affect the right of the participant to independently elect a form of payment of the remainder of benefits, unless the alternate payee is designated as the participant's surviving spouse in an EDRO or unless the participant's benefits are already in pay status (in which case the form of payment is already fixed). 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 18-04 § 3, 2004; Ord. 04-04 § 3 (part), 2004; Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999; Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.670 - Qualified retirement system. 
A.  The city intends the retirement system to be a qualified pension plan under Section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended, and that the trust be exempt under Section 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code. The board shall administer the retirement system so as to fulfill this purpose. The provisions of this retirement ordinance notwithstanding, the board of trustees shall at all times administer the retirement system in compliance with the provisions of Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code, and applicable regulations thereunder, which are applicable to public employee retirement plans and which are incorporated herein by reference as permitted by Tax Reform Act of 1986, Section 1106(h). 
B.  The term "compensation" means for purposes of the limitations set forth in this Section 2.100.670 all compensation of the participant from the participating employer (as described in Section 415 of the Code and the regulations thereunder) for the limitation year. For purposes of applying the limitations of this Section 2.100.670, compensation paid or made available during such limitation period shall include the following: 
1.  Effective for limitation years beginning on or after January 1, 1998, any elective deferral (as defined in Section 402(g)(3) of the Code), and any amount which is contributed or deferred by the participating employer at the participant's election and which is not includible in the participant's gross income by reason of Section 125 or 457 of the Code; and 
2.  Effective for limitation years beginning on or after January 1, 2001, any amount which is not includible in the participant's gross income under a salary reduction agreement used for qualified transportation fringe benefits pursuant to Section 132(f)(4) of the Code. 
    For purposes of applying the limitations of this Section 2.100.670 for limitation years beginning on or after January 1, 2002, an amount which is contributed or deferred by the participating employer by reason of Section 125 of the Code shall include any amounts not available to a participant in cash in lieu of group health coverage because the participant is unable to certify that he has other health coverage. For this purpose, an amount shall be treated as a contribution or deferral by reason of Section 125 of the Code only if the participating employer does not request or collect information regarding the participant's other health coverage as part of the enrollment process for the health plan. 
C.  The term "limitation year" means for purposes of this Section 2.100.670 the plan year. 
D.  The maximum permissible annual benefit computed under this Section 2.100.670 shall not include benefits attributable to mandatory or voluntary participant contributions, if any. The sum of such contributions shall be deemed to be a separate defined contribution plan subject to the limitations for such plans, as set forth in Section 415 of the Code and the regulations thereunder. 
E.  For purposes of determining the maximum permissible annual benefit under this Section 2.100.670, any contributions by a participant to purchase permissive service credits under this retirement ordinance shall comply with the requirements of Section 415(n) of the Code. 
F.  General Provisions. If the annual benefit under this retirement ordinance to a participant is in a form other than a straight life annuity, the maximum permissible amount shall be adjusted to the actuarial equivalent of a straight life annuity beginning at the same age. The interest rate assumption used for determining the actuarial equivalent of such other forms of benefits will be the greater of: 
1.  Five percent; or 
2.  The rate specified in Section 2.100.680 of this retirement ordinance for determining actuarial equivalence. 
    For distributions with an annuity starting date between July 1, 1989 and June 30, 1995, the applicable mortality table shall be the mortality table set forth in Section 2.100.680 of this retirement ordinance. For distributions with an annuity starting date between July 1, 1995 and June 30, 2003, the applicable mortality table shall be the mortality table set forth in Internal Revenue Service ("IRS") Revenue Ruling 95-6. For distributions with an annuity starting date on or after July 1, 2003, the applicable mortality table shall be the mortality table set forth in IRS Revenue Ruling 2001-62. 
(Ord. 04-04 § 3 (part), 2004: Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.680 - Actuarial equivalencies. 
A.  "Actuarial equivalency" or "actuarially equivalent" means a benefit of equivalent value to the benefit it replaces based upon the following actuarial assumptions to be used by the plan actuary in determinations hereunder: 
1.  Mortality: a percent of the male mortality rates and a percent of the female mortality rates contained in the 1971 Group Annuity Mortality Table (set back zero years for males and five years for females). The percentages of male and female mortality rates will be ninety (90) percent male and ten percent female. 
2.  Interest: for purposes of Actuarial Equivalency between the standard form of payment (straight life pension) described in Section 2.100.290 and the optional forms of payment described in Sections 2.100.300(A) through (F) and (H): seven percent a year, compounded yearly. For purposes of determining the remaining amount of pension payable in the straight life form after a participant has withdrawn his Accumulated Participant Contributions under Section 2.100.300(G), an interest rate determined as follows: 
a.  For participants of the firefighters coverage plan, the patrol officers coverage plan and the fire chief: the applicable monthly interest rate for an immediate annuity published by the pension benefit guaranty corporation for a trusteed single employer plan to value a benefit upon termination of an insufficient trusteed single employer plan. 
b.  For participants of the police command officers coverage plan and the police chief: the interest rate adopted by the board of trustees for use in the annual actuarial valuation. Effective July 1, 1996, the interest rate shall be the applicable monthly interest rate for an immediate annuity published by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation for a trusteed single employer plan to value a benefit upon termination of an insufficient trusteed single employer plan. 
c.  For participants in the general coverage plan: seven percent a year, compounded yearly. 
B.  No change in the interest rate or mortality table shall reduce the accrued benefit of any participant. In the event of a change in these actuarial assumptions as applicable to any participant, actuarially equivalent benefits for affected participants after the date of such change shall be the greater of subsection (B)(1) or (2) of this section: 
1.  The actuarial equivalent of the benefit accrued to the date of change, based upon the participant's final average compensation and credited service (both determined as of the date of change) and the provisions of the plan as of the date of change, including the Actuarial Equivalency factors prior to the date of change; or 
2.  The actuarial equivalent of a benefit based upon all final average compensation and credited service determined as of the date of calculation after the amendment, and based upon the terms of the plan after the amendment, applying the new Actuarial Equivalency factors. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.690 - Diversion of assets prohibited. 
A.  All assets of the retirement system shall be held and invested for the sole purpose of meeting the legitimate obligations of the retirement system and shall be used for no other purpose. No part of the assets shall be used for or diverted to purposes other than for the exclusive benefit of participants and beneficiaries prior to satisfaction of all retirement system obligations. 
B.  However, without regard to the provisions of this section: 
1.  If a contribution or any portion thereof is made by the city by a mistake of fact, the board of trustees shall, upon written request of the city, return the contribution or such portion to the city within one year after the date of payment; and 
2.  Earnings attributable to amounts to be returned to the city pursuant to subsection (B)(1) of this section shall not be returned, and losses attributable to amounts to be returned pursuant to subsection (B)(1) of this section shall reduce the amount to be so returned. 
C.  Participants of the board of trustees and its employees and agents are prohibited from having a beneficial interest, direct or indirect, in an investment of the retirement system; borrowing from the retirement system; and receiving any pay or emolument from any individual or organization providing services to the retirement system. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.700 - Amendment or discontinuance of retirement system. 
A.  It is the intent of the city that the retirement system be permanent and remain in effect for an indefinite period. The city, however, subject to any applicable collective bargaining agreements, reserves the right at any time and from time to time, and retroactively if deemed necessary or appropriate to conform with governmental regulations or other policies, to amend, modify or terminate, in whole or in part, any or all of the provisions of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter. No amendment to the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter (including a change in the actuarial basis for determining optional benefits) shall be effective to the extent that it has the effect of decreasing a participant's accrued pension benefit. For purposes of this paragraph, a retirement ordinance amendment which has the effect of eliminating an optional form of benefit, with respect to benefits attributable to service before the amendment shall be treated as reducing accrued benefits. Furthermore, an amendment to the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter shall not have the effect of decreasing a participant's vested interest determined without regard to such amendment as of the later of the date such amendment is adopted, or becomes effective. 
B.  In the event the retirement system is discontinued or terminated, all participants shall immediately become fully vested in their benefits. The discontinuance or termination shall be carried out in all respects in conformance with the code and with applicable statute, rule or regulation of the state of Michigan, or any duly constituted agency thereof. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.710 - Early retirement. 
    As part of its efforts to reduce the city's workforce, the city shall make available an "early retirement window benefit." This early retirement window benefit is made available to such person employed as the deputy treasurer for the city on May 31, 1993 and who retires not later than June 3, 1993. Under the terms of this early retirement window benefit such deputy treasurer employee shall receive a normal retirement benefit that is not actuarially reduced to reflect early commencement. If such deputy treasurer employee retires from the city after June 3, 1993 such employee's eligibility for early retirement and the amount of the employee's benefits under the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter are determined without regard to the early retirement window benefit. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.720 - Direct rollovers. 
A.  This section applies to distributions made on or after January 1, 1993. Notwithstanding any provision of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter to the contrary that would otherwise limit a distributee's election under this section, a distributee may elect, at the time and in the manner prescribed by the board of trustees, to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee in a direct rollover. 
B.  Definitions. 
1.  An "eligible rollover distribution" means any distribution of all or any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an eligible rollover distribution does not include any distribution that is one of a series of substantially equal periodic payments (paid not less frequently than annually) paid over any one of the following periods: the life of the participant (or the joint lives of the participant and the participant's designated beneficiary), the life expectancy of the participant (or the joint life and last survivor expectancy of the participant and the participant's designated beneficiary), or a specified period of ten years or more. 
    Effective January 1, 2002, a portion of a distribution shall not fail to be an eligible rollover distribution merely because the portion consists of after-tax employee contributions which are not includable in gross income. However, such portion may be paid only to an individual retirement account or annuity described in Section 408(a) or (b) of the Code, or to a qualified defined contribution plan described in Section 401(a) or 403(a) of the Code that agrees to separately account for amounts so transferred, including separately accounting for the portion of such distribution which is includable in gross income and the portion of such distribution which is not so includable. 
2.  "Eligible retirement plan" means as follows: 
a.  An individual retirement account described in Code Section 408(a); 
b.  An individual retirement annuity (other than an endowment contract) described in Code Section 408(b); 
c.  A qualified plan described in Section 401(a) of the Code if it is a defined contribution plan which permits the acceptance of rollover distributions; 
d.  An annuity plan described in Section 403(a) of the Code; 
e.  Effective January 1, 2002, an annuity contract described in Section 403(b) of the Code; or 
f.  Effective January 1, 2002, an eligible plan under Section 457(b) of the Code which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state, or any agency or instrumentality of a state or political subdivision of a state and which agrees to separately account for amounts transferred into such plan from this plan. 
    Effective January 1, 2002, the definition of an eligible retirement plan shall also apply in the case of a distribution to a surviving spouse, or to a spouse or former spouse who is the alternate payee under a qualified domestic relation order, as defined in Section 414(p) of the Code. 
3.  A distributee means and includes an employee or former employee. In addition, the employee's or former employee's surviving spouse and the employee's or former employee's spouse or former spouse who is the alternate payee under a qualified domestic relations order, as defined in Section 414(p) of the Code, are distributees with regard to the interest of the spouse or former spouse. 
4.  A "direct rollover" means a payment by the retirement system to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.730 - Accrued benefits. 
    In no case shall the accrued benefits of any participant under Chapter 2.100 of the Hazel Park Municipal Code, as amended, be impaired or diminished by the provisions of the re-stated retirement ordinance codified in this chapter nor by any amendment thereto. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.740 - Preservation of retirement system service credits. 
    The city has elected to become a reciprocal retirement system within the meaning of the Michigan Reciprocal Retirement Act (MCLA Section 3.1101 et seq.) Accordingly, a participant who leaves the employ of the city and enters the employ of another governmental unit and participates in a reciprocal retirement system at such unit, may be entitled to have his or her credited service earned at the succeeding governmental unit recognized under this chapter as credited service for purposes of determining eligibility for a pension hereunder (but not for determining the amount of such pension). Furthermore, a participant who enters the employ of the city from another governmental unit where he participated in a reciprocal retirement system may be entitled to have his or her credited service earned at such preceding governmental unit for purposes of determining eligibility for a pension hereunder (but not for determining the amount of such pension). This section shall only apply to a participant who meets all requirements of the Reciprocal Retirement Act, as same may be amended. The provisions of the Reciprocal Retirement Act are incorporated into this plan by reference as though fully set forth herein. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, upon the completion of thirty (30) months of service with the city, any participant of the city's Supervisor's Union Local 1917 who has received or is currently receiving a pension from another municipality shall be eligible to receive a pension from the city based on the participant's credited service with the city without regard as to whether the preceding governmental employer participated in a reciprocal retirement system. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.750 - Employment rights. 
    The retirement system shall not be construed as giving an employee any right to be retained in the service of the city without its consent nor shall the retirement system interfere with the right of the city to discharge an employee, nor shall an employee be given any right, claim or interest in any benefits of the retirement system except upon fulfillment of the conditions and requirements of the retirement system. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.760 - Correction of errors. 
    The board of trustees shall correct errors in the records and actions of the retirement system. The board of trustees shall seek to recover overpayments and shall make up underpayments. Recovery of overpayments may be accomplished by reducing the amount of future payments so that the actuarial present value of actual payments is equal to the actuarial present value of correct payments. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.770 - Applicable laws. 
    The retirement system shall be construed and enforced under the laws of the state of Michigan and any applicable federal law, rule or regulation, and all of the provisions hereof shall be administered in accordance therewith. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.780 - Severability. 
    If any section or part of a section of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity of the remaining sections of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter or the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter in its entirety. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.790 - Headings. 
    The headings in this chapter are inserted for convenience of reference only and are not to be considered in construction of the provisions hereof. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.800 - Gender and number. 
    Except when otherwise required by the context, any masculine terminology in this chapter shall include the feminine, and any singular terminology shall include the plural. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.810 - Retiree health benefits. 
A.  The eligibility for health insurance coverage, the specific health insurance coverage, the conditions of which would lead to loss of coverage, and the cost to the city and the covered individuals provided after the retirement or death of a retired participant shall be as described in the city of Hazel Park retiree health benefit plan. 
B.  The city's share of the cost of retiree health insurance benefits provided under this section shall, to the extent such account has sufficient funds, be paid from the separate account as described in Section 2.100.460. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 865 (part), 1994) 
2.100.820 - 1994 special early retirement window program. 
A.  Two "special early retirement window" benefits ("window I" and "window II") shall be available as prescribed in this section. Except as provided in subsections (E) and (F) of this section, a participant eligible under subsection (B) of this section shall be entitled to a special early retirement benefit determined in accordance with subsection (C) of this section. Participant election procedures and other requirements are prescribed at subsection (D) of this section. The interaction of this plan with severance pay which is paid directly by the city is described at subsection (G) of this section. 
B.  Age and Service Conditions for Special Early Retirement Program. 
1.  Early Retirement Window I. To be eligible for early retirement window I, a participant must meet one of the age and service conditions described below, as of December 31, 1994. 
a.  General Coverage Plan. 
i.  Age fifty (50) with twenty (20) or more years of credited service; or 
ii.  Age fifty-five (55) with fifteen (15) or more years of credited service; or 
iii.  Age sixty (60) with ten or more years of credited service. 
b.  All Other Coverage Plans. 
i.  Twenty-five (25) or more years of credited service regardless of age; or 
ii.  Age fifty-five (55) with ten or more years of credited service. 
    Only early retirement window I, and not window II, shall be available to a participant who meets the foregoing conditions. 
2.  Early Retirement Window II. To be eligible for early retirement window II, a participant must meet one of the age and service conditions described below, as of December 31, 1994. 
a.  General Coverage Plan. 
i.  Age forty-six (46) with sixteen (16) or more years of credited service; or 
ii.  Age fifty-one (51) with eleven (11) or more years of credited service; or 
iii.  Age fifty-six (56) with six or more years of credited service. 
b.  All Other Coverage Plans 
i.  Twenty-one (21) or more years of credited service regardless of age; or 
ii.  Age fifty-one (51) with six or more years of credited service. 
    A participant who meets the conditions of subsection (B)(2) of this section but not the conditions of subsection (B)(1) shall be eligible only for early retirement window II and not window I. Service purchased by such a participant pursuant to subsection (C)(2) of this section shall not count towards meeting the service requirements of subsection (B)(1) of this section. 
C.  Amount of Straight-Life Retirement Allowance Under the Special Early Retirement Program. 
1.  Early Retirement Window I. In lieu of the normal retirement pension as would otherwise be provided under Sections 2.100.230 through 2.100.270 as applicable, a participant electing early retirement window I shall receive a straight-life retirement allowance (the standard form of payment) in the amount set forth below, as applicable to the participant's coverage plan. In all other respects, the participant's rights under this Plan shall be the same as if the participant had received a normal retirement pension under the usual terms of the applicable coverage plan. 
a.  General Coverage Plan. A general coverage plan participant who satisfies the age and service requirements as described in subsection (B)(1)(a) of this section for a special early retirement benefit shall receive an early retirement allowance under the standard form of payment equal to his or her total years of credited service as of the early retirement date multiplied by two percent of his or her final average compensation. 
b.  Police Patrol and Firefighters Coverage Plans. A police patrol or firefighter coverage plan participant who satisfies the age and service requirements as described in subsection (B)(1)(b) of this section for a special early retirement benefit shall receive an early retirement benefit under the standard form of payment equal to two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by years of credited service with a maximum total credited service of thirty (30) years. 
c.  Police Command Officer, Police Chief and Fire Chief Coverage Plans. A police command officer, police chief and fire chief coverage plan participant who satisfies the age and service requirements as described in subsection (B)(1)(b) of this section for a special early retirement benefit shall receive an early retirement benefit under the standard form of payment equal to two and one-half percent of final average compensation multiplied by years of Credited Service to a maximum of seventy-five percent (75%) of final average compensation. 
2.  Early Retirement Window II. A participant eligible for early retirement window II as set forth at subsection (B)(2) of this section may elect to purchase only so many years (or fractions of years) of credited service as shall be required, when added to the participant's actual years of credited service, to meet the minimum service requirement for a normal retirement pension under the coverage plan applicable to the participant. Such purchased credited service shall be aggregated with actual credited service in calculating the amount of such benefit. In order to purchase such credited service, the participant shall pay in full to the pension reserve fund and prior to the participant's last day worked, the applicable amount set forth below. 
a.  General Coverage Plan. Five percent of the participant's annual compensation as defined at Section 2.100.020.F. (this does not include overtime, uniform allowance or car allowance) times years (or fractions of years purchased), such compensation to be determined as of the date the election to accept the special early retirement benefit is filed with the retirement system administrator. 
b.  All Other Coverage Plans. Five and one-half percent of the participant's compensation as defined at Section 2.100.020.F. (this does not include overtime, uniform allowance or car allowance) times years (or fractions of years purchased), such compensation to be determined as of the date the election to accept the special early retirement benefit is filed with the retirement system administrator. 
D.  Participant Election Procedures for Special Early Retirement. A participant may retire under the special early retirement program provided he or she satisfies each of the following requirements: 
1.  During the period commencing August 1, 1994 and ending September 15, 1994, the participant files with the retirement system administrator (city clerk) a written election for the special early retirement benefits, on forms prescribed by the board, and including any associated releases. Such forms shall be time stamped by the retirement system administrator and copies evidencing the election shall be returned to the participant. 
2.  The participant terminates all city employment and retires during the period commencing October 1, 1994 and ending March 31, 1995. The participant may request a specific last day worked, but the city shall have final approval of same. A participant who terminates employment (other than by reason of death or disability) on other than the last day worked as determined by the city shall forfeit the early retirement benefit. 
3.  After the expiration of a seven day period beginning with the date of filing his or her election to retire, the participant files with the retirement system administrator a written confirmation of his or her failure to revoke the election to retire, such confirmation to be on a form prescribed by the board. Such form shall be time stamped by the retirement system administrator and a copy evidencing its filing shall be returned to the participant. At this time, the participant's election to retire shall be final and irrevocable. 
4.  Participant's retiring under early retirement window II shall, not later than the participant's last day worked, pay in full to the city of Hazel Park pension reserve fund (c/o the retirement system administrator), the amount necessary to purchase the additional years of Credited Service as prescribed at subsection (C)(2) of this section. 
E.  Minimum Participation Requirement. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, the special early retirement window program of this section shall be rescinded, void, and available to no person unless the conditions of subsections (E)(1) and (E)(2) have all been met, by five p.m. on September 23rd. 
1.  At least eleven (11) participants must have elected this special early retirement program and not rescinded the election. 
2.  At least four firefighter participants must have elected to retire under this special early retirement program, without rescinding that election. 
F.  Maximum Participation Limits. For participants in the coverage plans listed below, not more than the specified number of participants may elect a special early retirement window benefit under this section. If more than the specified number has so elected, the permitted number of participants in that coverage plan with the earliest dates of hire with the city will receive the special early retirement window benefits, and the remaining participants in that coverage plan will not. 
1.  Firefighters Coverage Plan. Not more than six firefighter participants (including for this purpose the fire chief) may receive this special early retirement program. 
2.  Patrol Officers Coverage Plan. Not more than three patrol officers may receive this special early retirement program. 
3.  Police Command Officers Coverage Plan. Not more than two police command officers (including for this purpose the police chief) may receive this special early retirement program. 
G.  Severance Pay. Although severance pay is not paid under this plan, the treatment of severance pay is integral to the special early retirement window of this section, and is therefore described herein. 
1.  Window I. A participant electing early retirement window I shall be paid the usual severance pay by the city, but on the following schedule: fifty percent (50%) upon retirement, and the remaining fifty percent (50%) on August 1, 1995. 
2.  Window II. A participant electing early retirement window II shall be paid the usual severance pay by the city, but on the following schedule: 
a.  Upon retirement. The greater of (i) the amount of severance pay (not to exceed one hundred percent (100%)) needed to purchase credited service under subsection (C)(2) of this section; or (ii) fifty percent (50%) of the severance pay. 
b.  August 1, 1995. The remaining severance pay (if any). 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 871 § 1, 1994) 
2.100.830 - 1994 department of public works early retirement benefit. 
A.  A special early retirement benefit is made available under this section to the following department of public works participants: 
1.  Department of public works-Crew leader, with at least thirty-one (31) years of credited service (including purchased military service, if any) as of June 11, 1994 
2.  Department of public works-Mechanic crew leader provided such participants retire not later than the board approved retirement dates of June 11, 1994 and June 24, 1994, respectively. 
B.  The participants eligible under this section shall be entitled to purchase as many additional years (or fractional years) of credited service as shall be required, when added to the participant's actual years of credited service, to meet the minimum service requirement for a normal retirement pension. Such purchased credited service shall be aggregated with actual credited service in calculating the amount of such benefit. In order to purchase such credited service, the participant shall pay in full to the pension reserve fund the applicable amount set forth below: 
 Five percent of the participant's base salary times years (or fractions of years purchased), such base salary to be determined as of the effective date of retirement. 
    For purposes of this section "base salary" means the salary as set forth in the supervisor's salary schedule listed in the city of Hazel Park supervisory union contract. These participants shall, not later than July 1, 1994, pay in full to the city of Hazel Park pension reserve fund (c/o the retirement system administrator) the amount necessary to purchase the additional years of credited service. 
C.  If either participant fails to retire from city employment on his approved retirement date, such participant's eligibility for this early retirement benefit shall be rescinded. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 874 § 1, 1994) 
2.100.840 - Disability retirement of Brian Sanders. 
    In March 1994, the board of trustees authorized participant Brian Sanders' duty-related disability retirement. At the time of his retirement, Mr. Sanders' duty disability pension benefit was calculated in accordance with the usual terms of this chapter as a normal retirement benefit, based on credited service as of the date of duty disability retirement plus projected credited service to age fifty-five (55). A normal retirement benefit is equal to a percentage of final average compensation times years of service. 
    A grievance arose between Mr. Sanders and the city as to whether he was entitled to a terminal payment of certain vacation pay, which he did not receive. Such a terminal payment would have increased Mr. Sanders' final average compensation amount, as well as his duty disability benefit. Pursuant to grievance procedures in the applicable collective bargaining agreement, the issue was resolved with the city not paying the additional vacation pay, but with Mr. Sanders' final average compensation under this chapter to be calculated as if the amount had been paid. By this section, Mr. Sanders' benefit is accordingly so calculated, retroactively to his date of retirement. Except as modified by this section, Mr. Sanders' benefit is subject to the usual terms of this chapter. 
    For purposes of this section, "final average compensation" means that which is set forth at Section 2.100.240; provided, however, that vacation pay which was determined to be owing to the participant but had not been paid shall be counted for purposes of calculating the final average compensation of this participant. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002) 
2.100.850 - Retirement benefit of Keith Lehr. 
    A general release and separation agreement ("agreement") between the city, Keith Lehr and Mr. Lehr's union was entered into to settle and resolve various employment and retirement issues relating to Mr. Lehr. Under the terms of the agreement, Mr. Lehr is permitted to commence a retirement benefit under this chapter under the terms of the patrol officers coverage plan at Section 2.100.240 in accord with this section. 
    By this section, Mr. Lehr shall be entitled to purchase four additional years of credited service for purposes of increasing the years of service multiplier for a normal retirement pension. Such purchased credited service shall be aggregated with actual credited service to calculate the amount of Mr. Lehr's retirement benefit. In order to purchase such credited service, Mr. Lehr shall pay in full to the pension reserve fund the applicable amount set forth below: 
 Five and one-half percent of the maximum police officer's compensation, such compensation to be determined as of the effective date of retirement. 
    The participant's benefit as described in this section is conditioned upon satisfaction of all terms and conditions of the agreement. Except as modified by this section, Mr. Lehr's benefit is subject to the usual terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002) 
2.100.860 - Transfers of employment within the same employer. 
    A participant who transfers from one job category to another with the same participating employer (whether or not such job categories are in the same coverage plan) shall be eligible to receive a benefit (that is, shall be vested) based on his total years of credited service with the participating employer. Such benefit shall be calculated as follows: 
A.  If the participant transferred to another position within the same coverage plan, the participant's benefit shall be based on his total credited service and his compensation and final average compensation (as defined by the applicable coverage plan) earned at all such positions. 
B.  If the participant transferred to another position in a different coverage plan, then his final average compensation shall be determined based upon the prescribed period of credited service in which the total amount of compensation paid to the participant is highest, regardless of which coverage plan the participant was in when such credited service was rendered. The prescribed period for determining final average compensation shall be as set forth in each coverage plan in which the participant rendered service. A separate benefit amount shall be calculated for such a transferred participant under each separate coverage plan in which the participant has rendered service, based upon credited service earned under each respective coverage plan, and based upon the specifications for compensation, final average compensation, and the benefit multiplier percentage of each separate coverage plan. The entire benefit as separately calculated shall be aggregated and paid in a single form of benefit as elected by the participant, provided that option LS shall only apply to accumulated participant contributions made during the periods of credited service rendered under a coverage plan eligible for option LS (together with investment earnings applicable to such accumulated participant contributions). 
    The computation of the pension benefit earned in each applicable coverage plan shall be in accord with Section 2.100.120 and the coverage plans applicable to a participant as provided in Sections 2.100.230, 2.100.240, 2.100.250, 2.100.260A, 2.100.260B and 2.100.270 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004: Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999) 
2.100.870 - Transfers of employment among participating employers in the retirement system. 
    The pension of a participant who transfers to a position with a different participating employer in the retirement system shall be determined as follows: 
A.  The amount of pension shall be determined in accordance with Section 2.100.860 of this chapter, as if all credited service had been rendered to the same participating employer, but on the basis of all applicable coverage plans. 
B.  The participant shall be vested in the pension earned during employment with each participating employer of his total credited service (based on employment with all participating employers) meets the requirements to receive a pension under each applicable coverage plan. 
(Ord. 19-04 § 3 (part), 2004: Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999) 
2.100.880 - Library employee participation in the retirement system. 
A.  Transition from City to Library Board Employment. Effective November 28, 1995, employees of the city's public library, who were previously city employees ("library employees") became employees of an independent library board. Effective as of that date, the library board has adopted the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter as applicable to library employees of the library board. Therefore, for library employees who were participants in the retirement system prior to the establishment of the separate library board, participation in the general coverage provisions of the retirement system shall remain unchanged, notwithstanding the fact that such employees became employed by the library board. Notwithstanding Section 2.100.870, all credited service for benefits accrued and compensation for benefit purposes earned by a library employee as a city employee through November 28, 1995 shall continue to be recognized. Any library employees first hired after November 28, 1995 will participate in the general coverage provisions of the retirement system pursuant to the terms of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter. 
B.  Adoption of Ordinance by Library Board. By adoption of this ordinance, the library board delegates to the board of trustees the powers, duties and responsibilities of administering the retirement system, provided that it shall be the responsibility of the library board to (i) make employer contributions with respect to library employees as determined by the actuary of the retirement system in order to fund the employer portion of the pension consistent with the provisions of the general coverage plan of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter; (ii) withhold from the pay of library employees, and forward to the retirement system, the participant contributions required under the terms of the general coverage plan provisions of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter; (iii) pay plan expenses in proportion to the assets and liabilities of library employees either from such assets or directly by the library board, as the board of trustees shall direct with respect to all participating employers; and (iv) to timely provide the board of trustees with all information necessary or proper to the trustees' administration of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter. The library board further delegates to the city the right to amend or terminate the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter contained at Section 2.100.700; provided that the library board reserves the following rights: 
1.  To determine the level of participant contributions for library employees, and to determine whether such contributions shall be picked up by the library board and treated, for tax purposes only, as employer contributions pursuant to Code Section 401(h), provided that if the amount of participant contributions is changed, the actuary shall adjust the employer contributions to be paid by the library board accordingly; and 
2.  To terminate its adoption of this retirement ordinance, as further provided herein. 
C.  Allocation of Retirement System Assets and Liabilities Related to Library Employees. Reserved. 
D.  Termination of Participation by Library Board. The library board may terminate its participation in the retirement system upon appropriate action by it. The city council may terminate the participation of the library board in the retirement system upon one hundred eighty (180) days' written notice. In either event, the ordinance shall be appropriately amended to reflect the cessation of future accruals for participants who are library employees, and to reflect the disposition of benefits accrued by or with respect to current or former library employees (the "affected persons"). Such amendment shall cover the full effect of such withdrawal, including without limitation the effect on current or future vesting, the disposition of retirement system assets or liabilities, and the payment of benefits to affected persons, including the payment of benefits to retired participants and the future payment of benefits to vested terminated participants who were library employees. The specific provisions of the amendment shall depend upon the following factors: the nature of the withdrawal, any subsequent qualified retirement plan arrangements made for the affected persons, and any other relevant considerations. The amendment shall comply with applicable law, including without limitation, the Code, Michigan Constitution of 1963, as amended, and Michigan Statutes. 
    In the event the library board's participation in the retirement system terminates (i) the library board shall establish a successor retirement plan and trust ("transferee plan") which preserves the accrued financial benefits of all library employees and all retired and vested former library employees, and (ii) the board of trustees shall transfer to the successor plan and trust cash or assets having a value equal to the amounts credited to the pension reserve fund and participant contribution fund allocable to library employees and retired and vested former library employees, all as soon as administratively feasible after the date of such termination. 
    After the transfer of benefits and liabilities as described in this subsection, this retirement system shall be released of all liabilities to the affected persons, whose sole source of benefits shall be the transferee plan. 
E.  Library Board-Definition. For purposes of this section, "library board" means the city of Hazel Park library board, and any successor which shall be authorized to participate in the retirement system by (i) the successor's resolution adopting the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter, and (ii) approval of such successor's adoption by the city of Hazel Park city council. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999) 
2.100.890 - Court employee participation in the retirement system. 
A.  Pursuant to 1996 P.A. 374, funding of the 43rd district court transferred from joint funding by the state of Michigan and the city of Hazel Park to funding by the city only. Employees of the 43rd district court ("court employees") are under the supervision and control of the judges of the 43rd district court but are paid by the city. Such court employees have participated in the general coverage provisions of the retirement system and will continue to participate in the retirement system on the terms described in this chapter. Notwithstanding Section 2.100.870, all credited service for benefits accrued and compensation for benefit purposes earned by a court employee shall continue to be recognized. 
B.  Adoption of Ordinance by 43rd District Court. By adoption of this ordinance, the 43rd district court delegates to the board of trustees the powers, duties and responsibilities of administering the retirement system, provided that it shall be the responsibility of the city, on behalf of the 43rd District Court, to (i) make employer contributions with respect to court employees as determined by the actuary of the retirement system in order to fund the employer portion of the pension consistent with the provisions of the general coverage plan of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter; (ii) withhold from the pay of court employees, and forward to the retirement system, the participant contributions required under the terms of the general coverage plan provisions of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter; (iii) pay plan expenses in proportion to the assets and liabilities of court employees either from such assets or directly by the city, as the board of trustees shall direct with respect to all participating employers; and (iv) to timely provide the board of trustees with all information necessary or proper to the trustees' administration of the retirement ordinance codified in this chapter. The 43rd district court further delegates to the city the right to amend or terminate the retirement ordinance contained at Section 2.100.700; provided that the 43rd district court reserves the following rights: 
1.  To determine the level of participant contributions for court employees, and to determine whether such contributions shall be picked up by the city on behalf of the 43rd district court and treated, for tax purposes only, as employer contributions pursuant to Code Section 401(h), provided that if the amount of participant contributions is changed, the actuary shall adjust the employer contributions to be paid by the city accordingly; and 
2.  To terminate its adoption of this retirement ordinance, as further provided herein. 
C.  Allocation of retirement system Assets and Liabilities Related to Court Employees. Reserved. 
D.  Termination of Participation by 43rd District Court. The 43rd district court may terminate its participation in the retirement system upon appropriate action, subject to applicable collective bargaining agreements. The city council may terminate the participation of the 43rd district court in the retirement system upon one hundred eighty (180) days' written notice. In either event, (i) obligations under applicable collective bargaining agreements shall be appropriately met, and (ii) the ordinance shall be appropriately amended to reflect the cessation of future accruals for participants who are court employees, and to reflect the disposition of benefits accrued by or with respect to current or former court employees (the "affected persons"). Such amendment shall cover the full effect of such withdrawal, including without limitation the effect on current or future vesting, the disposition of retirement system assets or liabilities, and the payment of benefits to affected persons, including the payment of benefits to retired participants and the future payment of benefits to vested terminated participants who were court employees. The specific provisions of the amendment shall depend upon the following factors: the nature of the withdrawal, any subsequent qualified retirement plan arrangements made for the affected persons, and any other relevant considerations. The amendment shall comply with applicable law, including without limitation, the Code, Michigan Constitution of 1963, as amended, and Michigan Statutes. 
    In the event the 43rd district court's participation in the retirement system terminates (i) the 43rd district court shall establish a successor retirement plan and trust ("transferee plan") which preserves the accrued financial benefits of all court employees and all retired and vested former court employees, and (ii) the board of trustees shall transfer to the successor plan and trust cash or assets having a value equal to the amounts credited to the pension reserve fund and participant contribution fund allocable to court employees and retired and vested former court employees, all as soon as administratively feasible after the date of such termination. 
    After the transfer of benefits and liabilities as described in this subsection, this retirement system shall be released of all liabilities to the affected persons, whose sole source of benefits shall be the transferee plan. 
E.  43rd District Court-Definition. For purposes of this section, "43rd district court" means the 43rd district court, and any successor which shall be authorized to participate in the retirement system by (i) the successor's resolution adopting the retirement ordinance, and (ii) approval of such successor's adoption by the city of Hazel Park city council. 
(Ord. 17-02 § 3 (part), 2002: Ord. 945 (part), 1999)
