    No license of dog or cat kennels or catteries shall be issued, and the maintenance of any kennel or cattery or the owning, possessing or harboring or boarding of dogs or cats for breeding or commercial purposes in any residential neighborhood is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se which may be abated in any court of competent jurisdiction, 
(Ord. No. 06-17, pt. III, 7-11-2017) 
Article IV. - Animal Control Facilities and Personnel 

6.04.110 - Animal control shelter. 
A.  The city shall provide an animal control shelter and it shall be the duly of the animal control officer or any other authorized person to seize, take up and place in said control shelter any dog or cat running at large or being kept or harbored in any place in the city contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  No dog or cat shall be released from the animal control shelter unless the owner or person entitled to claim the animal shall pay the fees and charges as set forth by resolution of the city council, for the following: 
1.  Impounding fees; 
2.  Cost of board, vaccination and other care and treatment, if necessary; 
3.  Any license fees required. 
(Ord. No. 06-17, pt. IV, 7-11-2017) 
6.04.120 - Animal control officer. 
    It shall be the duty of the animal control officer: 
1.  To make diligent inquiry as to the dogs or cats owned, harbored, kept in the city and whether such dogs or cats are licensed. 
2.  To issue ordinance violation tickets to those persons owing or harboring dogs or cats contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
3.  To sell or otherwise dispose of a dog or cat from and after five working days of its acquisition. If the dog or cat has a collar, license, microchip or other evidence of ownership, the animal control officer shall notify the owner, in writing, and disposition of the animal shall not be make within seven days from the date of the certified mailing of the notice, unless said animal is sick or injured to the extent that the holding period would cause undue suffering or to animals whose owners request immediate disposal. 
4.  To dispose of any dog or cat after five working days, by transferring the animal to another shelter or animal rescue organization for adoption or otherwise. 
5.  Destroy, in a humane manner, all impounded dogs or cats 
(Ord. No. 06-17, pt. IV, 7-11-2017) 
Article V. - Nuisance 

6.04.130 - Nuisance. 
A.  Any animal, including dogs, which, by loud or frequent or habitual barking, yelping or howling, or other noises, causes serious annoyance to a neighbor or the neighborhood, or which injures or destroys real or personal property of persons other than its owner, or molests or injures, any person, or causes unsanitary conditions because of droppings, uneaten food or any other thing to cause odor or attraction of flies, rodents or vermin, is deemed in violation of the provisions of this section. 
B.  The owner of every dog or cat who permits dog or cat droppings to occur on any public street, right-of-way, park or public place, or to occur on the property of others, shall be deemed in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 06-17, pt. V, 7-11-2017) 
Article VI. - Dangerous/Vicious Animal 

6.04.140 - Definition. 
A.  A "dangerous" or "vicious animal" means: 
1.  A dog or other animal that bites or attacks a person, or a dog or other animal; 
2.  A dog or other animal that attacks and causes serious injury or death to a person or other animal; 
3.  A dog or other animal which has shown vicious habits or has molested a person when lawfully on its own or public property or under the control of its owner. 
B.  A dangerous or vicious animal does not include any of the following: 
1.  An animal that bites or attacks a person who is knowingly trespassing on the property of the animal's owner; 
2.  An animal that bites or attacks a person who provokes or torments the animal; 
3.  An animal that is responding in a manner that an ordinary and reasonable person would conclude was designed to protect a person if that person is engaged in a lawful activity or is the subject of an assault. 
(Ord. No. 06-17, pt. VI, 7-11-2017) 
6.04.150 - Complaint; retention; court order; destruction. 
A.  Upon a sworn complaint that an animal is a dangerous animal and the animal has caused serious injury or death to a person or has caused serious injury or death to another animal, the district court shall issue a summons to the owner ordering him or her to appear to show cause why the animal should not be destroyed. 
B.  Upon the filing of a sworn complaint as provided in subdivision A of this section, the court or magistrate shall order the owner to immediately turn the animal over to a proper animal control authority, an incorporated humane society, a licensed veterinarian, or a boarding kennel, at the owner's option and expense, to be retained by them until a hearing is held and a decision is made for the disposition of the animal. The owner shall notify the person who retains the animal under this section of the complaint and order. The animal shall not be returned to the owner until it has a current rabies vaccination and a license as required by law and further order of the court. 
C.  After a hearing, the court shall order the destruction of the animal, at the expense of the owner, if the animal is found to be a dangerous animal that caused serious injury or death to a person or another animal. After a hearing, the court may order the destruction of the animal, at the expense of the owner, if the court finds that the animal is a dangerous animal that did not cause serious injury or death to a person but is likely in the future to cause serious injury or death to a person or animal or in the past has been adjudicated a dangerous animal. 
D.  If the court or magistrate finds that an animal is a dangerous animal but has not caused serious injury or death to a person or another animal, the court shall notify the animal control authority for the city or county in which the complaint was filed of the finding of the court, the name of the owner of the dangerous animal, and the address at which the animal was kept at the time of the finding of the court. In addition, the court shall order the owner of that animal to do one or more of the following: 
1.  Take specific steps, such as escape proof fencing or enclosure, including a top or roof, to ensure that the animal cannot escape or non-authorized individuals cannot enter premises; 
2.  Have the animal sterilized; 
3.  Obtain and maintain liability insurance coverage sufficient to protect the public from any damage or harm caused by the animal; 
4.  Take any other action appropriate to protect the public. 
(Ord. No. 06-17, pt. VI, 7-11-2017) 
Article VII. - Violation; Penalty 

6.04.160 - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any part of this chapter shall be responsible for a civil infraction and shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus costs for a first offense and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) plus costs for a second or subsequent offense. Each day a violation exists shall be considered a separate violation. 
    In addition to any fine or penalty imposed for a violation of any provision of this chapter, the court may order the defendant not to own or possess an animal for a period of time. If a person is found responsible for a second or subsequent offense, the court may order the defendant not to own or possess an animal for any period of time, including relinquishment of animal ownership. 
(Ord. No. 06-17, pt. VII, 7-11-2017) 
Chapter 6.08 - RABBITS AND POULTRY 
Sections: 

6.08.010 - Keeping without permission. 
    No rabbits or poultry shall be kept within the corporate limits of the city except by permission of the city. 
(Ord. 33 § 1, 1943) 
6.08.020 - Application to keep. 
    Any person desiring to keep rabbits or poultry within the corporate limits of the city shall make application to the city manager in writing for permission to do so, describing particularly the place where the applicant proposes to keep such rabbits or poultry, the number thereof, the distance from such place to the public streets on each side and the distance to the dwelling houses upon the lands adjoining such proposed place. 
(Ord. 33 § 2, 1943) 
6.08.030 - Application-Investigation-Permit fee. 
    All applications shall be submitted by the city manager to the health department for investigation, report and recommendation. If it appears to the city manager that it will not be detrimental to the health, safety, and welfare of any of the inhabitants of the city, the city manager, upon payment of a license fee, to be set by resolution of the city council, for each permit, shall grant a permit to the persons applying therefor, to keep rabbits or poultry within the corporate limits of the city. Such permit shall specify the place where such rabbits or poultry may be kept, and the number thereof shall be reasonable as determined by the manager. No person shall keep any rabbits or poultry in the city contrary to the terms and conditions of such permit. The city manager may revoke such permit whenever he or she may deem it fit and proper to do so. 
(Amended during 1997 recodification; Ord. 33 § 3, 1943) 
6.08.040 - Keeping-Rules-Revocation of permit when. 
    All persons keeping any rabbits or poultry shall keep the places wherein they are kept in a clean and sanitary condition and in accordance with such rules and regulations as may be made from time to time by the city manager. Upon failure to comply with any such rules and regulations, the city manager may revoke the permit to keep any such rabbits or poultry. 
(Ord. 33 § 4, 1943) 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 7-11-2017) 
6.08.050 - Appeal. 
    Any person feeling aggrieved by any action or ruling of the city manager in relation to the powers granted to him or her in this chapter, may appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be in writing and after hearing thereon the determination of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. 33 § 5, 1943) 
6.08.060 - Running at large prohibited. 
    No rabbits or poultry may run at large within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 33 § 6, 1943) 
6.08.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person or persons violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or thirty (30) days in jail or both. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. II, 7-11-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-17, pt. II, adopted July 11, 2017, amended § 6.08.070 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 6.08.070 pertained to violation of Sections 6.08.010-6.08.060; penalty and derived from Ord. 33, § 8, adopted in 1943. 
6.08.080 - Sale of rabbit or fowl as pet. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, by himself or herself or another, to sell, offer for sale, barter or give away baby chicks, rabbits, ducklings, or other fowl as pets or novelties whether or not dyed, colored, or otherwise artificially treated. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the display or sale of natural chicks or ducklings in proper brooder facilities by hatcheries or stores engaged in the business of selling the same to be sold or raised for commercial purposes. 
(Ord. 333 § 1, 1963) 
6.08.090 - Violation-Seizure. 
    In the case of any violation of Section 6.08.080 it shall be the duty of any fully authorized humane officer, peace officer, sheriff or health officer to seize such fowl or pets and to provide the necessary care and attention, and such fowl or pets shall not be returned until all expenses for such care and attention shall have been paid. 
(Ord. 333 § 2, 1963) 
6.08.100 - Violation of Sections 6.08.080 and 6.08.090-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating the provisions of Sections 6.08.080 and 6.08.090 shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. 333 § 3, 1963) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY* 
Chapters: 
Chapter 8.02 - VACANT AND ABANDONED STRUCTURES 
Sections: 

8.02.010 - Findings. 
    The city council determines that the presence of vacant and abandoned structures creates an element of neighborhood and commercial blight. It is recognized that blight lowers property values, leads to deteriorating housing conditions, undermines the quality of neighborhood life, affects the public health, safety and general welfare and can also result in human injury and criminal activities. It is also determined that vacant and unoccupied structures occupy an inordinate amount of city administrative and ordinance enforcement resources. As such, the city council finds the prolonged presence of vacant and abandoned structures to be unacceptable to the citizens of Hazel Park. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
(a)  "Abandoned residential or commercial structure means either of the following: which has or have become vacant or abandoned for a period of at least thirty (30) consecutive days, excluding those structures which have been registered as seasonal businesses or homes with the city clerk's office, and which also meets at least one of the following conditions: 
(i)  "Residential structure" means any building which has been used or was intended for use as a residential dwelling, in whole or in part, including accessory building(s), 
(ii)  "Commercial structure" means any building not defined herein as a residential structure, has been vacant for a period of thirty (30) consecutive days or longer and is one or more of the following: 
1.  Open to casual entry or trespass; 
2.  Fire damaged to an extent which prohibits safe human occupancy; 
3.  The site of loitering or vagrancy; 
4.  Demonstrates a lack of property maintenance and upkeep as evidenced by one or more violations of the Property Maintenance Code (Chapter 43) or State Construction Code; 
5.  Has been secured or boarded up; 
6.  Has taxes in arrears to the city for a period of time exceeding three hundred sixty-five (365) days; 
7.  Has utilities disconnected or not in use; 
8.  Not fit for human occupancy or is under notice or legal order to vacate, or hearing officer notice that it is unfit for occupancy. 
9.  Structurally unsound; or 
10.  Dilapidated or in a state of decay or damage, determined by the building official that access to the structure or any structure on the property should be denied. 
(b)  "Accessory building" means a subordinate structure on the same premises as the main residential structure, the use of which would be naturally and normally incidental to that of the main structure, whether the main structure is an abandoned residential structure or not, such as, by not limited to, a garage, barn or storage shed. 
(c)  "Owner" means any person with legal or equitable ownership interest in the structure, including but not limited to a corporation foreclosing a lien or mortgage interest in the affected property. Owner shall include those persons having been foreclosed upon, but the redemption period has not expired. 
(d)  "Secured" means a building which has all points of entry into the structure either: 
(1)  Closed by use of windows and doors which are in proper working order, intact, without broken elements, and are locked; or 
(2)  Are secured by exterior grade plywood in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.030 - Registration and exclusions. 
A.  Registration of Abandoned Structures: Owners of an abandoned structure(s) shall register such property or properties with the city clerk's office and pay a monthly administration fee. The duty to register an abandoned structure shall not require prior notice to the owner by the city. Registration of an abandoned structure does not preclude the city from taking appropriate actions to secure the property or to issue orders to repair or abate dangerous, hazardous or unlawful conditions or from acting to eliminate an imminent hazard to public health and safety. 
B.  Registration of Excluded Structures: Businesses which are deemed seasonal may register with the city clerk's office as a seasonal business and shall be excluded from the definition of abandoned structure if all of the following are met: 
1)  The business has a valid business license from the city of Hazel Park; 
2)  The business property is maintained; including shoveling of snow from sidewalks; cutting of weeds and grass; exterior properly painted or sided, windows, doors and signs maintained in good working order. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.040 - Registration information. 
(a)  For each abandoned structure each owner shall register with the city clerk's office and provide the following information on an abandoned structure registration form available from the city: 
(1)  The address of the abandoned structure; 
(2)  The legal names of all owners of the property and each owner's date of birth; 
(3)  The complete mailing address of all owners; if post office address provided, a physical address for contact shall also be provided; 
(4)  Telephone numbers of each owner, including cell phone and mobile phone numbers; 
(5)  Proof of identification of each owner; 
(6)  The name, address and telephone number of any local agent or representative authorized by the owner to handle the affairs of the property, including, but not limited to real estate agents, rental managers, property maintenance personnel; 
(7)  The reason for the vacancy of the property; 
(8)  Name and contact information for the mortgage company, if under foreclosure or deed in lieu of foreclosure has been provided; 
(9)  The estimated length of time the property is expected to remain vacant; and 
(10)  Any plans for restoration, reuse or removal with an accompanying timeline and work schedule. 
(b)  An owner shall notify the city and file an amended form within seven days of any change to the registration information required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.050 - Registration and administrative fee. 
(a)  An owner of an abandoned structure, whether registered or not, shall pay an abandoned structure registration fee and a monthly administrative fee, the amounts of which shall be established by city council resolution, in addition to any fees related to maintenance performed at the property by the city, for the time during which such structure remains an abandoned structure. 
(b)  Fees under this section shall be established to support the services rendered by the city in the course of its duties related to abandoned structures. Failure to register an abandoned structure or pay the monthly administrative fee shall be cause for penalties to be assessed and are criminal violations of this chapter. 
(c)  The monthly administrative fee shall be paid so that it is received by the city on or before the seventh day of each month, following each month during which the structure was an abandoned structure for fifteen (15) days or more. 
(d)  A late fee, in an amount to be established by the city council, shall also be payable by an owner of an abandoned structure when the monthly administrative fee is not timely paid. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.060 - Recovery of fees. 
    If all or part of the fees required by this Chapter 8.02 are not paid or are overdue, the city may recover such sums by: 
(a)  Directing the city treasurer to take all necessary measures to add the amount due to the next tax roll of the city as a single lot assessment under these codified ordinances and collect said sum in the same manner as provided by law for collection of taxes and special assessments. The lien for the cost shall be collected and treated in the same manner as provided for property tax liens under the General Property Tax Act, Act 206 of the Public Acts of 1993, being Sections 211.1 to 211.57 of the Michigan Compiled Laws; 
(b)  Filing suit against the owner for entry of civil money judgment; or 
(c)  Any other means available by law. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.070 - Securing structures. 
(a)  A city order to secure an abandoned property shall be complied with by the owner within seventy-two (72) hours. if the securing has not been completed or does not comply with the requirements for securing the structure under this chapter, the city shall secure the structure and the city shall bill the owner for all costs incurred, including service fee and administrative costs. The amount so billed shall constitute a personal debt of the owner and may be recovered in the same manner as permitted for the recovery of fees under this chapter. 
(b)  Plywood boarding shall be placed over all points of entry on an abandoned residential structure such that all exterior openings suitable for animal or human entry are secured as follows: 
(1)  On all first story and ground accessible points of entry, such shall be secured by use of exterior grade plywood or its equivalent, of at least one-half inch thickness, cut to the size of the opening and secured by the use of Philips headed two-inch long screws; and 
(2)  On entry points being secured above the first story or where not accessible from ground level, such shall be secured by use of exterior grade plywood or its equivalent of at least one-half inch thickness, cut to the size of the opening and secured by the use of 16-penny common nails. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.080 - Right of entry and inspection. 
    Abandoned structure(s) shall be inspected annually by the city's building and electrical inspectors to insure that the structure(s) are in compliance with all ordinances and the safety of the public and other properties are not in jeopardy by its condition or continued deterioration. 
    If the owner has failed to secure a property and it has been secured by the city, the city may enter or reenter the structure to conduct necessary inspections to insure compliance with requirements of this chapter and to determine if there are any emergency or hazardous conditions. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.090 - Reuse and occupancy. 
    No abandoned structure shall be reoccupied until inspected and found to be in full compliance with all applicable city codes and a certificate of occupancy is issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.110 - Penalty. 
(a)  A person who violates or fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than ninety (90) days, or both, for each offense. 
(b)  In addition to any other penalty provided for in this section, this chapter may be enforced by suit for injunction, action for damages, or any equitable relief appropriate to the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.02.120 - Appeal. 
    The procedure for appealing decisions of the city building official under this Chapter shall be as follows: 
(1)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city building official, shall have the right, within ten days of notice being provided to the owner by first class mail and being posted on the primary structure, file a written request therefore with the city clerk. 
(2)  The appeal shall state the decision being appealed and provide a written basis upon which the appellant relies for overturning or modification of the building official's decision. 
(3)  The city clerk shall provide for a date and time in which the appeal will be heard by the city manager and such notice shall be mailed to address provided by the owner on the appeal request. 
(4)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city manager may appeal to the city council by providing a written request as heretofore outlined to the city clerk's office within five business days of the city manager's decision. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, pt. I, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 03-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
Chapter 8.04 - NUISANCES* 
Sections: 

8.04.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
1.  "Nuisance" means any act or acts or omissions to act on the part of any person which creates or permits the existence of a situation which annoys, injures or endangers the peace, welfare, order, health or safety of the public and their persons or property. As defined herein, a nuisance includes, but is not limited to, conditions which render persons insecure in life or in the use and enjoyment of their property, such as effects and emanations from noise, glare, lights, vibration, dust, smoke, odor, gas, steam, fly ash, soot, acids, chemicals, fumes, cinders, worms, insects, rodents, flies, decaying matter, whether such effects and emanations are natural or a result from human or mechanical alteration or manipulation of materials. A nuisance also includes residues or leaching from deposits of matter which seep into water on the surface or in the ground thereby making it unfit or unpalatable for human consumption, or for use by domestic animals. A nuisance includes a condition which is indecent, obnoxious or offensive to the senses. 
2.  "Persons" or "person" means a natural person and also includes corporations, partnerships and associations and their officers and officials existing under or authorized to exist under the laws of the state of Michigan or of any other state or foreign country. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1997) 
8.04.020 - Penalty. 
    Any person who creates, causes, allows, suffers or permits the existence of a nuisance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day that such nuisance is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate misdemeanor. Any person who is convicted of such a misdemeanor shall be punished as set forth in Chapter 1.12 of this code. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1997) 
8.04.030 - Abatement. 
    It is the duty of the person who creates, causes, allows, suffers or permits the existence of a nuisance, to abate the same. The term "abate" or "abatement" shall include demolition, removal, repair, maintenance, construction, reconstruction, replacement and reconditioning of structures, appliances, appurtenance or equipment; and it shall also include removal, transportation, buying, disposal and treatment of refuse, manure or other substance or media capable of causing obnoxious odors or retracting or brooding flies, an application of chemicals, insecticides or other substances or the use of mechanical means to control, eradicate and eliminate the nuisance conditions, including screen belts of trees and fences. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1997) 
8.04.031 - Enforcement of provisions. 
    The city manager, upon notice to city council is hereby authorized to enforce the provisions of Sections 8.04.010 through 8.04.030, and he or she may delegate the enforcement to any administrative official of the city. The city may seek abatement of a nuisance and such other relief as may be obtained by civil proceedings in court. This is in addition to and not in derogation of prosecutions for violations of said sections as set forth under Section 8.04.020. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1997) 
8.04.035 - Nuisances per se. 
    It is unlawful for any owner or agent thereof to keep or maintain any building or structure or part thereof which is a dangerous building. A "dangerous building" means a building or structure that has one or more of the following defects or is in one or more of the following conditions: 
A.  A door, aisle, passageway, stairway or other means of exit does not conform to the approved fire code of the city; 
B.  A portion of the building or structure is damaged by fire, wind, flood, deterioration, neglect, abandonment, vandalism or other cause so that the structural strength or stability of the building or structure is appreciably less than it was before the damage and does not meet the minimum requirements of this act or a building code of the city for a new building or structure, purpose or location; 
C.  A part of the building or structure is likely to fall, become detached or dislodged, or collapse and injure persons or damage property; 
D.  A portion of the building or structure has settled to such an extent that walls or other structural portions of the building or structure have materially less resistance to wind than is required in the case of new construction by the city building code; 
E.  The building or structure, or part of the building or structure, because of dilapidation, deterioration, decay, faulty construction, or the removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the support, or for other reason, is likely to partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or underpinning of the building or structure is likely to fall or give way; 
F.  The building, structure or a part of the building or structure is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is used; 
G.  The building or structure is damaged by fire, wind or flood, or is dilapidated or deteriorated and becomes an attractive nuisance to children who might play in the building or structure to their danger, or becomes a harbor for vagrants, criminals or immoral persons, or enables persons to resort to the building or structure for committing a nuisance or an unlawful or immoral act; 
H.  A building or structure used or intended to be used for dwelling purposes, including the adjoining grounds, because of the dilapidation, decay, damage, faulty construction or arrangement, or otherwise, is unsanitary or unfit for human habitation, is in a condition that the health officer determines is likely to cause sickness or disease, or is likely to injure the health, safety or general welfare of people living in the dwelling; 
I.  A building or structure is vacant, dilapidated, and open at door or window, leaving the interior of the building exposed to the elements or accessible to entrance by trespassers; 
J.  A building or structure remains unoccupied for a period of one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days or longer, and is not listed as being available for sale, lease, or rent with a licensed real estate broker, unless, the owner or agent notifies the Hazel Park police department that the building or structure will remain unoccupied for a period of one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days, which notice shall be given to the city police department not more than thirty (30) days after the building or structure becomes unoccupied; and the owner or agent maintains the exterior of the building or structure and adjoining grounds in accordance with the Hazel Park building code or the building or structure is a secondary dwelling that is regularly unoccupied for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days or longer each year, and the owner or agent notifies the police department that the dwelling will remain unoccupied for a period of one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days or more each year. An owner who has given the notice heretofore proscribed should notify the police department not more than thirty (30) days after the dwelling no longer qualifies for this exception. 
(Ord. 10-03 § 1, 2003; Ord. 892 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 756 § 1, 1988) 
8.04.040 - Notice. 
    If a building or structure is found to be a dangerous building, the enforcement officer shall issue a notice that the building or structure is a dangerous building. The notice shall be served on the owner, agent, or lessee that is registered pursuant to Title 5 of this code. If an owner, agent, or lessee is not registered under Title 5, the notice shall be served on each owner of or party in interest in the building or structure and whose name the property appears on the last local tax assessment records. The notice shall specify the time and place of a hearing on whether the building or structure is a dangerous building. The clerk shall file a copy of the notice that the building or structure is a dangerous building with the hearing officer. The notice shall be in writing and shall be served upon the person to whom the notice is directed either personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner or party in interest at the address shown on the tax records. If a notice is served on a person by certified mail, a copy of the notice shall also be posted upon a conspicuous part of the building or structure. The notice shall be served upon the owner or party in interest at least ten days before the date of hearing included in the notice. The person to whom the notice is directed shall have the opportunity to show cause at the hearing why the hearing officer should not order the building or structure to be demolished, otherwise made safe, or properly maintained. 
(Ord. 892 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 366 § 4, 1965: Ord. 9 § 4 (part), 1942) 
8.04.045 - Hearing. 
    At the hearing, the hearing officer shall take testimony of the enforcement officer, the owner of the property, and any interested party. Not more than five days after the completion of hearing, the hearing officer shall render a decision either closing the proceedings or ordering the building or structure demolished, otherwise made safe, or properly maintained. If the hearing officer determines that a building or structure should be demolished, otherwise made safe, or properly maintained, the hearing officer shall so order, fix a time in the order for the owner, agent, or lessee to comply with the order. 
    If the owner, agent, or lessee fails to appear and neglects or refuses to comply with the order issued, the hearing officer shall file a report of the findings and a copy of the order with the city council, not more than five days after noncompliance by the owner and request that necessary action be taken to enforce the order. A copy of the findings and order of the hearing officer shall be served on the owner, agent, or lessee in the manner proscribed in Section 8.04.040. 
(Ord. 892 § 1 (part), 1997) 
8.04.046 - Enforcement of decision made at hearing. 
    The city council shall fix a date not less than thirty (30) days after the hearing proscribed in Section 8.04.045 for a hearing on the findings and order of the hearing officer and shall give notice to the owner, agent, or lessee, in the manner proscribed in Section 8.04.040 of the time and place of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner, agent or lessee shall be given an opportunity to show cause why the order should not be enforced. The city council shall either approve, disapprove or modify the order. If the city council approves or modifies the order, the city council shall take all necessary action to enforce the order. If the order is approved or modified the owner, agent or lessee shall comply with the order within sixty (60) days after the date of the hearing under this section. For an order of demolition, if the city council determines that the building or structure has been substantially destroyed by fire, wind, flood, deterioration, neglect, abandonment, vandalism, or other cause, and the cost of repair of the building or structure will be greater than the state equalized value of the building or structure, the owner, agent or lessee shall comply with the order of demolition within twenty-one (21) days after the date of the hearing. 
    If the estimated cost of repair exceeds the state equalized value of the building or structure to be repaired, a rebuttable presumption that the building or structure requires immediate demolition exists. 
(Ord. 10-03 § 2, 2003: Ord. 892 § 1 (part), 1997) 
8.04.047 - Costs-Remedy. 
    The cost of demolition includes, but is not limited to, fees paid to hearing officers, costs of title searches or commitments used to determine the parties in interest, recording fees for notices and liens filed with the county register of deeds, demolition and dumping charges, court reporter attendance fees and costs of the collection charges authorized under this chapter. The costs of demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior of the building or structure or grounds adjoining the building or structure incurred by the city to bring the property into conformance with this act shall be reimbursed to the city by the owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears. 
    The owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears upon the last local tax assessment records shall be notified by the assessor of the amount of the cost of the demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior of the building or structure or grounds adjoining the building or structure by first class mail at the address shown on the records. If the owner or party in interest fails to pay the cost within thirty (30) days after mailing by the assessor of the notice of the amount of the costs, the city shall have a lien for the cost incurred by the city to bring the property into conformance. The lien shall not take effect until notice of the lien has been filed or recorded. The lien for the cost shall be collected and treated in the same manner as provided for property tax liens under the General Property Tax Act, Act 206 of the Public Acts of 1993, being Sections 211.1 to 211.157 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
    In addition to other remedies, the city may bring an action against the owner of the building or structure for the full cost of the demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior of the building or structure or grounds adjoining the building or structure. The city shall have a lien on the property for the amount of the judgment obtained pursuant hereto. 
(Ord. 10-03 § 3, 2003; Ord. 892 § 1 (part), 1997) 
8.04.050 - Violation of Sections 8.04.010 through 8.04.030-Penalty. 
    Should abatement as proposed by Section 8.04.040 be an impractical or impossible remedy, any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of Sections 8.04.010 through 8.04.030 after having been given notice of such violation, shall, upon conviction, be punishable as set forth in Chapter 1.12 of this code. 
(Ord. 521 § 1, 1973; Ord. 9 § 4 (part), 1942) 
8.04.060 - Violation of Section 8.04.045-Penalty. 
    A person who fails or refuses to comply with an order approved or modified by the city council within the time proscribed by Section 8.04.045 is guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or both. 
(Ord. 892 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 366 § 5, 1965) 
(Ord. No. 01-11, pt. I, 1-11-2011) 
8.04.065 - Appeals. 
    An owner aggrieved by any final decision or order of the city council may appeal the decision or order to the circuit court by filing a petition for an order of superintending control within twenty (20) days from the date of the decision. 
(Ord. 892 § 1 (part), 1997) 
8.04.075 - Declared nuisances-Abatement. 
A.  Declared Nuisances. Any building, vehicle, boat, aircraft or place used for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution or gambling, or used by, or kept for the use of prostitutes or other disorderly persons, or used for the unlawful manufacture, transporting, sale, keeping for sale, bartering or furnishing of any controlled substance as defined in Section 7104 of the Public Health Code, Act No. 368 of the Public Acts of 1978, being Section 333.7104 of the Michigan Compiled Laws, or of any vinous, malt, brewed, fermented, spirituous, or intoxicating liquors or any mixed liquors or beverages, any part of which is intoxicating, is declared a nuisance, and all controlled substances and nuisances shall be enjoined and abated as hereinafter provided, and as provided in the Michigan Court Rules. Any person, or his or her servant, agent, or employee who owns, leases, conducts or maintains any building, vehicle or place used for any of the purposes or acts set forth above is guilty of a nuisance. 
B.  Action to Abate; Parties. The city attorneys of Hazel Park, Michigan, the prosecuting attorney or any citizen of the city, may maintain an action for equitable relief in the name of the city of Hazel Park, upon the relation of such city attorney, prosecuting attorney, or citizen to abate such nuisance and to perpetually enjoin any person, his servant, agent, or employee, who shall own, lease, conduct or maintain such building, vehicle, boat, aircraft or place, from permitting or suffering, such building, vehicle, boat, aircraft or place owned, leased, conducted or maintained by him, or any other building, vehicle, boat aircraft or place conducted or maintained by him to be used for any of the purposes or by any of the persons set forth in subsection A of this section, or for any of the acts enumerated in the section. When the injunction has been granted, it shall be binding on the defendant throughout the judicial circuit in which it was issued. 
C.  Owner of Premises Defined; Authority of Court; Closing of Premises; Vehicles, Parties Defendant. An owner of the premises within the meaning of this section is deemed to be the grantee or vendee of the last recorded deed or contract which describes the premises, or any part thereof upon which any nuisance exists as heretofore defined, and the naming of such person a party defendant gives the court authority to abate the nuisance by closing the premises and such defendant is subject to the order and judgment of the court. 
1.  Owner of Vehicle Defined; Parties Defendant. An owner of a vehicle within the meaning of this section is deemed to be the person in whose name the vehicle is titled and any chattel mortgagee or assignee thereof or other lien holder whose lien has been filed in the office of the register of deeds prior to the commencement of suit, and the plaintiff shall join such mortgagee, assignee or lien holder as party defendant. 
D.  Admissible Evidence; Unnecessary Proof; Judgment and Order. In any action brought under this section, evidence of the general reputation of the building, vehicle, boat, aircraft or place is admissible for the purpose of proving the existence of the nuisance. 
1.  Proof of knowledge of the existence of the nuisance on the part of the defendants or any of them, is not required. 
2.  It is not necessary for the court to find the property involved was being used as and for a nuisance at the time of the hearing, or for the plaintiff to prove that the nuisance was continuing at the time of the filing of the complaint, if the complaint is filed within thirty (30) days after any act, any violation, or the existence of a condition herein defined as a nuisance, but on finding that the material allegations of the complaint are true, the court shall render judgement and order abatement as hereinafter provided. 
E.  Contempt; Punishment, Procedure, Bail. If any order or injunction granted under the provisions of this section is violated, the court may summarily try and punish the offender as for contempt, and the person so offending shall be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by imprisonment in the county jail not more than six months or by both fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. Such violation shall be charged by a motion supported by affidavit, and the court, if satisfied of the sufficiency thereof, shall immediately issue a bench warrant for the arrest of such offender and to bring him before such court to answer for such misconduct. The court may, in its discretion, permit such person arrested to give bail and fix the amount thereof pending hearing of the matters charged in such motion. 
F.  Order of Abatement; Closing of Building, Removal of Contents; Sale; Contempt. If the existence of the nuisance is established in an action as provided in this section, an order of abatement shall be entered as a part of the judgment in the case, which order shall direct the removal from the building or place of all furniture, fixtures and contents therein and shall direct the sale thereof in the manner provided for the sale of chattels under execution, and the effectual closing of the building or place against its use for any purpose, and so keeping it closed for a period of one year, unless sooner released as in this section provided. 
1.  Vehicles, Sale. Any vehicle, boat, or aircraft found by the court to be a nuisance within the meaning of this section, is subject to the same order and judgment as any furniture, fixtures and contents as herein provided. 
2.  Sale of Personal Property; Costs, Liens, Balance to City Treasurer. Upon the sale of any furniture, fixtures, contents, vehicle, boat or aircraft as provided in this section, the officer executing the order of the court shall, after deducting the expenses of keeping such property and costs of such sale, pay all liens according to their priorities which may be established by intervention or otherwise at the hearing or in other proceedings brought for that purpose as being bona fide as having been created without the lien or having any notice that such property was being used or was to be used for the maintenance of a nuisance as herein defined, and shall pay the balance to the city treasurer to be credited to the general fund of the city of Hazel Park. 
3.  Use of Closed Building; Contempt. If any person uses a building or place so directed to be closed, with knowledge that such building or place is closed by order of the court, he shall be punished as for contempt, as provided in subsection E of this section. 
G.  Removal and Sale of Property, Fees; Closing of Building; Loss of Exemptions; Liability of Officers; Fees. For removing and selling the movable property, the officer is entitled to charge and receive the same fees as he would be levying upon and selling like property upon execution, and for closing the building or place and keeping it closed, a reasonable sum shall be allowed by the court. 
1.  Loss of Property Exceptions, Liability of Officers. Any person found guilty of maintaining a nuisance under the provisions of this section shall forfeit the benefit of all property exemptions, so far as the satisfaction of the order or judgment of the court requires the same, and the taking and disposing of any property of the defendant or defendants by virtue of such order or judgment by any officer directed to execute the same is not a trespass nor shall such officers be liable either civilly or criminally therefor, if a proper return of such order or judgment and accounting for such property is made to the court within ten days after the order or judgment is executed. 
H.  Proceeds of Sale of Personal Property, Application. The proceeds of the sale of the personal property, as provided in subsection G of this section shall be applied in payment of the costs of the action and abatement, and the balance, if any, shall be paid to the persons entitled thereto as the court may direct. 
I.  Delivery of Premises to Owner, Bond, Abatement; Liability of Sureties; Appeal; Prerequisite to Deliver. If the owner of such building or place pays all costs of the proceeding, and files a bond with sureties approved by the circuit judge, in the penal sum of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), conditioned that he will immediately abate the nuisance and prevent the same from being established or kept therein within a period of one year from the date of the judgment, the court may order such premises to be delivered to the owner and if the bond is given and costs therein paid before order of abatement, the action shall be thereby abated as to that building only. 
1.  Liability of Sureties. If it appears to the court that the conditions of the bond have been violated, the principal and sureties thereon are liable thereon for the full penalty of the bond in an action brought in the name of the city of Hazel Park, or upon motion in the action in which the bond was given. 
2.  Appeal, Stay or Order of Abatement. Should the defendants, or any of them, appeal to the supreme court from the order and judgment rendered, the injunction or order or abatement shall not be stayed pending the appeal, except that stay may be granted or the order of abatement may be modified pending such appeal upon the written order of two justices of the supreme court. 
(Ord. 02-05 § 1, 2005) 
Chapter 8.09 - FIREWORKS[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, adopted July 24, 2012, repealed the former Ch. 8.09, §§ 8.09.010-8.09.040, and enacted a new Ch. 8.09 as set out herein. The former Ch. 8.09 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 15-02 § 1 (part) of 2002. 

8.09.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "2012 Fireworks Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012) 
8.09.020 - Statement of purpose. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter repeals the provisions of Chapter 8.09 and adopts a new chapter to provide for the regulation of the ignition, discharge and use of consumer fireworks, as allowed under the Michigan Fireworks Safety Act, MCL 28.451 et seq., as amended. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012) 
8.09.030 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall be defined as follows: 
    "APA standard 87-1" means 2001 APA standard 87-1, standard for construction and approval for transportation of fireworks, novelties, and theatrical pyrotechnics, published by the American Pyrotechnics Association of Bethesda, Maryland. 
    "Consumer fireworks" means fireworks devices that are designed to produce visible effects by combustion, that are required to comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations promulgated by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission under 16 CFR parts 1500 and 1507, and that are listed in APA standard 87-1, 3.1.2.3.2.3, or 3.5. Consumer fireworks do not include low-impact fireworks. 
    "Fireworks" means any composition or device, except for a starting pistol, a flare gun, or a flare, designed for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration or detonation. 
    "Low-impact fireworks" means ground and handheld sparkling devices as that phrase is defined under APA standard 87-1. 3.1, 3.1.1.1 to 3.1.1.8, and 3.5. 
    "Minor" means an individual who is less than eighteen (18) years of age. 
    "National holiday" means the following legal public holidays: 
A.  New Year's Day, January 1. 
B.  Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr., the third Monday in January. 
C.  Washington's Birthday, the third Monday in February. 
D.  Memorial Day, the last Monday in May. 
E.  Independence Day, July 4. 
F.  Labor Day, the first Monday in September. 
G.  Columbus Day, the second Monday in October. 
H.  Veteran's Day, November 11. 
I.  Thanksgiving Day, the fourth Thursday in November. 
J.  Christmas Day, December 25. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012) 
8.09.040 - Ignition, discharge and use of consumer fireworks. 
    A person shall not ignite, discharge, or use any consumer fireworks, except on the day preceding, the day of, or the day after a national holiday, and not between the hours of twelve midnight and eight a.m. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 10-13, pt. I, 6-25-2013) 
8.09.050 - Possession of consumer fireworks by minor. 
    A minor shall not possess consumer fireworks. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012) 
8.09.060 - Determination of violation-Seizure. 
    If a police officer determines that a violation of this chapter has occurred, the officer may seize the consumer fireworks as evidence of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012) 
8.09.070 - Penalty. 
A.  A violation of this chapter is a civil infraction, punishable by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus the cost of prosecution. 
B.  Following final disposition of a finding of responsibility for violating this chapter, the city may dispose of or destroy any consumer fireworks retained as evidence in that prosecution. 
C.  In addition to any other penalty, a person that is found responsible for a violation of this chapter shall be required to reimburse the city for the costs of storing, disposing of, or destroying consumer fireworks that were confiscated for a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012) 
8.09.080 - Disturbing the peace. 
    This chapter shall not supersede the provisions of Chapter 9.58 of the Hazel Park Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012) 
8.09.090 - Fire Code. 
    This chapter shall not supersede any provision of Chapter 15.20 of the Hazel Park Fire Prevention Code. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, pt. I, 7-24-2012) 
Chapter 8.10 - WOOD STORAGE 
Sections: 

8.10.010 - Wood usage and definitions. 
A.  Word Usage. When not inconsistent with the context, words in the present tense include the future; words in the plural number include the singular number; and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
B.  Definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. 
    "Eradication" means the elimination of rodents, insects and other pests by means not harmful to the public health, safety and welfare. 
    "Firewood" means wood used for fuel or decorative burning in a fireplace or stove. 
    "Harborage" means any condition which provides shelter or protection for rodents, insects and other pests. 
    "Person" means any person, film, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    "Private premises" means any lot, dwelling, house, building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for residential, commercial or industrial purposes, whether inhabited or uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any lands adjacent thereto under common ownership as that of the ownership of the structure. 
(Ord. 13-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
8.10.020 - Storage on private premises. 
    No person shall store firewood or maintain a woodpile on private premises unless: 
A.  The storage of firewood or woodpile is kept stacked and reasonably secure, no higher than five feet measured from the ground. 
B.  The storage of firewood or woodpile is raised at least eighteen (18) inches off the ground. 
C.  The storage of firewood or woodpile is stored in such a manner that it will not provide for the harborage of rodents, insects or other pests. 
(Ord. 13-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
8.10.030 - Screening and standards. 
    All storage of firewood or woodpile(s) shall be placed and stored in the rear yard only and shall be completely screened or hidden from view from any public street, right-of-way. 
    Storage shall not constitute an area greater than ten percent of a residential rear yard. 
    Storage or display shall not occupy any area intended or designed for pedestrian use, required parking area nor required front yard. 
(Ord. 13-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
8.10.040 - Violation and penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall upon being found responsible be fined three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each violation thereof. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 13-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
8.10.050 - Nuisance per se and injunctive relief. 
    A violation of any regulation contained in this chapter is determined to be detrimental to the health, safety and general welfare of the residents, property owners and other persons within the city, and is deemed a public nuisance per se. Any violation of this chapter shall constitute a basis for injunctive relief against the violator or land owner to restrain and prohibit the violator or owner from continuing the violation, in addition to any other relief or penalty provided by this chapter or allowed by law. 
(Ord. 13-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 8.16 - DRIVE-IN RESTAURANTS 
Sections: 

8.16.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words shall have the following meanings in this chapter: 
    "Drive-in restaurant" means any establishment where food, sandwiches, and/or beverages are served directly to or permitted to be consumed by patrons in automobiles, on motorcycles or in other motor vehicles parked on the premises. 
    "Waste material" means paper cups, straws, napkins, garbage, beverages and all other waste matter intended for disposal which, if not placed in a proper receptacle, tends to create a nuisance by rendering property unclean, unsafe and unsightly. 
(Ord. 394 § 1, 1966) 
8.16.020 - Duties of owner and/or manager. 
A.  It shall be the duty of the owner and/or manager of a drive-in restaurant to keep the premises whereon said restaurant is located, together with the parking area of the drive-in restaurant, free from all rubbish, waste products and debris, including waste material, at all times. Each drive-in restaurant shall be provided with a sufficient number of suitable containers to hold such waste material until the same is removed from the premises. 
B.  The owner and/or manager of any drive-in restaurant shall at least once every twenty-four (24) hours dispose of waste materials deposited by drive-in customers on the premises. 
C.  The owner and/or manager of any drive-in restaurant shall not knowingly permit waste materials to be blown from his or her drive-in restaurant onto the public right-of-way or adjoining private premises. 
(Ord. 394 § 2, 1966) 
8.16.030 - Noise prohibited. 
A.  The owner and/or manager of any drive-in restaurant shall not permit disorderly or immoral conduct or loitering upon the premises. 
B.  No person on the premises of a drive-in restaurant, whether in or out of a motor vehicle, shall consume, have in his or her possession or under his or her control, any beer, wine or intoxicating beverage. 
C.  No person or persons on the premises of a drive-in restaurant shall race the motor of any motor vehicle, needlessly bring to a sudden start or stop any motor vehicle, blow any horn or make or cause to be made any other loud or unseemly noise, nuisance or disturbance whereby the quiet and good order of the premises or of the neighborhood is disturbed. 
D.  No person or persons shall place, throw or deposit any waste material upon the outside premises or parking area of a drive-in restaurant or on any street, alley or adjoining property, except in adequate receptacles provided for that purpose. 
E.  It is unlawful for any number of persons to congregate for any time whatsoever at any location on the premises of a drive-in restaurant other than in the restaurant building, or in a legally parked motor vehicle. Any person so congregating shall be deemed guilty of loitering. 
F.  No person shall drive a motor vehicle onto the premises of a drive-in restaurant and then from the premises without parking such motor vehicle and seeking service, unless there is no unoccupied parking space available on the premises. It shall be the duty of the owner and/or manager of a drive-in restaurant to post on the premises in a conspicuous location, one or more signs bearing the following legend: "CRUISING AND GATHERING OUT SIDE OF MOTOR VEHICLE UNLAWFUL." 
(Ord. 394 § 3, 1966) 
8.16.040 - Wall required when-Exception. 
    Every drive-in restaurant hereafter erected or located on a lot, any part of which adjoins residential property, shall be enclosed on the lot line so adjoining or abutting the residential property by a solid, decorative masonry wall at least five feet in height and approved by the city building department. 
    The board of appeals on zoning of the city may modify the aforementioned wall requirement where, because of unusual circumstances or conditions, undue hardship would be suffered and no good purpose would be served by strict compliance thereto. 
(Ord. 394 § 4(a), 1966) 
8.16.050 - Compliance with zoning ordinance. 
    Every drive-in restaurant within the meaning of this chapter shall be required to comply with the provisions of the Hazel Park zoning ordinance, codified in Title 17 of this code. 
(Ord. 394 § 4(b), 1966) 
8.16.060 - Restaurant license-Issuance-Revocation. 
A.  The city clerk shall have the authority to refuse to issue a restaurant license to a drive-in restaurant, and licenses issued may be revoked or suspended by the city clerk at any time, for any of the following reasons: 
1.  Fraud, misrepresentation or any false statement contained in the application for license or made in the operation of a business; 
2.  Operating in violation of this chapter or of any other governing law, ordinance or regulation; 
3.  Operating so as to constitute a nuisance by reason of noise, disorderly conduct or immoral activity on the business premises. 
B.  Written notice of revocation or suspension, stating the causes therefor, shall be delivered to a licensee personally or by mail to his or her address stated in his or her application for license. 
(Ord. 394 § 5(a), (b), 1966) 
8.16.070 - License-Hearing. 
    Any person whose license is revoked or any person whose application for a license is refused shall have the right to a hearing before the council, provided a written request therefor is filed with the city clerk within ten days following the delivery of mailing or notice of revocation or within ten days following such refusal. The council may affirm or reverse any action of the city clerk, and the council may grant or reinstate any license. 
(Ord. 394 § 5(c), 1966) 
8.16.090 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision or provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction of such violation, be punished by a fine of not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment of not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. 
    Each day on which any such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 394 § 7, 1966) 
Chapter 8.27 - STANDING OR PARKING OF COMMERCIAL VEHICLES 
Sections: 

8.27.010 - Definitions. 
    "Commercial vehicle" means a motor vehicle designed to transport sixteen (16) or more passengers, including the driver, a motor vehicle, having a gross vehicle weight rating of twenty-six thousand one (26,001) or more pounds; a motor vehicle with a gross combination weight rating of twenty-six thousand one (26,00l) pounds or more including a towed unit with a gross vehicle weight rating of more than ten thousand (10,000) pounds, or a motor vehicle carrying hazardous material and on which is required to be posted a placard as defined and required under 40 C.F.R. parts 100 to 199. A commercial motor vehicle does not include a vehicle used exclusively to transport personal possessions or family members for non-business purposes. 
    "Parking or standing" means the parking of a commercial vehicle, whether occupied or not, on private property, when not loading or unloading, except when making necessary repairs. 
(Ord. 11-06 § 1 (part), 2006) 
8.27.020 - Standing or parking of commercial vehicles on private property. 
    No person, partnership, corporation, limited liability company or other entity, except as otherwise provided in this section, shall permit or cause a commercial vehicle, as defined in this chapter, to stand or park on private property, when contiguous to residential property, while its engine is operating. 
(Ord. 11-06 § 1 (part), 2006) 
8.27.030 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates this chapter shall be responsible for a civil infraction, and shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. 11-06 § 1 (part), 2006) 
Chapter 8.28 - VEHICLE STORAGE 
Sections: 

8.28.010 - Vehicle storage on private property. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  "Open storage" means the short or long-term parking or placement of any vehicle, as defined, upon private property that is not within a code-approved accessory garage. 
2.  "Vehicle" means any automobile, truck, van or motorcycle upon, or by which, any person or property is or may be transported or drawn on a highway, except those which are moved exclusively by human power, which are regulated under the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages. 
B.  No person, partnership, corporation or other entity, except as otherwise noted in this section, shall permit or cause a vehicle, as defined in this section, to be stored in the open upon private property unless the vehicle is: 
1.  Currently in operable condition and eligible for street use in accordance with the requirement of the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages; 
2.  Parked in a legal off-street parking area upon a hardtop surface as enumerated in Chapter 17.45 of the zoning ordinance; parking on unimproved surfaces, including but not limited to grass, dirt, gravel or any other surface that is not code-approved asphalt or concrete is prohibited. 
C.  All other vehicles must be stored within a completely enclosed structure which meets all aspects of the city code pertaining to the construction and maintenance of accessory buildings. 
D.  An automobile repair business is not permitted to store vehicles in the open unless all of the following criteria are met: 
1.  The vehicle is currently licensed for use upon the public highways; 
2.  The vehicle is under a current work order for repair at the site in question; 
3.  The repair business is licensed by both the city and state to conduct automotive repairs at the site in question; 
4.  The open storage is in compliance with all provisions of the Hazel Park zoning ordinance and is not conducted on any required off-street parking area(s). 
    No vehicle may be stored in the open at an automotive repair business in excess of thirty (30) days. 
E.  Automotive repairs in residential districts are limited to passenger vehicles that are currently licensed for use upon the public highways and are registered to a resident of the dwelling at which the repairs are occurring. 
1.  Minor Repairs. Limited to fluid changes, tune-ups, tire changes and those repairs not requiring major disassembly or overhaul may be performed in the legal off-street parking area of the dwelling; provided, that such repairs are completed within twenty-four (24) hours of their initiation, and, that such repairs do not become a nuisance to the neighborhood in terms of improper disposal of fluids or parts, noise or emissions. 
2.  Major Repairs. Including but not limited to engine replacement or overhaul, transmission replacement or overhaul, or other repairs requiring major disassembly, overhaul or body work must be performed inside a completely enclose structure, which meets all aspects of the city code pertaining to the construction and maintenance of accessory buildings; provided, that such repairs do not become a nuisance to the neighborhood in terms of noise, noxious odors, improper storage or disposal of parts, or emissions; whereby the city police, fire or code enforcement department may order such repair activity to be modified or ceased to eliminate the nuisance. 
3.  Automotive repairs in residential areas are prohibited from eleven p.m. until eight a.m. 
F.  Parking lots, easements, alleys and yards may not be utilized for the display or offering of vehicles for sale. A residential driveway may be utilized for the display or offering of a vehicle for sale as hereinafter set forth: 
1.  No more than one passenger vehicle may be offered for sale at any time. No more than two passenger vehicles may be displayed or offered for sale in any twelve (12) month period, provided that the vehicle being displayed or offered for sale is currently titled in the name of the resident of the premises; the vehicle is currently in operable condition and eligible for street use in accordance with the requirements of the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages; and is parked in a legal off-street parking area upon a hardtop surface as enumerated in Title 17, Hazel Park zoning ordinance, as amended. 
G.  A vehicle found to be in violation of this section is declared to be a nuisance per se, and, as such, may be impounded by the city, at cost to the property and/or vehicle owner; provided that notice of the impending impoundment shall be placed on the vehicle and/or posted at the premises a minimum of forty-eight (48) hours prior to the impoundment. All impending impoundments under this section shall be conducted in conjunction with the requirements of the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages regulating vehicle impoundment, including, but not limited to, the filing of a police report, entry on the law enforcement information network and all attendant notifications. 
H.  Violation-First Offense. Violations of this section are determined to be a civil infraction. The penalty, upon a finding of responsibility of any part of this section for each particular automobile shall be a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
I.  Violation-Second Offense. Violations of this section are determined to be a civil infraction. The penalty, upon a second or more finding of responsibility for violations of any part of this section for each particular automobile shall be a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
J.  City police and code enforcement officers are empowered to issue citations for violations of this section. 
(Ord. 05-03 § 1, 2003; Ord. 7-00 § 1, 2000: Ord. 936 (part), 1998) 
Chapter 8.29 - SOLID WASTE REGULATION AND DISPOSAL 
Sections: 
Article I. - General Provisions 

8.29.010 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms in this chapter shall be as follows: 
    "Ashes" means residue from fires used for cooking, heating building and/or incinerators. 
    "Builder's or contractor's refuse" means all forms of refuse generated from building construction, alterations or repairs by contractors or tradesmen. 
    "Bulk refuse" means items too large to handle in the regular rubbish truck, such as bedsprings and discharged furniture, appliances, tools and similar goods commonly known as "junk," except builder's or contractor's refuse as defined in this section. 
    "Curbside recycling collection" means the regular collection of newspaper and yard recyclables at the point of generation by an authorized agent of the city. 
    "Dead animals" means carcasses of animals, fowl or fish. 
    "Director" means the person in charge of the department of public works, or any individual designated by the city council to administer the terms of this chapter. 
    "Garbage" means animal, vegetable or fruit waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of foods and all other putrescible solid waste, but not dead animals or manure. 
    "Hazardous refuse" means volatile cleaning fluids, solvents, chemicals, acids, caustics, explosives, poisons, drugs, radioactive materials, containers of kerosene, fuel oil, crankcase oils, antifreeze, cutting oils, paints, lacquers or turpentine, and refuse of a similar nature. 
    "Newspaper" means newsprint only and shall not include magazines, glossy advertisements, cardboard, corrugated boxes or wrapping paper. 
    "Production or processing refuse" means all forms of waste generated from production, processing or manufacturing processes. 
    "Recycling container" means a durable or disposable storage container approved by the director or his or her designee for collecting yard recyclables. A durable container shall be identified with a city-approved sticker entitled "Yard Recyclables." 
    "Refuse" means all forms of waste as defined in this section, except newspaper and yard recyclables as defined in this section. 
    Refuse, Combustible. "Combustible refuse" means garbage, plastic, glass, bottles, dust, sweeping, bedding, hair, cardboard, corrugated boxes, wastepaper, wrapping paper, books, phone books, magazines, rags, wood, rubber, leather and similar refuse from residences and businesses, except builder's or contractor's refuse or production or processing refuse as defined in this section. 
    Refuse, Noncombustible. "Noncombustible refuse" means bottles, crockery, tin cans, any kind of wire, metal, automobile parts (except engines, transmissions or other automobile parts containing fluid), broken kitchenware, bedsprings and mattresses, masonry materials, yard waste, yard recyclables, portions of trees or limbs and other similar refuse from residences and businesses. 
    "Rubbish" means nonputrescible waste, excluding ashes, consisting of both combustible and noncombustible refuse or litter of any kind that is not detrimental to the public health and safety. 
    "Salvage material" means all forms of discarded or used materials, parts or matter that can be reused. 
    "Solid waste" means all forms of refuse as defined in this section, including newspaper and yard recyclables as defined in this section. 
    "Solid waste container" means a durable or disposable container approved by the director or his or her designee for collecting solid waste, except yard recyclables. 
    "Stored material" means all forms of materials that are stored for any purpose. 
    "Yard waste" means tree branches, logs, stumps, bushes," heavy-brush shrub clippings, sticks, vines, rocks, dirt, and general hard and garden waste, except leaves, shredded or small twigs, grass clippings, weeds, wood chips, garden produce, and old potting soil free of other debris. 
    "Yard recyclables" means leaves, shredded or small twigs, grass clippings, wood chips, garden vegetables and old potting soil free of other debris. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.020 - Duty of collection. 
    The city shall collect and dispose of all solid waste ashes, bulk refuse, garbage, newspaper, combustible and noncombustible refuse, rubbish, yard waste and yard recyclables, except builder's or contractor's refuse, production or processing refuse, and hazardous refuse, when properly prepared and placed for collection according to the regulations promulgated pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.030 - Arrangement of collection schedules. 
    The director shall be authorized to establish a schedule for collecting all solid waste throughout the city. Such schedule shall provide one collection weekly for residences and businesses, not to exceed five each week. Special arrangement may be made by the director for those businesses and multi-unit residences requiring more frequent service. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.040 - Solid waste fee. 
A.  A fee(s) for solid waste collection and disposal shall be charged to those owners of property receiving services under the terms of this chapter. Such fee shall be determined by a resolution of the city council. 
B.  Such fee(s) shall be provided for in the fiscal budget adopted by the city council or as to be amended, and established by resolution, and shall be certified to the assessor and assessed against the premises served. The fees shall be collected or returned in the same manner as the municipal taxes are certified, assessed, collected and returned as set forth in the City Charter. 
C.  Such fee(s) may be changed, as conditions may require, by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
Article II. - Rules and Regulations 

8.29.050 - Preparation of additional regulations for collection-Posting. 
    The director shall prepare and, when approved by the city council, post and cause to be distributed to every household and business, reasonable regulations, to be in addition to and not in conflict with the rules and regulations of this chapter and this code, concerning the days of collection of solid waste, the type and size of solid waste and recycling solid waste containers, the location and place for collection and such other regulations pertaining to the collection and disposal of solid waste as the city may deem advisable. Such regulations shall become effective when approved by resolution of the city council and after distribution and posting thereof. The regulations shall be posted at the police station and at the city hall. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.060 - Scattering prohibited. 
    No person shall by himself or herself, or by any other, scatter, leave, distribute or deposit, except in proper containers, any form of solid waste in any street, alley, park or on any public place or upon the property of another within the corporate limits of the city. No paper, lawn cuttings or rakings, leaves, weeds, ashes or any other solid waste or hazardous waste, builder's or contractor's production or processing refuses shall be thrown or swept into any right-of-way, street, gutter, intake, alley vacant lot other public property or private property of another. 
(Ord. 01-04 § 1, 2004: Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.070 - Responsibility and enforcement for accumulated solid waste on occupied private property. 
A.  It shall be the duty of every proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of any occupied private property to maintain at all times such property in a clean and orderly condition, permitting no deposit or accumulation of solid waste, other than those materials ordinarily attendant upon the day-to-day use for which such property is legally intended. 
B.  If any solid waste is allowed to accumulate, other than in proper containers or as an approved compost pile, on any occupied private property, or upon any sidewalk or boulevard, or in the alley or rear thereof, the proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant shall remove such solid waste forthwith. 
C.  The director or his or her designee may order the proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of such occupied private property to remove such solid waste by seven a.m. of the following day. The order to remove such solid waste shall be either served upon the proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of such property, or posted in a conspicuous place on the property. If such solid waste is not removed by seven a.m. of the following day, the director or his or her designee shall cause it to be removed and disposed of by city personnel or by contractors, and the cost thereof, including inspections and the cost of the notice, shall be paid by the proprietor. If such cost is not paid within thirty (30) days of the mailing of a bill to the proprietor of the property as shown in the latest tax or assessment roll, the cost shall be assessed against the property in the manner provided by Section 11.4, of the Charter of the city. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.080 - Responsibility and enforcement for accumulated solid waste on vacant private property.
