    The proprietor of any vacant private property, as reflected in the rolls maintained by the city assessor, shall cause any solid waste that accumulates on the proprietor's property, or on the sidewalk or boulevard in front of such property, or in the alley or in the rear thereof, to be removed forthwith upon notice by the director or his or her designee. A letter mailed to the proprietor's address shown on the most recent assessment or tax roll shall constitute due notice. If such solid waste is not removed within ten days after the notice is mailed, the director or his or her designee shall cause it to be removed and disposed of by city personnel or by contractors; and the cost thereof, including inspections and the cost of the notice, shall be paid by the proprietor. If such cost is not paid within thirty (30) days of the mailing of a bill to the proprietor of the property as shown in the latest tax or assessment roll, the cost shall be assessed against the property in the manner provided by Section 11.4 of the Charter of the city. If the chief of police, fire chief, health officer, building inspector or the director or his or her designee determines that such solid waste presents an immediate danger to the health, safety or welfare, the director shall cause the solid waste to be removed forthwith utilizing any reasonable means to effectuate such removal; and the cost of such inspections, notices, removal and disposal shall be paid by the proprietor or assessed against the property in the manner provided herein above. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.090 - Storage of solid waste-Containers. 
A.  Solid waste, salvage or stored material shall be so stored at all times so that it cannot serve as a harbor for rats or other vermin. Plastic bags shall not be considered suitable storage containers for solid waste, salvage or storage material; however, yard recyclables may be stored in plastic bags. 
B.  Loose paper and other loose material shall be stored in closed containers so that it cannot be scattered by the wind or by other means, and in such a manner that it cannot become a fire hazard. 
C.  No garbage, foodstuff or other matter that will attract flies, rats or other vermin shall be allowed to remain exposed at any time on any property. 
D.  All containers containing solid waste stored for future disposal or collection by the department of public services shall be in a watertight receptacle, sealed such that the passage of flies, insects, animals, vermin, gasses and odors is precluded. 
E.  No person other than the proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of any property for which solid waste and recyclable containers are stored or kept or the authorized agents, employees or licensees of the city shall disturb such containers or remove their seals or contents thereof. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.100 - Preparation for collection. 
A.  Garbage. Before placing garbage in a solid waste container for collection, each and every proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of any private property shall first drain water from the garbage and wrap the garbage in paper so that the solid waste container contains relatively dry paper packages of garbage. Wrapped garbage may be placed in a solid waste container containing other combustible refuse, provided such container has a watertight cover. 
B.  Food Containers. Plastic, metal and glass food containers shall be drained of excess liquids and may be placed separately or together with garbage. All food containers not thoroughly washed and cleaned and containing any portion of food or other material subject to rapid decomposition shall be placed in solid waste containers with watertight covers. 
C.  Ashes. Ashes shall be cooled, dried and placed in separate solid waste containers. 
D.  Bulk Refuse. Certain refuse that is not placed in an approved solid waste container will be collected by the department of public works or its designee as follows: 
1.  Bulk combustible refuse must be compressed and securely tied with nonmetallic material in bundles weighing not more than sixty (60) pounds, not longer than three feet in length, and not longer than eighteen (18) inches in diameter. 
2.  Bulk noncombustible refuse must be compressed and securely tied in bundles not heavier than sixty (60) pounds. 
3.  Furniture, bedsprings, mattresses, large kitchen and laundry appliances will be collected on the scheduled collection day. Doors to kitchen and laundry appliances shall be removed prior to collection. 
E.  Hazardous Refuse. No hazardous refuse will be collected by the department of public works. 
F.  Open Containers. Cans, receptacles, containers of any description shall be broken open before being placed in a solid waste container with noncombustible refuse. Containers that cannot be broken must be treated as noncombustible refuse. 
G.  Other Noncombustible Refuse. Other noncombustible refuse shall be placed in separate solid waste containers so that the nature of the refuse contained therein is plainly evident to the collector. 
H.  Yard Waste-All Branches, Logs, Stumps, Bushes, Heavy Brush, etc. All logs and stumps shall be placed between the curb and the sidewalk in separate and neat piles before seven a.m. of the scheduled collection day. All such materials shall be cut into such sizes that it can be handled by a single collector. Branches must be no larger than four inches in diameter and no longer than twelve (12) feet; all butt ends must be placed in the direction of normal vehicular travel. Any branches larger than four inches in diameter will be considered logs the same as tree stumps, and shall be cut into four-foot lengths. All soil and roots must be removed from stumps. Rose bushes or branches with thorns or needles shall be cut and packed in a suitable throw-away container that can be handled by one collector and set out for collection with other solid waste. Vines shall be cut and tied in bundles no larger than eighteen (18) inches in diameter and no more than thirty-six (36) inches in length and set out for collection with other solid waste. Loose brush shall be placed in a throw-away container than can be handled by one collector. 
I.  Yard Recyclables. Yard recyclables shall be placed in recycling containers or biodegradable bags approved by the director or his or her designee. The combined weight of any recycling container and its contents shall not exceed sixty (60) pounds. 
J.  Newspapers. Newspapers shall be separately accumulated, securely and neatly bundled, and tied in packages not exceeding twenty-five (25) pounds. Newspapers shall not be placed in solid waste or recycling containers. 
(Ord. 09-03 § 1, 2003; Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.110 - Unauthorized collection of solid waste prohibited. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person unauthorized by the city to collect or pick up, or cause to be collected or picked up, solid waste set out for city collection. Each collection in violation hereof from any collection point or stop shall constitute a separate, distinct offense. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.120 - Containers-Responsibility for furnishing. 
A.  The proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of any private property shall provide and maintain suitable containers for storing all forms of solid waste generated on such property. 
B.  The head of each household residing in a building arranged for one or two families shall provide his or her household unit with approved solid waste containers sufficient to hold all solid waste generated by his or her own household between regular collection periods. 
C.  The owner of any building arranged for three or more families shall provide and maintain approved solid waste containers sufficient to hold all solid waste generated by the occupants of the building between regular collection periods. 
D.  Each corporation, partnership, proprietorship or other entity having a place of business within the city shall provide and maintain the place of business with approved solid waste containers sufficient to hold all solid waste generated by the business between regular collection periods. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.130 - Solid waste containers-Specifications for approval. 
A.  Containers for Ashes. Containers for ashes shall be constructed of sturdy metal or plastic and have adequate handles to prevent spillage. 
B.  Containers for Garbage. Containers for garbage or for food containers shall be galvanized iron or other nonrusting metal of substantial construction or plastic with tight-fitting metal or plastic covers, be watertight, have adequate handles, and be of such size for one collector to handle easily. Such containers shall have a capacity between ten to thirty-five (35) gallons, and its contents shall not exceed sixty (60) pounds. Such containers shall be kept tightly covered at all times and be maintained in fly and vermin-proof condition. 
C.  Containers for Other Combustible Refuse. Containers for the storage of refuse and other combustible material shall be of substantial material approved by the director, have adequate handles, and be of such size to be easily handled by one collector, and in no case shall the container and its contents exceed sixty (60) pounds. The director may approve such containers as in his or her discretion meet the intention and requirements of this chapter. 
D.  Plastic Bags. Plastic bags of approved quality shall be deemed a suitable container for solid waste, provided that the bags are securely sealed, not punctured, and filled so that the contents will not cause tearing or rupturing of the bag when it is lifted at the sealed or tied end. For yard recyclables, plastic bags shall be biophotodegradable. 
E.  Recycling Containers for Yard Recyclables. Recycling containers for yard recyclables shall be durable or disposable as approved by the rector or his or her designee. 
F.  Improper Containers. Any container that does not conform to the provisions of this chapter or that may have ragged or sharp edges or any other defects liable to hamper or injure the collector shall promptly be replaced with an approved container upon receipt of notice by the director or his or her designee to the responsible person or his or her agent. If the container is not replaced within ten days after receipt of such notice, such nonconforming or defective container shall be disposed of by the department of public services along with the other solid waste. 
G.  Containers to be Kept Sanitary. Solid waste and recyclable containers are to be kept in a sanitary condition by the users thereof. Failure to maintain such containers in a sanitary condition after notice by the director or his or her designee will be sufficient reason for refusing to pick up the solid waste on the next collection day. 
(Ord. 09-03 § 2, 2003; Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.140 - Location of solid waste and recycling containers-Composting of yard recyclables-Hours of placement for collection-Removal of such containers-Enforcement. 
A.  Between each collection period the proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of any property shall provide a suitable place on such property to store solid waste. Solid waste and recycling containers shall be placed and protected so that they cannot be easily disturbed by animals; and shall be placed at the rear of each building or structure at a place that is reasonably inconspicuous and away from places occupied by other persons and from streets. 
B.  Yard recyclables may be composted provided that the accumulation of same does not exceed one hundred twenty-five (125) cubic feet and does not emit offensive odor or impair the health, comfort or welfare of the people. 
C.  Solid waste shall be set out on designated collection days and at such places as shall be specified in the solid waste regulations approved by the city council. For weekday collection, solid waste shall not be placed in any street prior to four p.m. of the day preceding the scheduled collection day; nor shall it be placed in any street on Sunday or on a holiday prior to nine p.m., except by arrangement with the director or his or her designee. 
D.  The director or his or her designee may order the proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of any private property to remove forthwith solid waste placed out for collection in violation of this chapter. The order to remove such solid waste shall be either served upon one of the above occupants of the private premises or posted in a conspicuous place thereat. Should another violation of this chapter occur at such property, the rector or his or her designee may cause such solid waste be removed; and the cost thereof, including inspections and notice shall be paid by the proprietor or assessed against the property in the manner provided by Section 11.4 of the Charter of the city. 
E.  Once emptied, solid waste and recycling containers placed in any street shall be promptly removed therefrom by the proprietor, tenant, lessee or occupant of any property. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.150 - Permission required for dumping sand, gravel, dirt, etc. 
A.  No sand, gravel, dirt or similar material shall be dumped upon any street, alley, sidewalk, crosswalk or any public property; nor may any cement, mortar or other material be mixed upon any street, sidewalk or crosswalk without a permit issued by the director or his or her designee. Such permit shall provide for the removal of such materials and related equipment with a reasonable time. 
B.  No sand, gravel, dirt or similar material shall be dumped upon any private property without the landowner's express permission. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.160 - Cleaning up builder's refuse-Assessment against property. 
A.  The landowner and the contractor involved in any construction or repair work shall remove from the premises within a reasonable time after the work is completed, surplus construction material and all refuse building material. 
B.  If the refuse is not removed within forty-eight (48) hours after notice is given to the owner, or contractor of the city, the director or his or her designee may order such refuse to be removed; and the cost thereof to be assessed against the land as provided in Section 11.4 of the City Charter. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.161 - Waste dumpsters in residential districts. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  "Dumpster" is defined as a metal storage receptacle used to temporarily store debris or garbage and which is then emptied of its contents or removed with its contents to a dumpsite. 
2.  "Temporary dumpster" is defined as any dumpster used or intended as a disposal facility for construction, renovation, or demolition projects, special events, seasonal use, or other purposes not permanent in nature. 
B.  Dumpster or similar commercial containers for the storage of construction debris or other waste are permitted in any residential district in the city only under the following conditions: 
1.  Prior to the issuance of any permit for any dumpster or temporary dumpster, its location and usage shall be reviewed and approved by the city. 
C.  A permit for a dumpster or temporary dumpster shall be for an initial term of not more than thirty (30) days. Provided the applicant is in compliance with all provision of this article and all other applicable city regulations, renewal permits may be approved and issued for an additional thirty (30) day period upon application and payment of the permit renewal fee. New construction of a dwelling may be allowed for no more than six months, but may be renewed for like periods. The dumpster or temporary dumpster shall be removed prior to the expiration of the permit. 
D.  The following requirements shall apply to any dumpster or temporary dumpster: 
1.  No dumpster or temporary dumpster may be placed on any arterial or collector roads in the city; within forty (40) feet of an intersection; or within any prohibited or restricted areas. 
E.  Sufficient reflective tape shall be placed upon all four (4) sides of the dumpster or temporary dumpster in such a manner as to make it visible at night. 
F.  No dumpster or temporary dumpster shall be placed nearer than fifteen (15) feet to any fire hydrant within the cartway or other area intended for fire-fighting equipment. 
G.  The name, address, and telephone number of the dumpster or temporary dumpster, owner/operator shall be conspicuously placed on at least two sides of the device. 
H.  The location of any dumpster or temporary dumpster upon any public street shall not interfere with any required clear sight distance across any intersection. 
I.  The location of any dumpster or temporary dumpster upon any public street shall not obstruct any pedestrian way or the travel lane of any public street. 
J.  No dumpster or temporary dumpster shall be loaded in such a manner as to cause its contents to spill onto any street, sidewalk, or other area intended for pedestrian travel. 
K.  No dumpster or temporary dumpster shall contain any hazardous waste unless pursuant to a permit for such waste issued by the appropriate governmental entity. 
L.  No materials contained in a dumpster or temporary dumpster shall emit any noxious or offensive odor or otherwise create any hazard or risk to public health. 
M.  No dumpster or temporary dumpster shall be placed in such a manner as to interfere with the operation or maintenance of any public utility. 
N.  The permit shall be conspicuously placed in a location that permits it to be identified from a public street. 
O.  The placement of any dumpster shall be located only on the driveway of the property, and shall not be located upon any street or within any required yard or setback unless specifically approved by the city. If there is no driveway, permission must be obtained from the fire department and the police department to place the dumpster on the front yard. All debris or other waste materials shall be fully contained within the dumpster or other container. The dumpster or other container shall be emptied or otherwise removed from the site as needed to prevent overflow, and otherwise maintained so as to minimize unsightly appearances to neighboring properties. If rodents appear around the dumpster, the homeowner must cure the problem within twenty-four (24) hours. If the problem is not cured, the city may cure the problem at the homeowner's expense. 
P.  If any damage or injury to the cartway, street, curb or sidewalk shall be caused or done by the use or occupancy, the party to whom such permit shall have been issued shall be responsible and liable for the same and shall restore the cartway, street, curb and/or sidewalk to its original condition. If the permittee refuses to properly restore the cartway, street, curb and/or sidewalk to its original condition, the city may do so and collect the cost of the same from the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 07-16, pt. 1, 10-11-2016) 
8.29.165 - Cleaning up refuse-Court ordered put outs. 
A.  The owner, property manager and/or agent involved in the cleaning, repair and/or removal of any items of personal property, junk, debris, garbage, and/or building materials, referred to herein as refuse, upon vacation of the premises by the previous occupant or upon eviction of the previous owner or occupant, shall remove all items from the property and immediately dispose of the same. No garbage, junk, debris, personal property or building materials shall be left on the property or at the curb for pick up unless said items conform to the requirements of this chapter and are properly placed at the curb on the designated trash pick up day. 
B.  If the refuse is not removed within twenty-four (24) hours of notice being placed on the building by the city, the items shall be removed by the city and the cost thereof to be assessed against the land as provided in Section 11.4 of the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 02-09, pt. I, 8-25-2009) 
Article III. - Private Collectors 

8.29.170 - Solid waste collectors-License required-Hours of Operation. 
    No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting or disposing of solid waste within the city without first obtaining a license therefor. Licenses shall be issued upon application to the city clerk's office on forms provided by the office and upon payment of such fee as shall be required by resolution of the city council. No such license shall be issued except upon certification by the director or his or her designee that the equipment and the ability of the licensee is such that the licensee is able to conduct a solid waste collection business according to the terms of this chapter and rules and regulations adopted by the city council. The director shall make such rules and regulations governing the operation of the business of solid waste collection, transportation and disposition as he or she may deem necessary. The city manager or his or her designee shall revoke, upon notice and an opportunity to be heard, the license of any solid waste collection that fails to abide by any such rule or regulation adopted by the city council or any provision of this chapter. Prior revocation of a license shall be sufficient grounds for the refusal by the director or his or her designee to certify any future application by such licensee. The collection of bundled newspaper at the curb through the city's newspaper recycling program shall be done only be designated licensees as directed by the director or his or her designee. Collecting bundled newspaper by licensees other than those so designated shall constitute sufficient grounds for revoking the license of the offending solid waste collector. 
B.  No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting or disposing of solid waste within the city between the hours of six p.m. and seven a.m., Monday through Saturday, and all day on Sunday. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.180 - Construction and identification of vehicles. 
    No person engaged in the business of collecting, transporting and disposing of solid waste shall do so in the city except with watertight covered vehicles, which shall be plainly marked or designed as the police chief and the director or his or her designee may prescribe. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.190 - Special written permission required for dumping. 
    No solid waste shall be dumped on public or private property within the city, except by permission of the director or his or her designee. 
(Ord. 839 § 1 (part), 1992) 
8.29.200 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be responsible for a civil infraction and subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. 01-04 § 2, 2004) 
Article IV. - Recyclable Materials 

8.29.300 - Recyclables collection. 
    Every occupant, resident or responsible party, including an owner of any real property within the City of Hazel Park, shall use the following procedures to set out recyclables. Recyclables are not to be mixed with any other waste as any time. 
1.  Eligible recyclables must be separated from refuse and set out for placement on the designated collection day using containers provided by SOCCRA which may be obtained at the city's department of public work, and in accordance with SOCCRA rules and regulations. Excess recyclables and corrugated cardboard shall be set out beside the container in a manner otherwise set forth by SOCCRA. 
2.  Weight Limits. The weight of any loaded container of recyclables shall not exceed sixty (60) pounds. Mechanically lifted rolling carts may be used only with prior permission from SOCCRA. 
(Ord. No. 12-11, pt. I, 11-26-2011) 
8.29.310 - Scavenging of authorized recyclable materials prohibited. 
    No person other than the owner of refuse or recyclables or agent, or employees of licensees of the city shall disturb, remove or attempt to remove refuse or recyclables in containers or bags, or disturb, remove or attempt to remove any recyclables not in containers whether same is on public or private property. This section does not apply to police officers or law enforcement officials who are lawfully engaged in their duties. 
(Ord. No. 12-11, pt. I, 11-26-2011) 
8.29.320 - Violation; penalty. 
    Any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation violating the provisions of Sections 8.29.300 to 8.29.310 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus costs and/or imprisonment not more than ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 12-11, pt. I, 11-26-2011) 
Chapter 8.32 - POSTING SIGNS AND DEPOSITING MATERIALS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY 
Sections: 

8.32.010 - Posting sign prohibited-Exception. 
    No person, corporation, or business shall post, attach, plant, place, paint or stamp any placard, circular, show bill, sign, or advertisement of any description whatever, nor any goods, wares, merchandise offered for sale or intended to induce sales, upon any public place or object in the city, or upon any street or sidewalk, or upon any public right-of-way including between streets and sidewalks and including between sidewalks and adjacent property lines, or upon any fence, building or property belonging to the city, or upon any telegraph, telephone or light pole, post or tower on city property or right-of-way. No person shall throw or place or through insecure fastening or otherwise, cause to be placed or thrown or to fall in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or any public thoroughfare, or any public park of the city or rights-of-way, any loose paper or other rubbish of a nature likely to be blown about by the wind; provided, that newspaper racks or boxes for the sale of current newspapers, telephones and/or telephone booths are excepted from the above prohibitions. The display of the American flag on such places is excepted from the above prohibitions, and provided further that charitable, fraternal, religious or eleemosynary associations or organizations may be excepted from the above prohibitions by special permission of the council or any agent they may designate. This section shall not be construed to be in derogation of the right or obligation of any governmental unit or agency to post or publish various notices, signs, or posters in the exercise of their official duties. 
(Ord. 364 § 1, 1965) 
8.32.020 - Littering prohibited. 
    No person shall, by himself or herself or by another, throw, place, deposit or leave in any street, highway, lane, alley, public place or square, or in any private place or premises, any glass, broken or unbroken, any metal, stone, earthenware, tacks, cinders or other substances of a nature likely to cause injury to travelers or pedestrians, or to carriages, bicycles or other vehicles, or injure any horse or other animal, or which might injure, cut or puncture, any pneumatic tire, nor shall any person, by himself or herself or by another, throw, place, deposit or leave in any street, highway, lane, alley, public place or square, or in any private place or premises, any animal or vegetable substance, dead animal, fish, shells, dirt, rubbish, excrement, filth, rot, unclean or nauseous water, liquids or gaseous fluids, hay, straw, soot, garbage, swill or any other substance or article whatever. 
(Ord. 364 § 2, 1965) 
8.32.030 - Enforcement. 
    The Hazel Park police department through its members of the police force is authorized to give tickets for violations which they observe. 
(Ord. 364 § 3, 1965) 
8.32.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any or all of the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction of such violation, be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or be imprisoned for a term not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. 364 § 4, 1965) 
Chapter 8.36 - REMOVAL OF DIRT OR TOPSOIL 
Sections: 

8.36.010 - Removal of dirt-Permit required. 
    Any person, individual, firm or corporation who removes, or causes to be removed, any dirt or topsoil from any lot or parcel of land within the city without first receiving a permit therefor from the city, causing said parcel of land or any portion thereof to become unwholesome, offensive or filthy, and/or be covered during any portion of the year with stagnant or impure water, or to be in such condition as to produce offensive exhalations, or to leave holes or pits thereon, liable to cause injury to persons or property, is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine of not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) or ninety (90) days imprisonment, or both such fine and imprisonment within the discretion of the court, together with costs of prosecutions. 
(Ord. 55 § 1, 1945) 
Chapter 8.40 - TREES* 
Sections: 

8.40.010 - Declaration of nuisance-Trimming. 
A.  Any tree or shrub or part thereof upon any property in the city which is infested with any injurious insect, pest, or plant disease which is liable to spread to other trees or shrubs, or any tree which is dead or which may otherwise be detrimental to the peace, health and safety of persons or property of the inhabitants of the city, are declared to be a nuisance. All persons owning or controlling lands or places in this city, and all public authorities having jurisdiction over streets, parks and other public places, shall keep the same free from all injurious matters declared by the provisions of this section to be a nuisance. 
B.  All trees and vegetation in the city which extend over public highways shall at all times be kept so trimmed that no branches of such trees shall be less than nine feet above sidewalks, twelve (12) feet above local and residential streets and alleys, and fourteen (14) feet above major streets or state trunk lines. All owners of such trees shall keep them trimmed as required by this section. 
C.  In order to provide an unobstructed view of an intersection, street or sidewalk from a driveway or a street, to a motorist, there shall be a triangular area of clear vision formed by the two intersecting streets or the driveway and the street or sidewalk. This unobstructed area shall be the triangular section of land formed by the two street curblines and a line connecting them at points twenty-five (25) feet from the intersection of said curblines or the triangular section of land formed by the driveway and sidewalk or street and a line connecting them at the driveway and sidewalk or street. No tree or shrub shall be planted or maintained in such a manner as to impede or obstruct vision between a height of thirty (30) inches and ten feet above the ground within this area. 
(Ord. 14-02 § 1, 2002; Ord. 1-00 § 1, 2000; Ord. 907 § 9 (part), 1997) 
8.40.020 - Abatement of nuisance. 
    The mayor is authorized, either through the office of the mayor or through such other city departments or divisions to which the mayor may delegate the authority, to cause the abatement of the nuisance defined in Section 8.40.010 in accord with procedures set forth in this chapter and applicable laws. 
(Ord. 907 § 9 (part), 1997) 
8.40.030 - Notice of abatement-Contents. 
A.  The city department abating the nuisance defined in Section 8.40.010 shall cause periodic inspections to be made of those lands included in the definition contained in Section 8.40.010. When it is found that the lands have thereon such a nuisance, those persons having ownership or other interest in or custody of the lands, as disclosed by the records of the county register of deeds, shall be notified by certified or registered mail addressed to the last-known address of such persons concerned with the lands. 
B.  The notice provided for in this section shall set forth: 
1.  The description of the lands found to be containing violations of this chapter; 
2.  The nature of the violations; 
3.  The corrective action to be taken; and 
4.  The time by which the corrections are to be completed, such time not to be less than ten days from the date of mailing the notice. 
C.  The notice shall further advise such persons of the provisions contained in this chapter for the city to abate the nuisance and that the cost thereof will be charged to such persons connected with the land or assessed such lands. 
(Ord. 907 § 9 (part), 1997) 
8.40.040 - Notice by publication-Trimming. 
    In lieu of the notice provided for in Section 8.40.030 pertaining to the trimming of trees overhanging public highways, the city department responsible for maintaining tree clearance over public highways may cause a notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county stating that any vegetation or trees with overhanging limbs and branches lower than the specified clearance called for within Section 8.40.010 must have such limbs trimmed or removed by the date specified within the notice. Failure to do so on the part of the property owner will result in the city trimming such overhanging limbs and the cost thereof charged against the person responsible for the property. The notice shall specify the method of trimming such trees and vegetation and a summary of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 907 § 9 (part), 1997) 
8.40.050 - Failure to abate nuisance-City removal-Costs. 
A.  If any person having the duty, through connection with lands as set forth in this chapter, to abate the nuisance set forth in Section 8.40.010 fails or refuses to eliminate the nuisance after the notice procedures as contained in this chapter have been carried out, then the office of the mayor or such other city department or division as may be designated by the mayor shall cause the nuisance to be abated. 
B.  All of the costs incurred in the abatement of the nuisance shall be the expense of the person responsible for the lands. The city department or division undertaking the abatement process under this chapter shall keep records of all expenses related to the abatement with costs assigned to each parcel of land or lot or property description and the person responsible for such lands. 
(Ord. 907 § 9 (part), 1997) 
8.40.060 - Costs a lien-Assessment. 
    All costs in connection with cutting, removing, destroying, trimming, eliminating or abating the nuisance shall be a lien upon the land where such nuisance shall have been caused by the city to be destroyed, cut, eliminated, removed, trimmed or abated, and all the costs of such abatement remaining unpaid each year, pursuant to provisions contained in the City Charter, shall be collected in the same manner that other special assessments are collected under the Charter. 
(Ord. 907 § 9 (part), 1997) 
8.40.070 - Permit-Fee. 
    Any person desiring to remove any tree of six inches diameter or more implanted in the ground on private property within the city shall be required to obtain a permit from the city before such work commences and pay therefore a fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per tree. 
(Ord. 14-02 § 2, 2002) 
Chapter 8.45 - BLOWING GRASS CLIPPINGS AND RAKING LEAVES 
Sections: 

8.45.010 - Blowing grass clippings and raking leaves. 
    It shall be unlawful to rake, place or mow fallen tree leaves or grass clippings onto the pavement or into the gutter of any public street. No person shall permit grass clippings from mower swaths to remain upon sidewalks, street pavements, gutters of any public street, or on abutting property not owned or occupied by said person. Fallen tree leaves shall not be allowed to accumulate on the property and shall be removed on or before May 15 th of each year. 
(Ord. No. 06-16, pt. I, 9-27-2016) 
8.45.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any part of this chapter shall be responsible for a civil infraction and shall be fined two hundred sixty-five dollars ($265.00) plus costs. Each day a violation exists shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 06-16, pt. I, 9-27-2016) 
Chapter 8.48 - WEEDS 
Sections: 

8.48.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words and their meanings shall apply in this chapter: 
    "Owner" means the person or persons, corporation, partnership, association, joint stock company, society or other entity having legal possession of the property. 
    A "lot" or "parcel of land" means and includes any continuous piece or parcel of land owned by a person, or any other legal entity and includes such portions of any street or alley abutting such land that would be attached to the piece or parcel of land upon the vacation of the public rights to the street or alley. 
    "Poisonous or harmful vegetation" means and includes any and all vegetation that in any way becomes a hazard to or detrimental to the health of any person. 
    "Weeds" means and includes all weeds, grass, brush, wildings, second growth, rank vegetation or other vegetation that is not growing in its proper place, having a greater height than eight inches or a spread of over eight square inches. 
(Ord. 907 § 11 (part), 1997; Ord. 388 § 1, 1966) 
(Ord. No. 15-13, pt. I, 12-10-2013) 
8.48.020 - Designated. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, "noxious weeds" includes canada thistle (Circium arvense), dodders (any species of Cuscuta), mustards (charlock, black mustard and indian mustard, species of Brassica or Sinapis), wild carrot (Daucus carota), bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis), perennial sowthistle (Sonchus arvensis), hoary alyssum (Berteroa incana), ragweed (Ambrosia elatior 1.) and poison ivy (Rhus toxicodendron), poison sumac (Toxicodendron vernix) or other plant which in the opinion of the city council coming under the provisions of this chapter is regarded as a common nuisance. 
(Ord. 453 § 2, 1969) 
8.48.030 - Owner responsibility. 
    Each person occupying a lot or parcel of land and the owners of vacant property or properties shall maintain all yard spaces, including such portions of any street or alley abutting such lands that would be attached to the parcel of land upon the vacation of the public rights to the street or alley, that is not otherwise paved or improved, in a condition that will not detract from the appearance of the neighborhood. 
    For property or properties occupied by a tenant or occupant, both the tenant or occupant and the owner of the property shall be responsible and subject to the penalties provided in this chapter. 
    For properties that are occupied for multiple uses, the owner shall designate a person who resides on the property to act as his or her agent and be responsible for the maintenance of the property as required by this chapter. Failure to appoint and register an agent with the city clerk's office shall make the owner subject to the penalties provided in this chapter. 
    Where the property is occupied by a tenant, that shall not relieve the owner of such responsibility and upon failure to maintain the property as required by this chapter, the city may do such work as is required and assess its cost to the property as herein provided. 
    For unoccupied properties the owner shall be responsible for maintaining the property as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 719 § 1, 1987; Ord. 388 § 2, 1966) 
(Ord. No. 15-13, pt. II, 12-10-2013) 
8.48.040 - Growth of weeds unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person having control of any occupied or unoccupied lot or parcel of land or any part thereof, in the city, to permit or maintain on any such lot or parcel of land any growth of weeds or poisonous or harmful vegetation as defined in Section 8.48.010. 
(Ord. 388 § 3, 1966) 
8.48.050 - Owner to remove weeds. 
A.  The landowner of land on which noxious weeds are found growing shall destroy the weeds before they reach a seed bearing stage and prevent their regrowth, or shall prevent them from becoming a detriment to public health. The city shall notify by certified mail with return receipt requested, the owner, agent, or occupant of any land on which noxious weeds are found growing. The notice shall describe methods of treating and eradicating the noxious weeds and a summary of the provisions of this section. Failure of the city to give such notice shall not, however, constitute a defense to any action to enforce the payment provided for or debt created of any penalty under this act. If the owner, agent, or occupant refuses to destroy the noxious weeds or cause them to be destroyed, the city shall enter upon the land and destroy the noxious weeds or cause them to be destroyed. Any expense incurred in the destruction shall be paid by the owner or owners of the land, and the city shall have a lien against the land for the amount of the expense, which lien shall be enforced in the manner now provided by law and City Charter. 
B.  Any owner who refuses to destroy noxious weeds as provided for in this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. 718 § 1 (part), 1987) 
8.48.060 - Notice of compliance. 
    In lieu of the notice required by Section 8.48.050 the city may publish notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the county during the month of March that weeds not cut in accordance and yards or property not maintained in accordance with this chapter will be cut by the city and the owner of the property charged with the cost under the provisions of Section 8.48.050. The publication shall also contain all other information required of the notice provided for in Section 8.48.050. The city may cut weeds as many times as is necessary and charge the cost to the property owner. 
(Ord. 944 § 1, 1999: Ord. 718 § 1 (part), 1987) 
8.48.070 - Clearing of weeds by city-Cost lien on property. 
    If a parcel of land has not been cleared of the weeds or poisonous or harmful vegetation, as provided in this chapter, within ten days after the date of the notice or by the deadline set forth in the publication notice provided for by Section 8.48.060 and maintained from May 15th through October 15th in a condition free from such weeds, poisonous or harmful vegetation without further notice, the city manager may cause such weeds, poisonous or harmful vegetation to be cut or completely destroyed; provided, that in the case of poison ivy or other poisonous plants he or she will cause such plants to be completely destroyed. 
    The actual cost of such cutting, removal or destruction plus a fee, to be set by resolution of the city council, for inspection and any other cost in connection therewith, shall be certified by the city manager to the city council and upon their approval shall become a lien upon the property on which such weeds, poisonous or harmful vegetation were located and such charges shall be assessed and collected in the same manner provided in the Charter of the city wherein any cost is incurred in connection with a single lot or parcel of land. 
(Amended during 1997 recodification; Ord. 718 §§ 2, 3, 1987; Ord. 532 § 2, 1974: Ord. 388 § 6, 1966) 
8.48.080 - Refuse removal. 
    If there is an accumulation of refuse upon any property which must be removed prior to cutting of weeds, the refuse shall be removed pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 8.29, and the cost of such removal shall be assessed against the property in the manner prescribed by the City Charter. 
(Ord. 907 11 (part), 1997: Ord. 532 § 3, 1974; Ord. 388 § 6A, 1966) 
8.48.090 - Right of entry by city. 
    Because of the failure of the person responsible to carry out the provisions of this chapter the city or its employees or agents shall have the right to enter upon any private property not securely fenced or enclosed, for the purpose of cutting, removing or destroying any and all weeds, poisonous or harmful vegetation, and the city and its employees or agents shall not be liable for any damage to any plants or vegetation obscured by the growth of weeds, poisonous or harmful vegetation as herein set forth. 
(Ord. 388 § 7, 1966) 
8.48.150 - Violation of Sections 8.48.030 through 8.48.090-Penalty. 
    Any person who neglects to cut, remove or destroy weeds, poisonous or harmful vegetation on property that is under his or her jurisdiction as directed by Sections 8.48.030 through 8.48.090, or who fails, neglects or refuses to comply with the provisions of any notice herein provided or who violates any of the provisions of Sections 8.48.030 through 8.48.090, or who resists or obstructs the city manager or his or her authorized agents in the cutting and removal of such weeds, poisonous or harmful vegetation, is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, and each day on which such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 388 § 8, 1966) 
8.48.160 - Violation of Section 8.48.020-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, corporation, owner, occupant, and/or agent of any lands violating Section 8.48.020 is guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) in the discretion of the judge of the district court. 
(Amended during 1997 recodification; Ord. 453 § 7, 1969) 
Chapter 8.49 - PORTABLE BASKETBALL HOOPS AND PORTABLE HOCKEY NETS 
Sections: 

8.49.010 - Prohibited in public right-of-way. 
    The placing and/or use of any portable basketball hoop, hockey net or any other portable or stationary athletic equipment in any public right-of-way to include streets, alleys, sidewalks, driveway approach, public parking lots or any other public areas, including but not limited to the area between the street and sidewalk, is expressly prohibited. 
(Ord. 14-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
8.49.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The parent of a child or the guardian of a ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit the child or ward to violate this chapter. 
    A person who violates this chapter is responsible for a civil infraction and subject to a fine in an amount of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. 14-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 8.50 - OUTDOOR STORAGE 
Sections: 

8.50.010 - Residential zoning districts. 
A.  In all residential zoning districts, all materials, equipment, and personal property shall be stored within a building except the following: 
1.  Clothes line. 
2.  Construction and landscaping materials currently being used on the premises. 
3.  Children's toys and children's recreational apparatuses when kept neat and orderly and in good repair. 
4.  Patio and lawn furniture kept in good repair. 
B.  In all residential districts, a vacant lot or parcel shall not be used for storage. 
(Ord. No. 02-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.50.020 - Commercial and industrial zoning districts. 
A.  Exterior storage shall be governed by the respective zoning district in which the use is located. 
B.  When exterior storage is allowed in a particular zoning district, it shall be screened so as not to be visible from adjacent properties and right of way, except as follows: 
1.  Merchandise being displayed for sale in accordance with zoning district requirements. 
2.  Materials and equipment currently being used for landscaping or construction on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 02-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.50.030 - All zoning districts. 
A.  No motor vehicle or trailer may be used to store items, scrap or junk unless the motor vehicle or trailer is permitted in the particular zoning district and is screened from view of adjacent properties and right of way. 
B.  The city manager or his or her designee may order the owner of any property to cease or modify outdoor storage uses, including existing uses, provided it is found that the use constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 02-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
8.50.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation violating the provisions of Sections 8.50.010 to 8.50.030 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus costs and/or imprisonment not more than ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 02-17, pt. I, 3-14-2017) 
Title 9 - PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE 
Chapters: 
I. - OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST PUBLIC OFFICERS AND GOVERNMENT 
Chapter 9.02 - VIOLATION OF STATE LAW 
Sections: 

9.02.010 - State law-Misdemeanors. 
    Every act prohibited by state law as a misdemeanor is prohibited, and whoever violates the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by the same penalty provided by state law, except that the penalty shall in no case exceed a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for ninety (90) days, or both. 
(Ord. 393 § 18, 1966) 
Chapter 9.04 - RESISTING A POLICE OFFICER-FALSE REPORT OF CRIME 
Sections: 

9.04.010 - Interference with police department. 
A.  No person shall resist any police officer, any member of the police department, or any person duly empowered with police authority while in the discharge or apparent discharge of his or her duty, or in any way interfere with or hinder him or her in the discharge of his or her duty. 
B.  No person shall offer or endeavor to assist any person in the custody of a police officer, a member of the police department, or a person duly empowered with police authority to escape or attempt to escape from such custody. 
C.  No person other than an official police officer of the city shall wear or carry the uniform, apparel, badge, identification card, or any other insignia or office like, or similar to, or a colorable imitation of that adopted and worn, or carried by the official police officers of the city. 
(Ord. 393 § 21(a) - (c), 1966) 
9.04.020 - Escape, aiding escapee prohibited. 
A.  No person shall make available to, present to, or place within the reach of any person confined under the authority of the city, any intoxicating or malt liquors, or any tool, implement, or other thing calculated to aid in the escape of such person so confined, or any person confined under authority of the city. 
B.  No person shall assist or aid, or attempt to assist or aid, any person in the custody of, or confined under the authority of the city, to escape from jail, place of confinement or custody. 
C.  No person shall, while a prisoner in the city jail, or at any place where prisoners are confined, or otherwise in custody of the city escape or attempt to escape or to assist others to escape or to attempt to escape from such custody or confinement. 
(Ord. 393 § 21(d)-(f), 1966) 
9.04.030 - False report of crime. 
    No person shall make or file with the police department of the city any false, misleading or unfounded statement or report concerning the commission or alleged commission of any crime occurring within the city. Any person who willfully makes a fictitious report of the commission of any crime to any police officer, knowing it to be false, shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 393 § 20, 1966) 
Chapter 9.06 - STOP AND FRISK 
Sections: 

9.06.010 - Authority. 
    When a police officer has reasonable cause to believe that the behavior of an individual warrants further investigation for criminal activity, the officer may stop and question such person. 
(Ord. 433 § 1, 1968) 
9.06.020 - Search for weapon. 
    When a police officer has stopped a person for questioning pursuant to Section 9.06.010, and has reasonable cause to believe there is danger to himself or herself or others, he or she may conduct a limited search of that person for dangerous weapons. The police officer may take and keep such weapon or any other thing, the possession of which may constitute a crime, until he or she has completed the questioning at which time he or she shall either return such property so taken, if lawfully possessed, or arrest such person and dispose of such property according to law. 
(Ord. 433 § 2, 1968) 
9.06.030 - Rights of citizen protected. 
    In enforcing Sections 9.06.010 and 9.06.020 the Hazel Park police department and the individual police officer will take special care not only to honor the rights of citizens as defined in the United States Constitution but also to safeguard the personal dignity of all those affected by it. 
(Ord. 433 § 3, 1968) 
Chapter 9.09 - FALSE FIRE ALARMS AND FALSE POLICE CALLS 
Sections: 

9.09.010 - False and prank reports. 
    Any person who shall knowingly make a false report of a crime or fire to any member of the police or fire department, or communicate the false report to any other person which causes that person to use the "911" telephone emergency to call the city police and/or fire department to report a false crime, false incident or false fire alarm report, or to call either or cause another to call either of those departments with a prank telephone call is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 01-06 § 1, 2006: Ord. 774 § 1 (part), 1989) 
9.09.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating Section 9.09.010 of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by ninety (90) days in jail and/or a five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. 01-06 § 2, 2006: Ord. 774 § 1 (part), 1989) 
9.09.030 - Nuisance per se. 
    It is further determined that a false police call, false fire alarm call and/or prank call shall be and is declared a nuisance per se; further the cost of providing city service in responding to the call shall be in an amount to be set by resolution of the city council, assessable against either the person who is in control of the phone, the real estate where the phone is located, the parents of a minor making such call, or the person who made such call. In the event collection is not obtained by city billing, the cost shall be assessed against the real estate and collected in the manner prescribed in the City Charter for collection of the fees and charges. 
(Amended during 1997 recodification: Ord. 774 § 1 (part), 1989) 
Chapter 9.10 - FALSE EMERGENCY CARE REQUEST 
Sections: 

9.10.010 - Requesting with intent not to use. 
    A person who, with the intent not to use the assistance, knowingly causes or makes a request for the assistance of an ambulance service or an advanced mobile emergency care service is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than ninety-three (93) days or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both. 
(Ord. No. 03-15, pt. I, 12-8-2015) 
II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
Chapter 9.16 - MARKET BASKET CARTS 
Sections: 

9.16.010 - Intent. 
    It is the intent of this chapter to prohibit the abandonment of market basket carts, as defined in Section 9.16.020 on the streets or in public places in the city. 
(Ord. 442 § 1, 1968) 
9.16.020 - Definitions. 
A.  "Market basket cart" means the common wire or steel fabricated basket set on wheels and designed to carry quantities of merchandise normally purchased at retail stores or markets. This definition is not intended to be all-inclusive, but suggestive of the well defined and commonly used market basket cart such as is in common use for customers at self-service markets or other retail outlets in the city. 
B.  "Public place" is defined to be any street, sidewalk, alley, public easement, park, greenbelt or any other public place owned and maintained by a public authority. 
(Ord. 442 § 2, 1968) 
9.16.030 - Abandonment unlawful. 
A.  From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, any person who abandons any such market basket cart in any public place as defined in Section 9.16.020 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by the penalty established in Chapter 1.12. 
B.  From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, any person, firm, store manager and/or corporation shall store all market basket carts inside the building belonging to such person, firm, manager and/or corporation during the hours that the business of such person, firm, manager and/or corporation shall be closed to the general public. The primary duty making sure said baskets are not left outside and unsupervised is placed on the store manager. 
C.  From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, any person, firm, store manager and/or corporation who furnishes market basket carts for the use of the public shall post notice within his or her business premises in a prominent display position near the market basket carts, of this ordinance codified in this chapter which shall read as follows: 
 Hazel Park City Ordinance No. 442 prohibits the abandonment of Shopping basket carts in a public place. Violation of said ordinance is punishable by a fine up to $500 and/or 90 days in jail. 
(Ord. 442 § 3, 1968) 
9.16.060 - Identification on cart. 
    All public places operating in the city and making available to their customers market basket carts shall identify their ownership of said market basket cart by attaching thereto in permanent manner a permanent tag or other identification stating the owner of said basket and the store at which the market basket cart is to be maintained or kept in the city or other place. The failure to attach to the basket such identification or failure of such identification to be on the basket at the time of being recovered from its abandonment shall relieve the city of any necessity to notify any owner of the fact that the basket is in the possession of the city. 
(Ord. 442 § 6, 1968) 
9.16.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Every person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter shall upon conviction be punishable as set forth in Chapter 1.12. 
(Ord. 442 § 7, 1968) 
Chapter 9.18 - PARKS AND PLAYGROUNDS 
Sections: 

9.18.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "public parks and playgrounds ordinance." 
(Ord. 476 § 1, 1971) 
9.18.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meaning given herein: 
A.  "Board" is the parks and recreation board. 
B.  "Director" is the director of recreation. 
C.  "Park" is a park, playground, recreation center or any other area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to recreation. 
(Ord. 476 § 2, 1971) 
9.18.030 - Protection of park property. 
    No person shall willfully mark, deface, disfigure, tamper with, displace or remove any building, tables, benches, fireplaces, trees, shrubs, flowers, or any other park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. No structure, booth, tent or stall shall be erected on park property for any purpose without permission from the director. 
(Ord. 476 § 3, 1971) 
9.18.040 - Refuse and trash disposal. 
    No person shall dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, boxes, cans, rubbish, waste, garbage or other trash of any nature in a public park, except in proper receptacles where these are provided. Where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Ord. 476 § 4, 1971) 
9.18.050 - Traffic regulations. 
    No person shall fail to comply with all provisions of city ordinances relative to equipment and operation of motor vehicles. No person shall drive or park a motor vehicle on any park area except roads or parking areas, or other such areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary parking areas by the director. 
(Ord. 476 § 5, 1971) 
9.18.060 - Loitering and disorderly conduct prohibited. 
    No person shall sleep or protractedly lounge on the seats or benches or other park areas, or engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusive, insulting of indecent language or behavior, or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to a breach of the public peace. 
(Ord. 476 § 6, 1971) 
9.18.070 - Fireworks and explosives. 
    No person shall bring into a park, or have in his or her possession, or set off or otherwise cause to explode in a park, any firecrackers, torpedo, rocket or other fireworks or explosives, or discharge them or throw them into any park area from land or highway adjacent thereto. 
(Ord. 476 § 7, 1971) 
9.18.080 - Building of fires. 
    No person shall build or attempt to build a fire in a park except in such areas and under such regulations as may be designed by the director. 
(Ord. 476 § 8, 1971) 
9.18.090 - Merchandising, advertising and signs. 
    No person shall expose or offer for sale in a park any article or thing, nor shall he or she station or place any stand, cart or vehicle in a park for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing. Exception is here made as to any regularly licensed concessionaire acting by and under the authority and regulation of the board. No person shall paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement, or inscription whatsoever, nor shall any person erect or cause to be erected any sign whatever in any park. 
(Ord. 476 § 9, 1971) 
9.18.100 - Dogs. 
    No person shall permit any dog owned by him or her or under his or her control or custody to enter any park where a sign or signs are posted bearing the legend "no dogs allowed," or other words to the same effect. In park areas where dogs are permitted, all such dogs shall at all times be kept under reasonable control by means of leash or otherwise. 
(Ord. 476 § 10, 1971) 
9.18.110 - Games and unusual activities. 
    No person shall take part in or abet the playing of any games involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects such as balls, arrows, javelins or model airplanes, except in areas specifically set apart for such form of recreation. 
(Ord. 476 § 11, 1971) 
9.18.120 - Closing hours. 
A.  All public parks shall be closed between the hours of nine p.m. and six a.m., except that any ball diamond, adjacent parking lot and/or grandstand may be used only by members of a city of Hazel Park organized league team, its members or audience until ten minutes following the termination of said game or activity when said diamond, grandstand and lot shall be vacated forthwith. 
B.  Any public park or any section or part of any public park may be closed to the public by the city council-designated hours as recommended by the city manager as necessary. Appropriate signs shall be posted advising the public the hours during said closed hours. The closed hours shall not apply to authorized, organized activities such as baseball games. 
(Ord. 714 § 1, 1986; Ord. 707 §§ 1, 4, 1986; Ord. 476 § 11A, 1971) 
9.18.130 - Rules and regulations. 
    The board may, by suitable rules and regulations, implement the foregoing provisions of this chapter. The board may set aside park areas for specific recreation activities and provide for the issuance of licenses and permits, under suitable conditions, for the carrying on of unusual or dangerous recreational activities. All such rules and regulations shall have the same force and effect as the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 476 § 12, 1971) 
9.18.140 - Enforcement. 
    The director and the city police shall diligently enforce the provisions of this chapter. They shall have the authority to revoke any permit issued for the diamond or park's use and eject from any park any person acting in violation of this chapter, or in violation of any rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. 707 § 5, 1986; Ord. 476 § 13, 1971) 
9.18.141 - Property damage by minors-Parental responsibility. 
    Every parent, father and/or mother, or guardian or adult in charge of a minor shall be personally responsible for any malicious damage to any person or property caused by a minor child under seventeen (17) years of age in their charge or care. 
(Ord. 707 § 3, 1986) 
9.18.150 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punishable as set forth in Chapter 1.12. 
(Ord. 476 § 14, 1971) 
9.18.160 - Alcoholic beverages-Permit. 
    It is unlawful to possess, serve, give away, sell and/or consume any alcoholic beer, wine, liquor or beverage upon, in or at any public park, playground or parking lot, with the following exception: 
    A city permit may be issued by the recreation director for family reunions, charitable, political, fraternal or service club activities, or industrial or commercial picnics, and to designated individuals representing the aforementioned groups subject to the following requirements: 
A.  The individual representing the aforementioned groups shall be personally responsible for the groups' conduct, activity, or damage caused by any of the individual participants; 
B.  Payment of a permit fee in an amount determined by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 906 § 2, 1997: Ord. 829 § 1, 1991) 
Chapter 9.20 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
Sections: 

9.20.010 - Preservation of public property. 
    It is unlawful for any person to destroy, injure or deface, or in any manner interfere with or hinder the face of, any public building or any public property whatsoever. 
(Ord. 393 § 13, 1966) 
9.20.020 - Destruction of property. 
    No person shall wilfully tamper with, injure, damage, destroy or deface any public property or any private property belonging to another person. 
(Ord. 393 § 14, 1966) 
9.20.025 - Destruction of house or building. 
    No person shall wilfully and maliciously destroy or injure any house, or other building of another, or other appurtenance thereof. 
(Ord. 906 § 3 (part), 1997) 
9.20.030 - Stealing property prohibited. 
    No person shall take, attempt to take, steal, attempt to steal, or carry away, or attempt to carry away any private property of any kind whatsoever belonging to another person. 
(Ord. 490 § 1, 1971: Ord. 393 § 25, 1966) 
9.20.040 - Trespass. 
    Any person who willfully enters upon the lands or premises of another without lawful authority after having been forbidden to do so by the owner or occupant, or any person being upon the land or premises of another, upon being notified to depart there from by the owner or occupant, the agent or servant of either, who without lawful authority neglects or refuses to depart there from, or any person who enters or occupies a structure that has been placarded by the code official or any person who shall let anyone occupy a placarded premises is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be subject to penalty of this chapter as set forth in Section 9.20.090. 
(Ord. 431 § 2, 1968: Ord. 393 § 37, 1966) 
(Ord. No. 08-11, pt. I, 9-15-2011) 
9.20.050 - Possession of burglar's tools. 
    No person shall possess any nippers, known as burglar's nippers, any picklock, skeleton key, key to be used with a bit, jimmy, or any other burglar's instruments or tools of whatever kind or description unless it be shown that such possession is innocent or for lawful purposes. 
(Ord. 393 § 34, 1966) 
9.20.060 - Retail fraud. 
    A person who does any of the following in a store or in its immediate vicinity is guilty of retail fraud if: 
A.  While a store is open to the public, he or she alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals, or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is offered for sale with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered for sale; or 
B.  While a store is open to the public, he or she steals property of the store that is offered for sale; or 
C.  With intent to defraud, he or she obtains or attempts to obtain money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and belongs to the store. 
(Ord. 863 § 1 (part), 1993) 
9.20.070 - Fraudulent schemes. 
    No person shall engage in any fraudulent scheme, devise or trick to obtain money or other valuable things from others. 
(Ord. 863 § 1 (part), 1993) 
9.20.080 - Disposition of abandoned property. 
A.  Delivered to Police Chief for Recording. Whenever any lost or abandoned money, goods or personal property are found within the limits of the city, by any police officer or employee of the city, the same shall be delivered at once to the chief of police, who shall cause to be documented in an incident report, a complete description of the property, the date of the finding of the same and the name of the person by whom found. Such book shall be a part of the public records of the city, and shall be kept on file in the police department. 
B.  Notice to Owner-Sale at Public Auction. If the owner of lost or abandoned property is known to the chief of police, he or she shall cause to be served upon such owner a written notice informing him or her that his or her property has been found and is in the possession of the police department. If the owner fails or neglects to appear and claim his or her property after a period of twenty (20) days from the date of service of such notice. If the owner of lost or abandoned property is unknown and he or she, or any person lawfully entitled to such property shall not appear and provide his or her ownership to the same, to the satisfaction of the chief of police within six months from date of finding of same, the city manager shall cause the same to be offered for sale at public auction upon first giving ten days notice of such sale in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, said notice to contain a description of the property and the time and place where it will be sold. 
C.  Firearms and Dangerous Weapons. Any firearm or dangerous weapon which has been abandoned or found and/or delivered to the police department shall not be sold at public auction but shall either be destroyed or disposed of in the discretion of the chief of police. 
(Ord. 906 § 3 (part), 1997) 
9.20.090 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating Sections 9.20.010, 9.20.020, 9.20.025, 9.20.030, 9.20.060 and 9.20.070 may be imprisoned for not more than ninety-three (93) days and/or fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or both. 
(Ord. 948 § 1, 1999) 
Chapter 9.22 - LITTERING 
Sections: 

9.22.010 - Littering-Prohibition. 
    A person shall not knowingly, without the consent of the city of Hazel Park for public property, or the owner of private property, dump, deposit, place, throw, or leave, or cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing, or leaving of, litter on public or private property or water other than property designated and set aside for such purposes. 
(Ord. 13-06 § 1 (part), 2006) 
9.22.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating Section 9.22.010 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by ninety (90) days in jail and/or a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine. 
(Ord. 13-06 § 1 (part), 2006) 
III. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON 
Chapter 9.25 - ASSAULTS 
Sections: 

9.25.010 - Assaults and battery. 
    No person shall assault and batter another, or shall engage in any fight, quarrel or other public disturbance, or shall use threatening language to another, or shall make threats against another person. 
(Ord. 906 § 4, 1997) 
9.25.020 - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this section may be imprisoned for not more than ninety-three (93) days and/or fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both. 
(Ord. 11-02 § 1, 2002) 
Chapter 9.29 - TELEPHONE HARASSMENT 
Sections: 

9.29.010 - Prohibited acts. 
    Any person is guilty of disorderly conduct who maliciously uses any service provided by a communications common carrier with intent to terrorize, frighten, intimidate, threaten, harass, molest or annoy any other person, or to disturb the peace and quiet of any other person by any of the following: 
A.  Threatening physical harm or damage to any person or property in the course of a telephone conversation; 
B.  Falsely and deliberately reporting by telephone or telegraph a message that any person has been injured, has suddenly taken ill, has suffered death or has been the victim of a crime, or of an accident; 
C.  Deliberately refusing or failing to disengage a connection between a telephone and another telephone or between a telephone and other equipment provided for the transmission of messages by telephone, thereby interfering with any communications service; 
D.  Using any vulgar, indecent, obscene or offensive language or suggesting any lewd or lascivious act in the course of a telephone conversation; 
E.  Repeatedly initiating a telephone call and, without speaking, deliberately hanging up or breaking the telephone connection as or after the telephone call is answered; 
F.  Making an unsolicited commercial telephone call which is received between the hours of nine p.m. and nine a.m. For the purpose of this subdivision, "an unsolicited commercial telephone call" means a call made by a person or recording device, on behalf of a person, corporation or other entity, soliciting business or contributions; 
G.  Deliberately calling a telephone of another person in a repetitive manner which causes interruption in telephone service or prevents the person from utilizing his or her telephone service. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1989) 
9.29.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating this section may be imprisoned for not more than ninety (90) days and/or fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both. An offense is committed under this section if the communication either originates or terminates or both originates and terminates in the city and may be prosecuted at the place of origination or termination. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1989) 
IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC DECENCY 
Chapter 9.38 - PARAPHERNALIA FOR USE OF CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES* 
Sections: 

9.38.010 - Possession of drug paraphernalia. 
A.  "Dangerous drug," when used in this section, means any drug defined as a narcotic by the statutes of the state, any barbiturate, any amphetamine, phencyclidine, hydrochloride, d-lysergic acid, diethylamine (LSD), or other drug possessing similar hallucinogenic properties. 
B.  A person shall be guilty of the offense of unlawful possession of drug paraphernalia if hypodermic needle, syringe, spoon, pipe or any other instrument, implement or device adapted for the use or administration of any dangerous drug, by injection or any other manner or method of introducing such drug into the body, and which is possessed for that purpose, unless such possession is authorized by a certificate of a licensed medical doctor or osteopathic physician issued within the period of one year; provided, that the prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to manufacturers, wholesalers, jobbers, licensed medical technicians, technologists, nurses, hospitals, research teaching institutions, clinical laboratories, medical doctors, osteopathic physicians, dentists, veterinarians, pharmacists and embalmers in the normal legal course of their respective business or profession, nor to persons suffering from diabetes, asthma or any other medical condition requiring self-injection. 
(Ord. 906 § 6 (part), 1997) 
9.38.020 - Enforcement. 
    Any drug paraphernalia used in violation of this section shall be seized and forfeited to the city. 
(Ord. 906 § 6 (part), 1997) 
9.38.030 - Violation-Penalty. 
    A person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days in jail, or both, in the discretion of the court. Each day a violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. 906 § 6 (part), 1997) 
9.38.040 - Nonapplication. 
    Nothing in this chapter or the code of ordinances shall apply to the use, possession or transfer of less than one ounce of marijuana, on private property not used by the public, or transportation of less than one ounce of marijuana, by a person who has attained the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(Ord. of 8-5-2014) 
Chapter 9.39 - SYNTHETIC MARIJUANA AND DANGEROUS PRODUCTS 
Sections: 

9.39.010 - Findings, intent and purpose. 
(a)  The city finds that synthetic marijuana, consisting of plant or other material treated with chemicals or other substances that have not been approved for human consumption, is being marketed and sold as herbal incense and is being used in the same manner and for the same purposes as marijuana, with that use having become increasingly popular, particularly among teens and young adults. 
(b)  The city further finds based on information and reports from poison control centers, hospitals, emergency room doctors, and police agencies, that individuals who use synthetic marijuana experience dangerous side effects including convulsions, tremors, seizures, hallucinations, unconsciousness, anxiety attacks, dangerously elevated heart rates, increased blood pressure, vomiting, and disorientation, evidencing that these herbal incense products are harmful if consumed and present an imminent and significant public health danger to persons consuming such products and other persons coming in contact with them. 
(c)  The city further finds that, notwithstanding the high potential for abuse, and lack of any accepted medical use, the ability of the state to prohibit all forms of synthetic marijuana as a controlled substance has been frustrated due to the changing nature of the chemicals used in the manufacturing process. 
(d)  The city further finds that in addition to synthetic marijuana, there may be other products or materials containing chemicals or substances, that while not approved for human consumption, are or may be marketed and sold in a form that allows for such consumption and which, upon consumption, may result in the same serious side effects and public health dangers as synthetic marijuana. 
(c)  Based on these findings, this chapter is adopted for the purpose and with the intent to protect the public health and safety of the city and its residents from the threat posed by the availability and use of synthetic marijuana and other dangerous products by prohibiting persons from trafficking in, possessing, and using them in the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, pt. I, 6-5-2012) 
9.39.020 - Definitions and adoption by reference. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases have the meanings indicated. 
    "Act" means the controlled substances provisions in Article 7 of the Public Health Code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978, MCL 333.7101 to MCL 333.7545, as amended, which is hereby adopted by reference as a part of this chapter. 
    "Chemical agent" means any chemical or organic compound, substance, or agent that is not made, intended and approved for consumption by humans. 
    "Consumable product or material" means a product or material, regardless of packaging disclaimers or disclosures, that is not for human consumption or use, is in a form that readily allows for human consumption by inhalation, ingestion, injection, or application, through means including but not limited to smoking, injection, application, or ingestion by mouth with or without mixing with food or drink.
