Within seven days after personal property is seized or a lien notice is filed against real property, the police department, or if the property is real property, the city attorney or prosecuting attorney, shall give notice of the seizure of the property and the intent to forfeit and dispose of the property according to this chapter to each of the following persons: 
1.  If charges have been filed against a person for a crime, the person charged; 
2.  Each person with a known ownership interest in the property; 
3.  Each mortgagee, person holding a security interest, or person having a lien that appears on the certificate of title or is on file with the Secretary of State or appropriate register of deeds, if the property is real property, a mobile home, motor vehicle, watercraft or other personal property; 
4.  Each holder of a preferred ship mortgage of record in the appropriate public office pursuant to the Ship Mortgage Act, 1920, Chapter 250, 41 Stat. 1000.46 U.S.C. App. 911, 921 to 927, 941, 951 to 954, 961, 971 to 975 and 981 to 984, if the property is a watercraft more than twenty-eight (28) feet long or a watercraft that has a capacity of five net tons or more; 
5.  Each person whose security interest is recorded with the appropriate public office pursuant to the Federal Aviation Act of 1958, Public Law 85-726, 27 Stat. 731, if the property is an aircraft, aircraft engine, or aircraft propeller, or a part of an aircraft, aircraft engine, or aircraft propeller; 
6.  Each person with a known security interest in the property; 
7.  Each victim of the crime. 
B.  Delivery of Notice. The notice required under subsection A of this section shall be a written notice delivered to the person or sent to the person by certified mail. If the name and address of the person are not reasonably ascertainable or delivery of the notice cannot reasonably be accomplished, the notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the personal property was seized or the real property is located for ten successive publishing days. Proof of written notice or publication shall be filed with the court having jurisdiction over the seizure or forfeiture. 
C.  Notification of Prosecuting Attorney. If personal property was seized, the police department shall immediately notify the prosecuting attorney of the seizure of the property and the intent to forfeit and dispose of the property. 
(Ord. 923 § 1 (part), 1997) 
9.99.040 - Return of property or discharge of lien motions-Motor vehicle seizure. 
A.  Motion for Return of Property. A person who did not have prior knowledge of, or consent to the commission of, the crime may move the court to return the property or discharge the lien on the grounds that the property was illegally seized, that the property is not subject to forfeiture under this chapter, or that the person has an ownership or security interest in the property and did not have prior knowledge of, or consent to the commission of, the crime. The court shall hear the motion within thirty (30) days after the motion is filed. 
B.  Hearing. At the hearing on the motion, the prosecuting attorney or the city attorney shall establish the following: 
1.  Probable cause to believe that the property is subject to forfeiture under this chapter and that the person filing the motion had prior knowledge of, or consented to the commission of, the crime; 
2.  If the person filing the motion claims the property was illegally seized, that the property was properly seized. 
C.  Burden of Proof. If the prosecuting or city attorney fails to sustain his or her burden of proof under subsection B of this section, the court shall order the return of the property or discharge of the lien. 
D.  Motor Vehicle Seizure. If a motor vehicle is seized, the owner of the vehicle may move the court to require the police department to file a lien against the vehicle and to return the vehicle to the owner. The court shall hear the motion within seven days after the motion is filed. If the owner of the vehicle establishes at the hearing that he or she holds the legal title of the vehicle and that it is necessary for him or her or his or her family to use the vehicle pending the outcome of the forfeiture action, the court may order the police department to return the vehicle to the owner. If the court orders the return of the vehicle to the owner, the court shall order the police department to file a lien against the vehicle. 
E.  Testimony; Admissibility. The testimony of a person at a hearing held under this section is not admissible against him or her in any criminal proceeding except in a criminal prosecution for perjury. The testimony of a person at a hearing held under this section does not waive the person's constitutional right against self-incrimination. 
(Ord. 923 § 1 (part), 1997) 
9.99.050 - Return of seized property or discharge of lien. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, personal property seized pursuant to Section 9.99.020 shall be returned to the owner, or a lien filed against real property under Section 9.99.020 or against a motor vehicle under Section 9.99.040 shall be discharged, within seven days after the occurrence of any of the following: 
A.  A warrant is not issued against a person for the commission of a crime within seven days after the property is seized or, if the property is real property, within seven days after the lien is filed; 
B.  All charges against the consenting legal owner relating to the commission of a crime are dismissed; 
C.  The consenting legal owner charged with committing a crime is acquitted of the crime; 
D.  In the case of multiple defendants, all persons charged with committing a crime are acquitted of the crime; 
E.  Entry of a court order pursuant to this chapter for the return of the property or the discharge of the lien. 
(Ord. 923 § 1 (part), 1997) 
9.99.060 - Notice of return of seized property or discharge of lien to certain persons. 
A.  Notice of Return of Property. Within seven days after personal property is returned to the owner, or a lien filed against real property or a motor vehicle is discharged pursuant to Section 9.99.050, the police department, or if the property is real property, the prosecuting or city attorney who gave notice of the seizure of the property and the intent to forfeit and dispose of the property pursuant to Section 9.99.030, shall give notice to the persons who received notice pursuant to Section 9.99.030 that the property has been returned to the owner or that the lien has been discharged pursuant to Section 9.99.050. 
B.  Delivery of Notice. The notice required under subsection A of this section shall be a written notice delivered to the person or sent to the person by certified mail. If the name and addresses of the person are not reasonably ascertainable or delivery of the notice cannot reasonably be accomplished, the notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the personal property was seized or the real property is located for ten successive publishing days. 
(Ord. 923 § 1 (part), 1997) 
9.99.070 - Forfeiture procedures-Burden of proof. 
A.  If property subject to forfeiture under this chapter has a total value of less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), within seven days after the conviction of a person of a crime, the prosecuting or city attorney seeking forfeiture of the property shall give notice of the seizure of the property or, if a lien has been filed, the filing of the lien, and the intent to begin proceedings to forfeit and dispose of the property according to this chapter to each of the persons to whom notice is required to be given under Section 9.99.030. Notice shall be given in the same manner as required under Section 9.99.030. 
B.  Within twenty-one (21) days after receipt of the notice or of the date of the first publication of the notice under subsection A of this section, a person claiming an interest in property subject to the notice may file a claim with the city expressing his or her interest in the property. 
C.  If no claim is filed within the twenty-one (21) day period as described in subsection B of this section, the city shall declare the property forfeited and shall dispose of the property according to Section 9.99.080. 
D.  If a claim is filed within the twenty-one (21) day period as described in subsection B of this section, the city shall transmit the claim with a list and description of the property to the prosecuting or city attorney. The prosecuting or city attorney shall institute a civil action for forfeiture within seven days after the expiration of the twenty-one (21) day period. 
E.  If property subject to forfeiture has a total value of more than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), the prosecuting or city attorney shall institute a civil action for forfeiture within seven days after the conviction of a person of a crime. 
F.  At the forfeiture proceeding, the plaintiff shall prove the following by a preponderance of the evidence: 
1.  If the property is personal property, that the property is the proceeds of a crime, the substituted proceeds of a crime, or an instrumentality of a crime; 
2.  If the property is real property, that the property is the proceeds of a crime or the substituted proceeds of a crime; 
3.  If a person, other than the person convicted of the crime, claims an ownership or security interest in the property, that the person claiming the interest in the property had prior knowledge of, or consented to the commission of, the crime. 
G.  If the plaintiff fails to meet the burden of proof under subsection F of this section, the property shall be returned to the owner within seven days. 
(Ord. 923 § 1 (part), 1997) 
9.99.080 - Sale of forfeited property-Appointment of receiver for real property. 
A.  Sale of Forfeited Property. The city may sell property that is not required to be destroyed by law and that is not harmful to the public and may dispose of the proceeds and any money, negotiable instrument, security, or other thing of value that is forfeited in the following order of priority: 
1.  Pay any outstanding security interest of a secured party who did not have prior knowledge of, or consent to the commission of, the crime; 
2.  Satisfy any order of restitution in the prosecution for the crime; 
3.  Pay the claim of each person who shows that he or she is a victim of the crime to the extent that the claim is not covered by an order of restitution; 
4.  Pay any outstanding lien against the property that has been imposed by a governmental unit; 
5.  Pay the proper expenses of the proceedings for forfeiture and sale, including, but not limited to, expenses incurred during the seizure process and expenses for maintaining custody of the property, advertising, and court costs; 
6.  The balance, if any, shall be paid to the city, and seventy-five (75) percent of such money shall be used to enhance enforcement of the criminal laws and twenty-five (25) percent of the money shall be used to implement the Crime Victim's Rights Act, pursuant to M.C.L. 780.751 to M.C.L. 780.775. The director of finance shall annually report to the State Department of Management and Budget the amounts and uses of money received. 
B.  Appointment of Receiver. In the course of selling real property pursuant to subsection A of this section, the court, on motion of the prosecuting or city attorney, may appoint a receiver to dispose of the real property forfeited. The receiver is entitled to reasonable compensation. The receiver has authority to do all of the following: 
1.  List the forfeited real property for sale; 
2.  Make whatever arrangements are necessary for the maintenance and preservation of the forfeited real property; 
3.  Accept offers to purchase the forfeited real property; 
4.  Execute instruments transferring title to the forfeited real property. 
(Ord. 923 § 1 (part), 1997) 
9.99.090 - Jurisdiction. 
    The district court shall have equitable jurisdiction over forfeiture proceedings and may hear and determine a forfeiture action or a motion relating to a forfeiture action, and may issue and enforce any order or judgment relating to a forfeiture action. 
(Ord. 923 § 1 (part), 1997) 
Chapter 9.100 - PROHIBITION OF CONSUMPTION OR POSSESSION OF ALCOHOL BY PERSONS UNDER TWENTY-ONE (21) 
Sections: 

9.100.010 - Prohibition of consuming or possessing alcohol by persons under twenty-one (21). 
A.  A minor, defined herein as a person under twenty-one (21) years of age, shall not purchase or attempt to purchase alcoholic liquor, consume or attempt to consume alcoholic liquor, or possess or attempt to possess alcoholic liquor, except as provided in this section. A minor who violated this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided in Section 9.100.020. 
B.  This section does not prohibit a minor from possessing alcoholic liquor during regular working hours and in the course of his or her employment if employed by a person licensed by the Michigan Liquor Control Act, by the Liquor Control Commission, or by an agent of the commission, if the alcoholic liquor is not possessed for his or her personal consumption. 
C.  This section does not limit the civil or criminal liability of the vendor or the vendor's clerk, servant, agent or employee for a violation of this chapter. 
D.  The consumption of alcoholic liquor by a minor who is enrolled in a course offered by an accredited post secondary educational institution in an academic building of the institution under the supervision of a faculty member is not prohibited by this section if the purpose of the consumption is solely educational and is a requirement of the course. 
E.  The consumption by a minor of sacramental wine in connection with religious services at a church, synagogue, or temple is not prohibited by this section. 
F.  This section does not apply to a minor who participates in either or both of the following: 
1.  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the persons's employer and with the prior approval of the local prosecutor's office as part of an employer-sponsored internal enforcement action. 
2.  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the state police, the commission, or a local police agency as part of an enforcement action unless the initial or contemporaneous purchase or receipt of alcoholic liquor by the minor was not under the direction of the state police, the commission, or the local police agency and was not part of the undercover operation. 
G.  The state police, the commission, or a local police agency shall not recruit or attempt to recruit a minor for participation in an undercover operation at the scene of a violation of this section, MCL 436.1801(2) or local ordinance substantially corresponding to MCL 436.1801(2), or MCL 436.1701(1) or local ordinance substantially corresponding to MCL 436.1701(1). 
(Ord. 01-02, § 1 (part), 2002) 
9.100.020 - Penalty. 
A.  For the first violation of fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and may be ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in MCL 333.6107, and designated by the administrator of substance abuse services, and may be ordered to perform community service and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in this section. 
B.  For a violation of this chapter following a prior conviction or juvenile adjudication for a violation of this chapter or Section 33b(1) of former 1933 (Ex Sess) PA 8, a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), and may be ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in MCL 333.6107, and designated by the administrator of substance abuse services, to perform community service, and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in this chapter. 
C.  For a violation of this ordinance following two or more prior convictions or juvenile adjudications for a violation of this chapter or Section 33b(1) of former 1933 (Ex Sess) PA 8, a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and may be ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in MCL 333.6107, and designated by the administrator of substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in this chapter. 
(Ord. 01-02, § 1 (part), 2002) 
9.100.030 - Fraudulent identification. 
    A person who furnishes fraudulent identification to a minor, or notwithstanding Section 9.100.010, a minor who uses fraudulent identification to purchase alcoholic liquor is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than ninety-three (93) days or a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or both. 
(Ord. 01-02, § 1 (part), 2002) 
9.100.040 - Screening and assessment. 
    The court may order the person convicted of violation Section 9.100.010 to undergo screening and assessment by a person or agency as designated by the substance abuse coordinating agency as defined in MCL 333.6103, in order to determine whether the person is likely to benefit from rehabilitative services, including alcohol or drug education and alcohol or drug treatment programs. 
(Ord. 01-02, § 1 (part), 2002) 
9.100.050 - License sanction. 
    The secretary of state shall suspend the operator's or chauffeur's license of an individual convicted of violating Section 9.100.010 or 9.100.030 as provided in Section 319 of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.319. 
(Ord. 01-02, § 1 (part), 2002) 
9.100.060 - Preliminary breath test. 
    A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe a minor has consumed alcoholic liquor may require the person to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis. A peace officer may arrest a person based in whole or in part upon the results of a preliminary chemical breath analysis. The results of a preliminary chemical breath analysis or other acceptable blood alcohol test are admissible in a criminal prosecution to determine whether the minor has consumed or possessed alcoholic liquor. A minor who refuses to submit to a preliminary chemical breath test analysis as required in this ordinance is responsible for a civil infraction and may be ordered to pay a civil fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. 01-02, § 1 (part), 2002) 
9.100.070 - Notification of parents for minors under eighteen (18). 
    A law enforcement agency, upon determining that a person less than eighteen (18) years of age who is not emancipated under MCL 722.1 to 722.6, allegedly consumed, possessed, purchased, or attempted to consume, possess or purchase alcoholic liquor in violation of this chapter shall notify the parent or parents, custodian, or guardian of the person as to the nature of the violation if the name of a parent, guardian or custodian is reasonably ascertainable by the law enforcement agency. The notice required by this chapter shall be made not later than forty-eight (48) hours after the law enforcement agency determines that the person who allegedly violated Section 9.100.010 is less than eighteen (18) years of age and not emancipated under MCL 722.1 to 722.6. The notice may be made by any means reasonably calculated to give prompt actual notice including, but not limited to, notice in person, by telephone, or by first-class mail. If an individual less than seventeen (17) years of age is incarcerated for violating Section 9.100.010, his or her parents or legal guardian shall be notified immediately as provided in this section. 
(Ord. 01-02, § 1 (part), 2002) 
XI. - IN CUSTODY COST RECOVERY 
Chapter 9.200 - MEDICAL AND EMERGENCY SERVICE 
Sections: 

9.200.010 - Purpose. 
    In order to protect the city from extraordinary expenses resulting from the utilization of city resources in response to medical or emergency calls or services required for individuals in police custody, this article authorizes the imposition and collection of fees to recover actual costs incurred by the city in responding to such incidents. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, pt. I, 1-25-2011) 
9.200.020 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of the terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    "Assessable costs" means those costs for services for individuals in custody and incurred by the city in connection with a response for medical and/or emergency services, including transportation, cost of equipment, cost of materials, wages and administrative costs. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, pt. I, 1-25-2011) 
9.200.030 - Cost recovery authorization and procedure. 
A.  Any person in the custody of the Hazel Park Police or Hazel Park Police Department who utilizes city services for medical and/or emergency services including transportation shall be required to reimburse the city for all assessable costs incurred. 
B.  The assessable costs shall be a charge against the person liable for the expenses under this chapter. The expense constitutes a debt of that person which may be imposed by the city and/or the court. 
C.  The city treasurer or their designee shall within thirty (30) days, or as soon thereafter as is feasible, of receiving a statement of assessable costs submit a bill for the same by first class mail or personal service to the person liable for these expenses as enumerated under this chapter. The bill shall require full payment within thirty (30) days from the date of mailing or personal service. If payment is not made in full and/or installments as mutually agreed to by the city and the person liable therefor, statutory interest shall commence on the thirty-first day on the unpaid balance thereof. 
D.  Any failure by a person described in this chapter as liable for the assessable costs to pay the bill submitted by the city treasurer within thirty (30) days of mailing or personal service shall render such matter in default. If the person liable for the debt refuses to pay the city shall pursue any and all of its remedies, in law and/or equity, including, but not limited to, filing suit, seeking contempt proceedings in court, seeking revocation of any probation imposed by the court, turning the matter over to a collection agency for collection and any other remedies available to it under the law. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, pt. I, 1-25-2011) 
Chapter 9.300 - COSTS OF INCARCERATION 
Sections: 

9.300.010 - Recovery of inmate expenses. 
    The City of Hazel park may seek reimbursement from any person who is or was a convicted inmate in the city's jail for expenses incurred by the city in relation to the incarceration of that person, as follows: 
A.  Not more than sixty dollars ($60.00) per day for the expenses of maintaining that inmate or the actual per diem cost of maintaining that inmate, whichever is less, for the entire period of time the inmate was confined in the city jail, including any period of pre-trial detention. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, pt. II, 1-25-2011) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapters: 
Chapter 10.04 - UNIFORM TRAFFIC CODE 
Sections: 

10.04.010 - Code and amendments and revisions adopted. 
    The Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages as promulgated by the director of the Michigan department of state police pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act of 1969, 1969 PA 306, MCL 24.201 to 24.328 and made effective October 30, 2002, and all future amendments and revisions to the Uniform Traffic Code when they are promulgated and effective in this state are incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. 23-02 § 1, 2002: Ord. 909 § 1, 1997: Ord. 663 § 1, 1981) 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § I, 10-27-2008) 
10.04.020 - References in Code. 
    References in the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages to a "governmental unit" shall mean the City of Hazel Park. 
(Ord. 663 § 2, 1981) 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § I, 10-27-2008) 
10.04.025 - Notice to be published. 
    The city clerk shall publish this ordinance in the manner required by law and shall publish, at the same time, a notice stating the purpose of the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages and the fact that a complete copy of the code is available to the public at the office of the clerk for inspection. 
(Ord. 711 § 2, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § I, 10-27-2008) 
10.04.030 - Penalties. 
    The penalties for violation of any civil infraction under the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages, as adopted by reference by the City of Hazel Park, shall be as set by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 663 § 3, 1981) 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § I, 10-27-2008; Ord. No. 02-12, pt. I, 3-27-2012) 
Chapter 10.05 - MICHIGAN VEHICLE CODE 
Sections: 

10.05.010 - Code and amendment and revisions adopted. 
    The Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, M.C.L. 257.1 to 257.923, and all future amendments and revisions to the Michigan Vehicle Code when they are effective in this state are incorporated and adopted by reference. 
(Ord. 10-04 § 1 (part), 2003: Ord. 21-02 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.05.020 - References in code. 
    References in the Michigan Vehicle Code to "local authorities" shall mean the city of Hazel Park. 
(Ord. 10-04 § 1 (part), 2003: Ord. 21-02 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.05.030 - Notice to be published. 
    The city clerk shall publish the ordinance codified in this chapter in the manner required by law and shall publish, at the same time, a notice stating the purpose of the Michigan Vehicle Code and the fact that a complete copy of the code is available to the public at the office of the clerk for inspection. 
(Ord. 10-04 § 1 (part), 2003: Ord. 21-02 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.05.040 - Penalties. 
    The penalties for violation of any civil infraction under the Michigan Vehicle Code as adopted by reference by the City of Hazel Park shall be as set by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 10-04 § 1 (part), 2003: Ord. 21-02 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 02-12, pt. II, 3-27-2012) 
10.05.050 - Adoption of code by reference. 
    The Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.1 to 257.923, as amended, is hereby adopted by reference. MCL 257.625(1)(C) of the Vehicle Code is specifically adopted by reference, pursuant to Public Act 7 of 2012. 
(Ord. No. 03-12, § 2, 3-27-2012) 
10.05.060 - Violations and penalties. 
    The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code are adopted by reference. The city may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than ninety-three (93) days; provided, however, that a violation of MCL 625(1)(C) is punishable by one or more of the following: 
(i)  Community service of not more than three hundred sixty (360) hours. 
(ii)  Imprisonment for not more than one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(iii)  A fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or more than seven hundred dollars ($700.00). 
(Ord. No. 03-12, § 3, 3-27-2012) 
Chapter 10.06 - DEFINITIONS* 
Sections: 

10.06.085 - Civil infraction. 
    "Civil infraction" means an act or omission prohibited by law which is not a crime as defined in Section 5 of Act No. 308 of the Public Acts of 1931, as amended, being Section 750.5 of the Michigan Compiled Laws, and for which civil sanctions may be ordered. 
(Ord. 597 § 2, 1979) 
10.06.480 - Vehicle Code. 
    "Vehicle Code" means Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949, as amended, being Sections 257.1 to 257.923 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(Ord. 597 § 3, 1979) 
Chapter 10.07 - VEHICLE INSURANCE 
Sections: 

10.07.010 - Vehicle insurance. 
    An owner or registrant of a motor vehicle or motorcycle with respect to which security is required, who operates the motor vehicle or motorcycle or permits it to be operated upon a public street or highway without having in full force and effect security complying with MCLA 500.3101 or MCLA 500.3103 is guilty of a misdemeanor. A person who operates a motor vehicle or motorcycle upon a highway in the city with the knowledge that the owner or registrant does not have security in full force and effect is guilty of a misdemeanor. A person convicted of a misdemeanor under this section shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for ninety-three (93) days in jail or both. 
(Ord. 06-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
(Ord. No. 01-12, pt. I, 1-24-2012) 
10.07.020 - Proof of insurance. 
    The failure of a person to produce evidence that a motor vehicle or motorcycle has in full force and effect security complying with this chapter or MCLA 500.3101 or MCLA 500.3103 on the date of issuance of the citation, creates a rebuttable presumption in a prosecution under Section 10.07.010 of this chapter that the motor vehicle or motorcycle did not have in full force and effect security complying with this chapter or MCLA 500.3101 or MCLA 500.3103 on the date of the issuance of the citation. 
(Ord. 06-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.07.030 - Nonresident owner or registrant. 
    A nonresident owner or registrant of a motor vehicle or motorcycle not registered in this state shall not operate or permit the motor vehicle or motorcycle to be operated in this state for an aggregate of more than thirty (30) days in any calendar year unless he or she continuously maintains security for the payment of benefits pursuant to this chapter or MCLA 500.3101 et seq. 
(Ord. 06-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.07.040 - False or fraudulent insurance. 
    A person who uses an altered, fraudulent, or counterfeit certificate of insurance is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than ninety-three (93) days in jail and/or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 01-12, pt. I, 1-24-2012) 
Chapter 10.26 - MOTOR CARRIER LOAD 
Sections: 

10.26.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Motor Carrier Load Ordinance." 
(Ord. 852 § 1, 1993) 
10.26.020 - Motor carrier safety regulations adopted by reference-Definitions. 
A.  1.  The following provisions of Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations as of February 28, 1990, are adopted by reference: Motor Carrier Safety Regulations, being 49 C.F.R., parts 390 through 393, inclusive, and parts 395 through 399, inclusive, including Appendices C, D, E and G. 
2.  Part numbers as used in this chapter shall refer to the like part numbers in Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations as of February 28, 1990. 
3.  "Interstate" means intrastate or interstate, or both, as applicable. 
    "Special agent of the Federal Highway Administration" or "administrative personnel" means a peace officer or an enforcement member or a vehicle inspector of the Hazel Park police department. 
    "United States Department of Transportation," "Federal Highway Administration," "Federal Highway Administrator," "director" or "Bureau of Motor Carrier Safety" means the Hazel Park police department. 
B.  1. The following provisions of the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963, P.A. 1963, No. 181, as amended, are adopted by reference: Sections 1a; 2a through 2w, inclusive; 3; 5; 6; 7; 7b; and 11. 
2.  Section numbers as used in this chapter shall refer to the like section numbers in the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963, as amended. 
3.  "Motor carrier officer," as used in Section 6 means a duly sworn Hazel Park police officer. 
(Ord. 15-00 § 1, 2000; Ord. 852 § 2, 1993) 
10.26.030 - Size, weight and load provisions adopted by reference. 
A.  The following provisions of the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code, P.A. 1949, Number 300, as amended, are adopted by reference: Section 605; Section 683; Sections 716 through 726b inclusive. 
B.  Section numbers as used in this chapter shall refer to like section numbers in the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. 15-00 § 2, 2000: Ord. 852 § 3, 1993) 
10.26.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The penalties provided by the Motor Carrier Safety Act and the Michigan Vehicle Code are adopted by reference. 
(Ord. 15-00 § 3, 2000: Ord. 868 § 1, 1994: Ord. 852 § 7, 1993) 
Chapter 10.40 - EXPENSE OF EMERGENCY RESPONSE 
Sections: 

10.40.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "Emergency response" means the providing, sending and/or utilizing public service, public works, police, firefighting, rescue and emergency medical services personnel and services by the city to an accident scene and/or a traffic stop and arrest involving a motor vehicle where one or more of the drivers were operating the motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, operating a motor vehicle with an unlawful blood alcohol level, or operating a motor vehicle while visibly impaired, pursuant to Michigan Compiled Laws (MCL) 257.625, et seq., which is incorporated herein and made a part hereof. 
B.  "Expense of an emergency response" means those costs and expenses incurred by the city making an appropriate emergency response to the incident, including the cost and expense of providing public service, public works, police, fire, rescue and emergency medical services at the scene of the accident and/or traffic stop and arrest, including but not limited to, the regular and overtime hourly wages and benefits of public service, public works, police, fire, rescue and emergency medical services personnel, the cost and expense of special equipment used during the response, such as use of preliminary breath test and breathalyzer equipment, the cost and expense of any special personnel called to the scene to assist in the response, the cost and expense of incarceration, the cost and expense of prosecution, the cost and expense incurred by the city in having to collect the same against person liable therefore and any statutory interest on the unpaid balance thereof; provided, however, the foregoing costs and expenses shall only include those costs and expenses directly arising out of the response to a particular incident plus, collection fees and statutory interest. The term "statutory interest" shall either mean that interest determined by the state of Michigan Treasurer's Office for interest charges on judgments or the interest charged by Oakland County for performing the same services as defined in subsection A of this section, whichever is higher. Interest shall commence on the thirty-first day after the bill for said expenses has been mailed or personally served as provided for in Section 10.40.060. 
(Ord. 882 § 2 (part), 1995: Ord. 766 § 1 (part), 1989) 
10.40.020 - Operator under the influence-Liability. 
    Any person who is under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or any drug, or while visibly impaired, or under the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage and any drug, whose operation of a motor vehicle while under that influence or visibly impaired proximately causes an appropriate emergency response is liable for the expense of the emergency response to the city. 
(Ord. 766 § 1 (part), 1989) 
10.40.030 - Influence of alcoholic beverage or drug-Inability to operate motor vehicle-Presumptions. 
    For purposes of this section, a person is under the influence of or impaired by an alcoholic beverage or any drug, or the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage or drug, or both, when his or her physical or mental abilities are impaired to a degree that he or she no longer has the ability to operate a motor vehicle with the caution characteristic of a sober person of ordinary prudence or when he or she is affected by the alcohol or drug so that it influences him or her to drive other than in a sober manner. For purposes of this chapter, the presumptions described in Section 257.625(2) et seq. of the Michigan Compiled Laws shall apply. 
(Ord. 766 § 1 (part), 1988) 
10.40.040 - Charge against person liable-Collection of debt. 
    The expense of an emergency response shall be a charge against the person liable for expenses under this chapter. The expense of an emergency response constitutes a debt of that person which may be imposed by the court and/or city and is collectible by the city and/or the court. Any costs or expenses assessed and received under this chapter shall be turned over to the city treasurer as reimbursement for those costs and expenses incurred. 
(Ord. 882 § 2 (part), 1995: Ord. 766 § 1 (part), 1989) 
10.40.060 - Costs and payment. 
    In addition to any other fines, costs and fees assessed by the court, the court shall assess a flat fee to cover the costs incurred for emergency response expenses, pursuant to this chapter, in the following amounts: 
A.  Three hundred ($300.00) dollars for all cases in which the amount of alcohol or presence of a controlled substance or both in a driver's blood is shown by analysis of a person's blood. 
B.  One hundred fifty ($150.00) dollars for all cases in which the amount of alcohol in a driver's blood is shown by chemical analysis of a person's breath. 
(Ord. No. 06-13, pt. I, 3-26-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-13, pt. I, adopted March 26, 2013, amended § 10.40.060 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 10.40.060, pertained to city treasurer to submit bill for expenses incurred for emergency response, and derived from Ord. 766 § 1 (part) of 1989 and Ord. 882 § 2 (part) of 1995. 
10.40.070 - Failure to pay. 
    Any failure by a person described in this chapter as liable for the expense of an emergency response, to pay the bill submitted by the city treasurer and/or the court clerk within thirty (30) days of mailing or personal service of the same shall render such matter in default. If the person who is liable for the debt refuses to pay the bill and costs and owns real estate within the city, the costs and expenses, including collection fees and statutory interest, may be assessed against the real estate in the manner as provided in the City Charter for delinquent taxes, bills and assessments. In any event, the city may pursue any and all of its remedies, in law and/or equity, including but not limited to filing suit, foreclosing on property, seeking contempt proceedings in court, seeking revocation of any probation imposed by the court, turning the matter over to a collection agency for collection and any other remedies available to it under the law. 
(Ord. 882 § 2 (part), 1995: Ord. 766 § 1 (part), 1989) 
Chapter 10.41 - SCHOOL BUSES, SEATBELTS, CHILD RESTRAINT AND ABANDONED VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.41.010 - School bus. 
A.  The driver of a vehicle overtaking or meeting a school bus which has stopped and is displaying two alternately flashing red lights located at the same level shall bring the vehicle to a full stop not less than twenty (20) feet from the school bus and shall not proceed until the school bus resumes motion or the visual signals are no longer actuated. The driver of a vehicle who fails to stop for a school bus as required by this subsection, who passes a school bus in violation of this subsection, or who fails to stop for a school bus in violation of an ordinance that complies with this subsection, is responsible for a civil infraction. 
B.  The driver of a vehicle upon a highway which has been divided into two roadways by leaving an intervening space, or by a physical barrier, or clearly indicated dividing sections so constructed as to impede vehicular traffic, need not stop upon meeting a school bus which has stopped across the dividing space, barrier or section. 
C.  Any proceeding for a violation of subsection A of this section, proof that the particular vehicle described in the citation was in violation of subsection A of this section, together with proof that the defendant named in the citation was, at the time of the violation, the registered owner of the vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle was the driver of the vehicle at the time of the violation. 
D.  In addition to a civil fine and costs, the judge, district court referee, or district court magistrate, may order a person who violates this section to perform not to exceed one hundred (100) hours of community service at a school. 
(Ord. 911 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 826 § 1 (part), 1991) 
10.41.020 - Safety belt required. 
A.  This section shall not apply to a driver or passenger of: 
1.  A motor vehicle manufactured before January 1, 1965; 
2.  A bus; 
3.  A motorcycle; 
4.  A moped; 
5.  A motor vehicle either driver or passenger possessing a written verification from a physician that the driver or passenger is unable to wear a safety belt for physical or medical reasons; 
6.  A motor vehicle which is not required to be equipped with safety belts under federal law; 
7.  A commercial or United States postal service vehicle which makes frequent stops for the purpose of pick up or delivery of goods or services; 
8.  A motor vehicle operated by a rural carrier of the United States postal service while serving his or her rural postal route. 
B.  This section shall not apply to a passenger of a school bus. 
C.  Each driver and front seat passenger of a motor vehicle operated on a street or highway in the city shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened safety belt, except that a child less than four years of age shall be protected as required in Section 10.41.030 of this chapter. 
D.  Each driver of a motor vehicle transporting a child four years of age or more but less than sixteen (16) years of age in a motor vehicle shall secure the child in a properly adjusted and fastened safety belt. If the motor vehicle is transporting more children than there are safety belts available for use, all safety belts available in the motor vehicle are being utilized in compliance with this section, and the driver and all front passengers comply with subsection C of this section, then the driver of a motor vehicle transporting a child four years of age or more but less than sixteen (16) years of age for which there is not an available safety belt is in compliance with this subsection, if the child is seated in other than the front seat of the motor vehicle. However, if the motor vehicle is a pick up truck with an extended cab or jump seats, and all safety belts in the front seat are being used, the driver may transport such child in the front seat without a safety belt. 
E.  Enforcement of this section by state or local law enforcement agencies shall be accomplished only as a secondary action when the driver of a motor vehicle has been detained for a suspected violation of another section of this act. 
F.  Failure to wear a safety belt in violation of this section may be considered evidence of negligence and may reduce the recovery for damages arising out of the ownership, maintenance, or operation of a motor vehicle. However, such negligence shall not reduce the recovery for damages by more than five percent. 
G.  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
H.  Points shall not be assessed for a violation of this section. 
(Ord. 911 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 826 § 1 (part), 1991) 
10.41.030 - Mandatory child restraints. 
A.  Except as provided in this section, or as otherwise provided by law, a rule promulgated pursuant to the administrative procedures act of 1969, Act No. 306 of the Public Acts of 1969, as amended, being Sections MCL 24.201 to MCL 24.328 of the Michigan Compiled Laws, or federal regulation, each driver transporting a child in a motor vehicle shall properly secure each child in a child restraint system as follows: 
1.  Any child less than one year of age in a child restraint system which meets the standard prescribed in 49 CFR 571.213, except as provided in subsection F of this section. 
2.  Any child one year of age or more but less than four years of age, when transported in a front seat, in a child restraint system which meets the standards prescribed in 49 CFR 571.213, except as provided in subsection F of this section. 
3.  Any child one year of age or more but less than four years of age, when transported in a rear seat, in a child restraint system which meets the standards prescribed in 49 CFR 571.213, unless the child is secured by a safety belt provided in a motor vehicle, except as provided in subsection F of this section. 
B.  This section does not apply to any child being nursed. 
C.  This section does not apply if the motor vehicle being driven is a bus, school bus, taxi cab, moped, motorcycle, or other motor vehicle not required to be equipped with safety belts under federal law or regulations. 
D.  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
E.  Points shall not be assessed for a violation of this section. 
F.  The Secretary of State may exempt by rules promulgated pursuant to Act. No. 306 of the Public Acts of 1969, as amended, a class of children from the requirements of this section, if the Secretary of State determines that the use of the child restraint system required under subsection A of this section is impractical because of the physical unfitness, a medical problem, or body size. The Secretary of State may specify an alternate means of protection for children exempted under this subsection. 
(Ord. 911 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 826 § 1 (part), 1991) 
10.41.040 - Abandoned vehicles. 
A.  Abandonment of Vehicle; Offense; Presumption of Ownership; Civil Penalty; Procedure for Disposition. 
1.  A person shall not abandon a vehicle in the city of Hazel Park. It is presumed that the last titled owner of the vehicle is responsible for abandoning the vehicle unless the person provides a record of sale as that term is defined in Section 10.41.120 of this chapter. A person who violates this section and who fails to redeem the vehicle before disposition of the vehicle as herein provided is responsible for a civil infraction and shall be ordered to pay a civil fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
2.  As used in this section abandoned vehicle means either of the following: 
a.  A vehicle that has remained on private property without the consent of the owner; 
b.  A vehicle that has remained on public property for a period of not less than forty-eight (48) hours, or on a state trunk line highway as described in MCL 247.651, as follows: 
i.  If a valid registration plate is affixed to the vehicle, for a period of not less than eighteen (18) hours, 
ii.  If a valid registration plate is not affixed to the vehicle. 
3.  If a vehicle has remained on public property for the period of time described in subsection (A)(2)(b) of this section so that it qualifies as abandoned, the police or its designee shall determine whether the vehicle has been reported stolen and may affix a written notice to the vehicle. The written notice shall contain the following information: 
a.  The date and time the notice was affixed; 
b.  The name and address of the Hazel Park police department; 
c.  The name and badge number of the police officer affixing the notice; 
d.  The date and time the vehicle may be taken into custody and stored at the owner's expense or scrapped if the vehicle is not removed; 
e.  The year, make, and vehicle identification number of the vehicle, if available. 
4.  If the vehicle is an abandoned vehicle, the police agency or the agency's designee may have the towing agency take the vehicle into custody. 
5.  A police agency that has received a vehicle taken into custody as abandoned shall do all of the following: 
a.  Recheck to determine if the vehicle has been reported stolen; 
b.  Within twenty-four (24) hours after the vehicle is taken into custody, enter the vehicle as abandoned into the law enforcement information network, and notify the Secretary of State through the law enforcement information network that the vehicle has been taken into custody as abandoned. Each notification shall contain the following information: 
i.  The year, make, and vehicle identification number of the vehicle, if available, 
ii.  The address or approximate location from which the vehicle was taken into custody, 
iii.  The date on which the vehicle was taken into custody, 
iv.  The name and address of the police agency that had the vehicle taken into custody, 
v.  The name and business address of the custodian of the vehicle, 
vi.  The name of the court that has jurisdiction over the case. 
c.  Within seven days after receiving notice under subsection (A)(5)(b) of this section that the vehicle has been taken into custody, the Secretary of State shall do both of the following: 
i.  Send to the last titled owner and secured party, as shown by the records of the Secretary of State as described in MCL 257.221 or 247.237, by first class mail or personal service, notice that the vehicle is considered abandoned. The format for the notice shall be furnished by the Secretary of State. Each notice shall contain the information as required by MCL 257.252a(5)(c)(i)(A-I), (ii). 
6.  The owner may contest the fact that the vehicle is considered abandoned or the reasonableness of the towing fees and daily storage fees by requesting a hearing. A request for a hearing shall be made by filing a petition with the court specified in the notice described in subsection (A)(5)(c) within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice. If the owner requests a hearing, the matter shall be resolved after a hearing conducted under Sections 10.41.070 and 10.41.080 of this chapter. An owner who requests a hearing may obtain release of the vehicle by posting a towing and storage bond in an amount equal to the forty dollars ($40.00) plus the accrued towing and storage fees with the court. The owner of a vehicle who requests a hearing may obtain release of the vehicle by paying a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) to the court and the accrued towing and storage fees instead of posting the towing and storage bond. 
7.  If the owner does not request a hearing under subsection (A)(6) of this section he or she may obtain the release of the vehicle by paying a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) and the accrued towing and storage fees to the custodian of the vehicle. The custodian of the vehicle shall forward twenty-five dollars ($25.00) of the fee to the Secretary of State within thirty (30) days after receipt in a manner prescribed by the Secretary of State, who shall deposit the fee into the abandoned vehicle fund created in MCL 257.252h. 
8.  If the owner does not redeem the vehicle or request a hearing within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice described in subsection (A)(5)(c), the secured party may obtain the release of the vehicle by paying a forty dollars ($40.00) fee plus the accrued charges to the custodian of the vehicle. The custodian of the vehicle shall forward twenty-five dollars ($25.00) of the fee to the Secretary of State, who shall deposit the fee into the abandoned vehicle fund created in MCL 257.252h. 
9.  If a vehicle has remained on private property without the consent of the owner, the owner of the private property may have the vehicle taken into custody as an abandoned vehicle by contacting a local towing agency. 
10.  Before removing the vehicle from private property in Hazel Park, the towing agency shall notify the Hazel Park police department that the vehicle is being removed. The police department shall determine if the vehicle has been reported stolen and have the vehicle entered into the law enforcement information network as an abandoned vehicle. 
11.  Within twenty-four (24) hours after taking the abandoned vehicle into custody, the police agency shall notify the Secretary of State through the law enforcement network that the vehicle has been taken into custody as abandoned. Each notification shall contain the following information: 
a.  The year, make, and vehicle identification number of the vehicle, if available; 
b.  The address or approximate location from which the vehicle was taken into custody; 
c.  The date on which the vehicle was taken into custody; 
d.  The name and address of the police agency that had the vehicle taken into custody; 
e.  The name and business address of the custodian of the vehicle; 
f.  The name of the court that has jurisdiction over the case. 
12.  Within seven days after being notified under subsection (A)(11) of this section, the Secretary of State shall do both of the following: 
a.  Send to the owner and secured party, as shown by the records of the Secretary of State, by first class mail or personal service, notice that the vehicle is considered abandoned. The form for the notice shall be furnished by the Secretary of State. Each notice form shall contain the following information: 
i.  The year, make, and vehicle identification number of the vehicle, if available; 
ii.  The location from which the vehicle was taken into custody; 
iii.  The date on which the vehicle was taken into custody; 
iv.  The name of the towing agency that had the vehicle taken into custody; 
v.  The business address of the custodian of the vehicle; 
vi.  The procedure to redeem the vehicle; 
vii.  The procedure to contest the fact that the vehicle is considered abandoned or the reasonableness of the towing fees and daily storage fees; 
viii.  A form petition that the owner may file in person or by mail with the specified court that requests a hearing on the custodian's action; 
ix.  A warning that the failure to redeem the vehicle or to request a hearing within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice may result in the sale of the vehicle and the termination of all rights of the owner and the secured party to the vehicle or the proceeds of the sale. 
b.  Enter the information described in subdivision (A)(12)(a) of this section on a website maintained by the department for public use in locating vehicles that are removed under this section as abandoned. 
13.  The owner may contest the fact that the vehicle is abandoned or, unless the towing fees and daily storage fees are established by contract with the city of Hazel Park or the Hazel Park police department and comply with Section 10.41.110 of this chapter, the reasonableness of the towing fees and daily storage fees by requesting a hearing. A request for a hearing shall be made by filing a petition with the court specified in the notice within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice. If the owner requests a hearing, the matter shall be resolved after a hearing conducted under Section 10.41.080 of this chapter. An owner who requests a hearing may obtain release of the vehicle by posting with the court a towing and storage bond in an amount equal to forty dollars ($40.00) plus the accrued towing and storage fees. The owner of a vehicle who requests a hearing may obtain release of the vehicle by paying a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) to the court plus the towing and storage fees instead of posting the towing and storage bond. 
14.  If the owner does not request a hearing, he or she may obtain the release of the vehicle by paying a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) plus the accrued charges to the custodian of the vehicle. The custodian shall forward twenty-five dollars ($25.00) of the fee collected under this subsection to the Secretary of State within thirty (30) days after receipt in a manner prescribed by the Secretary of State, who shall deposit the fee into the abandoned vehicle fund created in MCL 257.252h. 
15.  If the owner does not redeem the vehicle or request a hearing within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice, the secured party may obtain the release of the vehicle by paying a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) and the accrued towing and storage fees to the custodian of the vehicle. The custodian shall forward twenty-five dollars ($25.00) of the fee collected under this subsection to the Secretary of State within thirty (30) days after receipt in a manner prescribed by the Secretary of State, who shall deposit the fee into the abandoned vehicle fund created in MCL 257.252h. 
16.  Not less than twenty (20) days after the disposition of the hearing described in subsection (A)(6) of this section or, if a hearing is not requested, not less than twenty (20) days after the date of the notice, the police department if the abandoned vehicle is found on public property, or the custodian of the vehicle if the vehicle is found on private property, shall offer the vehicle for sale at a public sale under Section 10.41.090 of this chapter. 
17.  If the ownership of a vehicle that is considered abandoned under this section cannot be determined either because of the condition of the vehicle identification numbers or because a check with the records of the Secretary of State does not reveal ownership, the police department may sell the vehicle at public sale as provided in Section 10.41.090 not less than thirty (30) days after public notice of the sale has been published. 
18.  The Secretary of State shall release a vehicle for disposition under Section 10.41.050 or 10.41.090 of this chapter within forty-five (45) days after the vehicle is entered into the law enforcement information network as an abandoned vehicle. 
(Ord. 14-05 § 1 (part), 2005: Ord. 826 § 1 (part), 1991) 
10.41.050 - Procedure for disposition of registered abandoned scrap vehicles. 
A.  As used in this section: 
1.  "Registered abandoned scrap vehicle" means a vehicle that meets all of the following requirements: 
a.  Is on public or private property; 
b.  Is seven or more years old; 
c.  Is apparently inoperable or is extensively damaged, to the extent that the cost of repairing the vehicle so that it is operational and safe as required by MCL 257.683 would exceed the fair market value of that vehicle; 
d.  Is currently registered or titled in the state of Michigan or displays current year registration plates from another state. 
2.  "Unregistered abandoned scrap vehicle" means a vehicle that meets all of the following requirements: 
a.  Is on public or private property; 
b.  Is seven or more years old; 
c.  Is apparently inoperable or is extensively damaged, to the extent that the cost of repairing the vehicle so that it is operational and safe as required by MCL 257.683 would exceed the fair market value of that vehicle. 
d.  Is not currently registered in this state and does not display current year registration plates from another state. 
B.  The police department or its designee or, if the vehicle is on private property, the property owner may have an unregistered abandoned scrap vehicle taken into custody, in which case the police department shall do all of the following: 
1.  Determine if the vehicle has been reported stolen; 
2.  Take two photographs of the vehicle; 
3.  Make a report to substantiate the vehicle as an unregistered abandoned scrap vehicle. The report shall contain the following information: 
a.  The year, make and vehicle identification number if available, 
b.  The date of abandonment, 
c.  The location of abandonment, 
d.  A detailed listing of the damage or the missing equipment, 
e.  The reporting officer's name and title, 
f.  The location where the vehicle is being held; 
4.  Within twenty-four (24) hours after taking the vehicle into custody, enter the vehicle into the law enforcement information network. 
C.  Within twenty-four (24) hours, excluding Saturday, Sunday, and legal holidays, after taking the vehicle into custody, the police department or its designee shall complete a release form and release the vehicle to the towing service or a used vehicle parts dealer or vehicle scrap metal processor, who shall then transmit that release form to the Secretary of State and apply for a certificate of scrapping. Upon receipt of the release form and application, the Secretary of State shall issue a certificate of title or a certificate of scrapping. 
D.  The release form described in subsection C of this section shall be furnished by the Secretary of State and shall include a certification executed by the Hazel Park police department or its designee when the abandoned scrap vehicle is released. The certification shall state that the police agency has complied with all the requirements of subsection (B)(2) and (3) of this section. 
E.  The Secretary of State shall retain the records relating to an abandoned scrap vehicle for not less than two years. The two photographs taken under subsection (B)(2) of this section shall be retained by the police department or its designee for not less than two years. After the certificate of scrapping has been issued, a certificate of title for the vehicle shall not be issued again. 
F.  The police department or its designee or, if the vehicle is on private property, the property owner may have a registered abandoned scrap vehicle taken into custody, in which case the police department or the towing service shall do all of the following. 
1.  Determine if the vehicle has been reported stolen; 
2.  Take two photographs of the vehicle; 
3.  Make a report to substantiate the vehicle as an unregistered abandoned scrap vehicle. The report shall contain the following information: 
a.  The year, make and vehicle identification number if available, 
b.  The date of abandonment, 
c.  The location of abandonment, 
d.  A detailed listing of the damage or the missing equipment, 
e.  The reporting officer's name and title, 
f.  The location where the vehicle is being held; 
4.  Within twenty-four (24) hours after taking the vehicle into custody, enter the vehicle into the law enforcement information network. 
G.  Within seven days after taking the vehicle into custody, the Secretary of State shall send to the last titled owner and secured party, as shown by the records of the Secretary of State, by first class mail or personal service, notice that the vehicle is considered abandoned. The form for the notice shall be furnished by the Secretary of State. Each notice form shall contain the information required by MCL 257.252b (7) (a)(b)(c)(d)(e)(f)(g)(h)(i)(j). 
H.  The registered owner of a registered abandoned scrap vehicle may contest the fact that the vehicle is abandoned or the reasonableness of the towing fees and daily storage fees by requesting a hearing. A request for a hearing shall be made by filing a petition with the court specified in the notice in subsection G of this section within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice. If the owner requests a hearing, the matter shall be resolved after a hearing conducted under Section 10.41.080 of this chapter. An owner who requests a hearing may obtain release of the vehicle by posting a towing and storage bond equal to forty dollars ($40.00) plus the accrued towing and storage fees with the court. The owner of a vehicle who requests a hearing may obtain release of the vehicle by paying a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) plus the towing and storage fees to the court instead of posting the towing and storage bond. 
I.  If the owner does not request a hearing under subsection G of this section, he or she may obtain the release of the vehicle by paying a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) plus the accrued charges to the custodian of the vehicle. The custodian shall forward twenty-five dollars ($25.00) of the fee collected under this subsection to the Secretary of State within thirty (30) days after receipt in a manner prescribed by the Secretary of State, who shall deposit the fee into the abandoned vehicle fund created in MCL 257.252h. 
J.  If the owner does not redeem the vehicle or request a hearing within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice described in subsection G of this section, the secured party may obtain the release of the vehicle by paying a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) plus the accrued charges to the custodian of the vehicle. The custodian shall forward two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) of the fee collected under this subsection to the Secretary of State within thirty (30) days after receipt in a manner prescribed by the Secretary of State, who shall deposit the fee into the abandoned vehicle fund created in MCL 257.252h. 
K.  Not less than twenty (20) days after the disposition of the hearing described in subsection H of this section, or if a hearing is not requested, not less than twenty (20) days after the date of the notice described in subsection G of this section, the police department or its designee shall follow the procedures established in subsections C to E of this section. 
(Ord. 14-05 § 1 (part), 2005) 
10.41.060 - Immediate removal of vehicles from property. 
A.  The police department or its designee may provide for the immediate removal of a vehicle from public or private property to a place of safekeeping at the expense of the registered owner of the vehicle in any of the following circumstances: 
1.  If the vehicle is in such a condition that the continued operation of the vehicle upon the highway would constitute an immediate hazard to the public; 
2.  If the vehicle is parked or standing upon the highway in such a manner as to create an immediate public hazard or an obstruction of traffic; 
3.  If a vehicle is parked in a posted tow away zone. 
4.  If there is reasonable cause to believe that the vehicle or any part of the vehicle is stolen. 
5.  If the vehicle must be seized to preserve evidence of a crime, or if there is reasonable cause to believe that the vehicle was used in the commission of a crime. 
6.  If removal is necessary in the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, storm, snow, natural or man-made disaster, or other emergency. 
7.  If the vehicle is hampering the use of private property by the owner or person in charge of that property or is parked in a manner which impedes the movement of another vehicle. 
8.  If the vehicle is stopped, standing, or parked in a space designated as parking for persons with disabilities and is not permitted by law to be stopped, standing or parked in a space designated as parking for persons with disabilities. 
9.  If the vehicle is located in a clearly identified access aisle or access lane immediately adjacent to a space designated as parking for persons with disabilities. 
10.  If the vehicle is interfering with the use of a ramp or a curb-cut by persons with disabilities. 
B.  If the owner or other person who is legally entitled to possess the vehicle arrives at the location where the vehicle is located before the actual towing or removal of the vehicle, the vehicle shall be disconnected from the tow truck, and the owner or other person who is legally entitled to possess the vehicle may take possession of the vehicle and remove it without interference upon the payment of the reasonable service fee, for which a receipt shall be provided. 
C.  The police department that authorizes the removal of a vehicle under subsection A of this section shall do all of the following: 
1.  Check to determine if the vehicle has been reported stolen. 
2.  Follow the procedures set forth in Section 10.41.040 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 14-05 § 1 (part), 2005) 
10.41.070 - Courts with jurisdiction over issues involving processing of abandoned vehicles, venue in district court-Towing and storage fees. 
A.  The 43rd District Court, Hazel Park, shall have jurisdiction to determine if the police department has acted properly in processing a vehicle under this chapter. 
B.  The court specified in the notice prescribed in Section 10.41.040(A)(5)(b) or Section 10.41.050(G) of this chapter or as provided in Section 10.41.060(C)(2) of this chapter shall be the court that has territorial jurisdiction at the location from where the vehicle was removed or deemed abandoned. Venue in the district court shall be governed by Section 8312 of the revised Judicature Act of 1961, 1961 PA 236, MCL 600.8312. 
C.  If the owner fails to pay the accrued towing and storage fees, the towing and storage bond posted with the court to secure release of the vehicle under Sections 10.41.040, 10.41.050 or 10.41.060 of this chapter shall be used to pay the towing and storage fees. 
(Ord. 14-05 § 1 (part), 2005) 
10.41.080 - Hearing-Findings. 
A.  Upon receipt of a petition prescribed in Sections 10.41.040, 10.41.050 and 10.41.060 signed by the owner of the vehicle which has been taken into custody, the court shall do both of the following: 
1.  Schedule a hearing within thirty (30) days for the purpose of determining whether the police department acted properly; 
2.  Notify the owner and the police department of the time and place of the hearing. 
B.  After the hearing the court shall make a decision which shall include one or more of the following: 
1.  A finding that the police department complied with the procedures established for the processing of an abandoned vehicle or a vehicle removed under Section 10.41.060 of this chapter, and an order providing a period of twenty (20) days after the decision for the owner to redeem the vehicle. If the owner does not redeem the vehicle within twenty (20) days, the police department shall dispose of the vehicle pursuant to Section 10.41.050 or 10.41.090 of this chapter; 
2.  A finding that the police department did not comply with the procedures established for the processing of an abandoned vehicle or a vehicle removed pursuant to Section 10.41.060 of this chapter. After making such a finding, the court shall issue an order directing that the vehicle immediately be released to the owner, and that the police department is responsible for the accrued towing and storage charges; 
3.  A finding that the towing and daily storage fees were reasonable; 
4.  A finding that the towing and daily storage fees were unreasonable and issue an order directing an appropriate reduction. 
(Ord. 14-05 § 1 (part), 2005) 
10.41.090 - Disposition of abandoned vehicles-Disposition of proceeds from sale of vehicles. 
A.  Subject to Section 10.41.040(A)(16) of this chapter, a public sale for a vehicle and its contents that has been determined to be abandoned under Section 10.41.040 or removed under Section 10.41.060 of this chapter shall be conducted in the following manner: 
1.  It shall be under the control of the police department or its designee or the custodian of the vehicle or the custodian's designee; 
2.  It shall be open to the public and consist of open auction bidding or bidding by sealed bids. If sealed bids are received, the person submitting the bid shall receive a receipt for the bid from the police department or the department's designee or, if the vehicle is being sold under Section 10.41.040(A)(16), the custodian of the vehicle; 
3.  Except as otherwise provided in Sections 10.41.040(A)(17) and 10.41.050(G) of this chapter, it shall be held not less than five days after public notice of the sale has been published; 
4.  The public notice shall be published at least once in a newspaper having a general circulation within the county in which the vehicle was abandoned. The public notice shall give a description of the vehicle for sale and shall state the time, date and location of the sale. 
B.  The money received from the public sale of the vehicle shall be applied in the following order of priority: 
1.  Towing and storage charges; 
2.  Expenses incurred by the police department or the custodian of the vehicle; 
3.  Payment of the forty dollars ($40.00) abandoned vehicle fee described in Section 10.41.080(B)(1) of this chapter; 
4.  Any extra money shall be sent to the department of treasury's unclaimed property division to be disbursed as follows: 
a.  To the secured party, if any, in the amount of the debt outstanding on the vehicle. 
b.  Remainder to the Owner. A reasonable attempt shall be made to mail the remainder to the last titled owner. If delivery of the remainder cannot be accomplished, the remainder shall become the property of the city of Hazel Park. 
C.  If there are no bidders on the vehicle, the police department or the custodian of the vehicle may do one of the following: 
1.  Turn the vehicle over to the towing firm or the custodian of the vehicle to satisfy charges against the vehicle. However, if the value of the vehicle does not satisfy the towing fees and accrued daily storage fees, the custodian of the vehicle may collect the balance of those unpaid fees from the last titled owner, subject to Section 10.41.110 of this chapter. 
2.  Obtain title to the vehicle for the police department or the city of Hazel Park by doing the following: 
a.  Paying the towing and storage charges; 
b.  Applying for title to the vehicle. 
3.  Hold another public sale under subsection A of this section. 
D.  A person who acquires ownership of a vehicle under subsection A or C of this section that has been designated as a distressed vehicle shall apply for a salvage certificate of title within fifteen (15) days after obtaining the vehicle. 
E.  Upon disposition of the vehicle, the police department shall provide the Secretary of State with the vehicle's disposition and the name of the agency that disposed of it and shall cancel the entry in the law enforcement information network. 
(Ord. 14-05 § 1 (part), 2005) 
10.41.110 - Recovery of towing or storage fees from owner of abandoned vehicle. 
A.  A towing service, custodian of a vehicle or both shall not be precluded from the recovery of towing fees or, subject to subsection B of this section, storage fees from the last titled owner of a vehicle deemed abandoned under Section 10.41.040 or Section 10.41.050 of this chapter, or removed under Section 10.41.060. 
B.  If a vehicle is released for disposition under Section 10.41.050 or Section 10.41.090 of this chapter, the amount of storage fees that may be collected is whichever one of the following is the least amount: 
1.  The daily storage rate charged by the storage facility. 
2.  One thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
C.  Subsection B of this section does not apply to a commercial vehicle or to a vehicle that is owned or leased by an entity other than an individual. 
(Ord. 14-05 § 1 (part), 2005) 
10.41.120 - Failure to show proof of sale. 
A.  The owner of a motor vehicle who has made a bona fide sale by transfer of his or her title or interest and who has delivered possession of the vehicle and the certificate of title to that vehicle properly endorsed to the purchaser or transferee is not liable for any damages or a violation of law that subsequently results from the use or ownership of the vehicle by another, if the owner, other than a licensed dealer, satisfies the conditions prescribed under subsection B of this section. 
B.  The owner of a motor vehicle, other than a licensed dealer, shall satisfy one of the following conditions: 
1.  Accompany the purchaser of the vehicle to a Secretary of State branch office to assure that the title of the vehicle being sold is transferred. 
2.  Maintain a record of the sale for not less than ten months. As used in this subsection, "record of the sale" means either a photocopy of the reassigned title or a form or document that includes the name, address, driver's license number, and signature of the person to whom the vehicle is sold and the purchase price and date of sale of the vehicle. 
C.  A person who violates subsection B of this section is responsible for a civil infraction and shall be ordered to pay a civil fine of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
D.  A person who violates subsection B of this section is presumed to be the last titled owner and to be liable for towing fees and daily storage fees for an abandoned motor vehicle. 
(Ord. 14-05 § 1 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 10.50 - COST RECOVERY 
Sections: 

10.50.010 - Cost recovery for hazardous/toxic material incidents and hazardous conditions of extended duration. 
A.  The fire department shall be entitled to recover all costs and damages incurred in conjunction with emergency incidents involving hazardous/toxic materials or hazardous conditions of extended duration. Such costs and damages shall include, but not be limited to those associated with incident abatement, cleanup and mitigation, including any related third party costs, which were necessary to ensure the safety of city and its populace. 
B.  Such costs and damages shall be the joint and several responsibility of the owner(s) and/or operator(s) of the property, equipment, vehicle or container causing or contributing to any emergency incident or hazardous condition of extended duration. All such costs and damages shall be paid within thirty (30) days of demand by the fire department unless otherwise approved by city council. 
C.  The city shall have a lien for all unpaid costs and damages incurred by the fire department as above described and may enforce such lien in the manner prescribed by the general laws of the state providing for the enforcement of tax liens. 
(Ord. 05-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.50.020 - Costs recovery for incendiary-type fires. 
A.  The fire department shall be entitled to recover all costs and damages incurred in conjunction with any incendiary-type fire. Such costs shall include, but are not limited to, those associated with the fire extinguishment and investigation. 
B.  Such costs and damages shall be the joint and several responsibility of the person(s) deemed responsible by the fire department as a result of an investigation into the incident. All such costs and damages shall be paid within thirty (30) days of demand by the fire department. 
C.  The city shall have a lien for all unpaid costs and damages incurred by the fire department as above described and may enforce such lien in the manner prescribed by the general laws of the state providing for the enforcement of tax liens. 
(Ord. 05-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.50.030 - Cost recovery for emergency services for nonresidents. 
    The fire department shall be entitled to recover all expenses incurred in the provisions of emergency services to nonresidents of the city of Hazel Park who are neither employees of the city of Hazel Park or Hazel Park business. Council shall by resolution, establish a schedule of fees to be charged for each emergency service, which may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. 05-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.50.040 - Cost recovery for inspection and investigation. 
A.  The fire department shall be entitled to recover costs associated with inspections conducted to verify compliance with this code and state law. Council shall by resolution, establish a schedule of fees to be charged for each inspection, which may be amended from time to time. 
B.  The fire department shall be entitled to recover costs associated with the use of expert consultants and analysts in fire and other emergency investigations. Such actual costs shall be the responsibility of the person(s) deemed to be responsible by the fire department for causing the incident requiring investigation. All such costs shall be paid within thirty (30) days of demand by the fire department. 
C.  The city shall have a lien for all unpaid costs incurred under this section and may enforce such lien in the manner prescribed by the general laws of this state for the enforcement of tax liens. 
(Ord. 05-04 § 1 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 10.72 - SNOW EMERGENCY PARKING 
Sections: 

10.72.010 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter:
